My favorite tower defense game, and I've played a lot of them. A lot has been said about the option to essentially code unit behavior in the game. I dabbled in this a bit, but wasn't particularly interested. It isn't required to succeed, though I imagine it might matter if you're into competitive pvp multiplayer.

The game is criminally under-priced. While I might not have initially picked it up at a higher price, at this point I would gladly pay triple or quadruple. There's also still new development being done, and I'm excited to see what the next version is like.

Version 7 added another planet with a whole new campaign and set of blocks/buildings and units. I have mixed feelings about a couple of details, but overall really enjoyed it. I would say the factory mechanics in the new planet (Erekir) are more complex and challenging, but as a result also more engaging. The new units also feel more different from each other, and the differences in how they path around terrain makes for challenge in the variety of paths you have to defend against. The new Erekir campaign is much better designed than Serpulo, feels like a natural evolution and improvement. That said, I'm glad that Serpulo is still there; I still enjoy it for it's different style of play.

My nitpicks for Erekir:
- Visually, I think it looks amazing. But I also sometimes struggle to tell at a glance what's going on. The changes to make routing more challenging are annoying, but make sense to me. I just find it harder to tell which building is which, and most importantly what is being carried in each duct. Surge conveyors are also visually more "noisy" than plastanium conveyors.
- The new "RTS-like" method of unit control is nice, and much more convenient. However, I feel like this has led to a shift in the overall tone of the game towards a more RTS style of play, and thus away from tower defense. I'm undecided on how I feel about this. I think it's a net improvement, but I prefer playing tower defense overall.

There's now a V8 coming. At this point, I think the game is worth double what it costs, and if V8 is as good as it looks in the sample videos, it will be worth triple after release.

Mindustry: If you have a life, not anymore.

It is by far the most addictive game that I know.
Both campaigns are well balanced and have different tech trees and topology. 
Each battlefield unlocks new tech, which scratches that upgrade itch.
This pushes me for just one more hour, away from actually having a life and being productive.

To give you an idea, I restarted this mission Intersect 7 times, spent maybe 10 hours because the enemy AI kept attacking weak spots with aerial. Then when I get those plugged I counter attack one of their 3 bases, big mistake, they had amassed about 200 tier 3 units which razed my base. That was my 5th attempt. 
On the last attempt I get nearly pulverized but my long range canons saved the base, unfortunately aerials took out 2 out of the 3 reactors so all resources came to a grinding halt. So here I am, as the one surviving is busy taking out my inner walls, I reroute the magma to bypass Nitrogen reactors and fill the chemical power plants, shut down the secondary mining to reroute enough power to kick start beryllium production so that I can rebuild the conveyors to some inner guns to take out that last mech. 
And just when I get back to positive power output, a second wave storms in.
It took 3 hours just to get back on my feet and I went to bed at 2am.

When you play this game you start seeing blocks and re routing liquids in your dreams. It's bad.

It is a simple game but very well made. The graphics are scalable, not pixelated. It combines seamlessly exploration, factory (factorio/shapezz/etc. style), RTS style units, tower defense and attack.

I have more than 10 days' worth of IRL time in the game over the span of owning it for around 2-3 years (I think? I don't play on my PC super-often), and I can for sure say- it's unique from other games of its type, and it's overall a wonderful experience.
It combines factory/resource-management, tower defense, and exploration all into one big game, with dozens upon dozens of sectors to explore.
The controls are simple enough, and the mechanics are easy to get used to.
For people who struggle with certain aspects of the game, there's also a catalog of sorts always available at the player's disposal containing all sorts of useful information about every single unit, tile, resource and status effect in the game (to my knowledge, at least.)
The sectors are all split up between five difficulties and two different types- Attack, and Defense, which helps spice up the game even more.
There's also online multiplayer, as well as community-run servers, and said servers also have numerous 'game-modes' of sorts of their own, and the users (at least from what I've experienced) are friendly- but that shouldn't drive you away from the campaign.
After all, it has a lot to offer, and I'm sure an unreasonable amount of effort went into making the game, as well as every single update.

All in all, I've loved the game from the start, and I still very much enjoy it now. There's updates every once in a while, and within the last year there was a major update which overhauled certain mechanics or systems and added an entire new planet with all-new objectives, tiles, units- Basically, it's like a sequel, but in the same game. Final Rating: 10/10.

Mindustry, a unique blend of tower defense, real-time strategy, and resource management, offers a compelling and addictive gameplay experience that stands out in the indie game scene. Developed by Anuken, Mindustry challenges players to not only defend their base from waves of enemies but to also manage resources, construct production chains, and optimize layouts to ensure efficiency and survival. This review explores Mindustry’s key aspects, including gameplay mechanics, level design, replayability, community support, and innovation, providing a detailed overview of what makes the game both engaging and challenging.

1. Gameplay Mechanics
Rating: 9/10 - Excellent
Mindustry excels in its gameplay mechanics, seamlessly merging elements of different genres into a cohesive and engaging experience. Players must gather resources, build processing units, and create defenses against relentless enemy waves. The game’s depth comes from the need to balance resource collection with defense, requiring strategic planning and quick adaptation to changing situations. The mechanics encourage creativity in designing efficient production lines and defensive layouts, rewarding players for innovative strategies and optimization.

2. Level Design
Rating: 8/10 - High
The level design in Mindustry is varied and challenging, offering a wide range of environments that require players to adapt their strategies. Each map presents unique geographical features and resource distribution, pushing players to rethink their usual tactics. The procedural generation of maps in certain modes adds to the replayability, ensuring that no two games feel the same. Some levels, especially those later in the game, can feel overwhelming due to the difficulty spike, but this also serves to maintain a high level of engagement.

3. Replayability
Rating: 9/10 - Excellent
Replayability is one of Mindustry’s strongest suits. The game offers multiple modes, including campaign, survival, and custom games with adjustable difficulty settings. The procedural generation of maps and the ability to design and share custom maps with the community significantly enhance the game's replay value. Additionally, the continuous challenge of optimizing and rethinking strategies to improve efficiency keeps the gameplay fresh and engaging over time.

4. Community Support
Rating: 8/10 - High
Mindustry boasts a robust and active community that contributes greatly to the game's appeal with STEAM Workshop. The community-driven content, including custom maps, mods, and schemes, extends the game's longevity and adds layers of depth to the gameplay. Developer engagement with the community, through regular updates and responsiveness to feedback, fosters a positive environment that encourages player investment and content creation. However, newcomers might find the vast array of community content and the intricacies of more advanced gameplay slightly intimidating at first.

5. Innovation
Rating: 9/10 - Excellent
Mindustry stands out for its innovative approach to blending genres. The game takes familiar elements from tower defense, RTS, and resource management games and combines them in a way that feels both fresh and familiar. This innovation extends to the game's open-source nature, allowing for community contributions that continually enhance and expand the game beyond its original scope. Mindustry’s emphasis on efficiency, strategy, and creativity sets it apart from traditional games in its category, offering a unique and captivating experience.

Overall Summary and Score
Overall Rating: 8.6/10 - Excellent
Mindustry is a testament to the depth and engagement that indie games can offer. With its excellent gameplay mechanics, challenging level design, high replayability, strong community support, and innovative approach to genre-blending, Mindustry provides a rich and satisfying experience. The game encourages strategic thinking, creativity, and adaptation, appealing to both casual players and those seeking a deeper challenge.

Strongly Recommended for fans of strategy, tower defense, and resource management games; a must-play for those who enjoy optimization and creativity in gameplay.

Mindustry is a fun tower defense game, and I highly recommend it. There is a decent amount of content in the game from the start, as well as workshop support for mods, maps, and more. The game features a campaign where you capture sectors on planets by surviving waves of enemies or taking over enemy bases, as well as multiple modes outside of the campaign like survival, sandbox, PVP, and attack. The game also has a built-in map editor, so you can create your own maps using all of the features in the game. Pretty much everything available in the game can be done in a multiplayer setting; if you don't want to play solo, there are servers as well. I would say this game is well worth the $11.49 price tag!

I intended to give an "neutral" review instead of a recommend.

Mindustry is VERY different from factorio, it's more of a tower defense game or RTS game (depend on defense or attack mission) with a "little" factory element. I'd say the tower defense aspect is the most fun and refined, the towers are cool, the enemies are cool the maps are cool, and the strategy elements with the all three combined, are very good and fun. 

But the other two aspects (RTS and factory) are both the quality of an early access title which lack significant quality of life feature. The RTS unit control system is borderline unplayable, but at least we can pause and take it slow.

The factory aspect ... well ... just ... just play factorio if factory is what you want. This game doesn't have a proper automation feature but simply jammed a assembly interpreter into the game. If you have a programming background then it might be ok for you. If you don't though, this game might be a bit rough.

Game is fun at times but also irritating, The enemy wave maps are too easy at times, while the siege base ones are difficult. one common thing I found is after you attack an enemy base on Erekir and lose all your troops, the AI will send a BS amount of waves/enemies towards your base, when your at your weakest. This type of game play encourages you to grind out so many troops/units that you destroy the base on your first attempt. In other words, the game encourages you to waste a lot of your time building a crap ton of troops. This will be fine and all if the game had a save and load function, but you can only save upon quitting. This means you waste hours just to build up your troops, fail to destroy the enemy base, and then get ridiculous amount of enemy waves as you watch everything you build get destroyed. 

Hopefully they'll make the difficulty curve better instead of "oh, your attacking our base, time to ramp up to 200% productivity."  I hope I can change this to a thumbs up in the future.

I'm amending my original review after trying both campaigns. The old review remains (with a couple of additional thoughts), as it still reflects my thoughts on the older, original campaign, which is still in the game (you can freely switch between them while playing). I more strongly recommend the new "Serpulo" campaign.

New review (New campaign, Serpulo):

Overall, pretty good. It lacks some QoL features and the controls are a little janky. But designing and building the "factory" is fun, similar to Factorio.

The new campaign changes the learning curve and unit/building availability (and art) significantly. It's the main reason I haven't permanently put the game down.

I haven't yet had nearly the same level of frustration with controls and UI that I have with the old campaign. But...
* Lots of the blocks/buildings still look somewhat similar. But at 12 hours into the newer Serpulo campaign, it's not nearly as bad. Have not had to build or pickup containers yet (not sure if this building/transport method is part of the newer campaign).
* Still have to drag and drop items from my ship to the core. After thinking about it a little more, it's really not so bad.
* Placing belts still not fun.

New complaints:
* I wanted more than a wave defense game. While the older campaign had levels that weren't all wave defense, the new campaign seems to be ALL wave defense. It's a little bit vanilla
* Related to above - the early game seems to focus VERY strongly on building towers. I've beaten maybe ten levels so far without building a single mobile unit. I would like something more dynamic
* Configuring factories for units to be rebuilt into the next level unit is still a PITA.
* Dealing with severe space constraints on some levels isn't that fun to me.
* Can't decide if I like the fact that larger ore deposits can't be 100% mined, due to having to place belts over parts of the deposits. It adds a little more challenge to selecting belt and drill locations, but it frustrates my desire for efficiency. And when deposits are combined with space constraints and/or very close to walls, that's worse. Some deposits just can't be mined because of where they're located. That seems like a waste. Perhaps later in the campaign there are buildings to address this.



Old review (old campaign):

I want to like this game so much. But the controls and UI are REALLY bad.

* Half of the buildings look almost the same. It's so hard to see within few seconds the type of building I'm trying to make.
* I need to drag and drop items from my ship into the core in order to use them to build things FROM THE SHIP? Why can't I just use what's on the ship if it's needed?
* Placing belts still not fun. Should be more like (and better than) Factorio.
* Picking up containers using the keyboard is/was a dumb idea. I can't just CLICK it?? And I can't just BUILD one on top of an empty container transporter/cannon? I have to build it somewhere clear and THEN pick it up and drop it onto the transporter using two DIFFERENT keyboard buttons? I'm trying to relax while playing this game, not hunch over a keyboard and mouse and hunt and peck for special keyboard controls. The default keys need to be different or something.

Mindustry is basically two games: Serpulo and Erekir. There's very little crossover between them. The mechanics for each are similar and yet different. Each has some advantages and disadvantages.

Overall pros:
This game is like a Factorio clone, that doesn't do Factorio as well as Factorio, but does enough other things differently and right, that it's still unique and fun, and not just "a standalone Factorio mod".

Overall cons:
Block/icon graphics aren't very unique and can be confusing.
RTS unit control is clunky.
Mod community and availability is still pretty weak.

The absolute worst crime this game makes is something essentially all RTS games have had figured out since Warcraft 1: DON"T CHANGE THE BLOCK LOCATION AND ORDERING! It's extremely irritating that most new blocks reorder and relocate all the old blocks. This is especially bad on Erekir where all the block graphics/icons are so similar and losing the location-memorization means you have to slowly hover and re-read every single one, and re-write your memorization. And then just when you're starting to get used to the change, a new one is unlocked and BREAKS EVERYTHING AGAIN! Extremely irritating. Happens on both planets, but it's especially bad on Erekir.


Overall Score 6.5/10:
I put almost 200 hours into it over the holiday vacation. It's no Factorio, but it has a lot of interesting and unique mechanics. Mindustry has more RTS elements where Factorio is more (veeery zoomed out) solo-adventure. The planetary region exploration, multiple planets, unique features, all make it a worthwhile game to check out for people bored with Factorio, and looking for something a little different.

For a full review and massive spoilers, look in my conversation thread:
https://steamcommunity.com/app/1127400/discussions/0/4042609216213209006/

I played Serpulo, there are just too many damn turrets, too many resources to manage and set up and too many units to automate, it's utterly ridiculous, so I fell off of it right around Thorium.

I played on the v7 update, enjoyed Erekir, felt like Anuke learnt from the mistakes of Serpulo, up until missions were taking me literally several hours to complete. Siege took me 9 and a half hours before I realized that I wasn't playing a Tower Defense-RTS hybrid, but instead, I was playing an overdeveloped idle game that can't even satisfy, or give me progress for going offline.
I never beat it, it only got halfway there before staring at another actual hour of doing nothing but waiting for my army to rebuild so I could push the enemy, destroy another literal 12 buildings, and potentially just be back to square one again.

However, it seems Anuke didn't learn from every mistake of Serpulo, I'm a patient man, I think a mission taking 3 hours is a good medium for every single mission, asking the player for anything more than that is you taking the piss.
Your game takes too long to play Anuke, to quote the great Chef Ramsay; I wouldn't even serve it to a freaking pig.

EDIT: Review isn't wrong and it's still fully accurate, I'm just adding more because a new campaign, Erekir is here, and while it's a somewhat more condensed experience, it's got its own special slew of problems.

1. Fluid pipes work differently, for absolutely no reason, routers wil not connect to bending pipes directly adjacent to them, a pipe must travel in a given direction for 1 tile and then bend for it to connect, this blatantly sucks and causes pipe layouts to become excessively more cumbersome, obnoxious and downright infuriating to deal with. Bridge to pipe connections and junction to pipe connections don't operate this way for absolutely no reason. You cannot convince me that turning an Erekir pipe router into the same thing as a serpulio pipe route would degrade the campaign.

2. Ducts are the replacement for normal Serpulio belts and they lack junctions, requiring the use of bridges, which happily and heavily combines with the above point to make later bases, for all intents and purposes, absolutely confusing because A. You cannot toggle the visiblity of various graphics via in-game menus (seriously put checkboxes in the bottom left, there is functionally no need for that part of the screen to be empty when this QoL feature can be there for great effect) but those same graphics indicate power transmission as beam towers, (a new feature and a different way power connections are made which I prefer (ISH). And B. Combined with pipe routers working badly like that, it results in your base effectively turning into more of a confusing mess of belts and pipes that communicate almost nothing when it comes to figuring out the actual problems in them due to it having to become so utterly convoluted for the base to vaguely function past the first ten levels.

Cool thing: Erekir is linear (more or less) so there's (almost) never a question of which mission to do next

3. The later the mission in Erekir, the longer it takes. Anuken seems to think that if something takes a player more time to accomplish, it means it's more difficult. The game can be paused, in the mission I'm in as of writing, it is the 5th time I've played it, a grand total of 2 playthroughs that got this far, with 4 total playthroughs, it is Level 10, and this mission by itself takes 2 hours just to get to 7 of 24 waves because the map is both so huge, and the waves can't be sent while enemies from a wave still remain (for no reason, just make the victory condition be that the final wave has been reached, no cores and no enemy units remain, actually simple) which means that it will effectively take you, this is including pauses because the pipe system and belt system on Erekir is not well implemented, approximately 7 hours to beat it.

Seriously Anuken, your game takes too long. Why did I delete my previous save? Because I got to the point where Tier 3 walkers are usable, and by this point I had been playing maps with terrible resource layouts that ultimately resulted in me having really messy belt layouts, because the armored belt for no reason whatsoever, just has more armor and health and not...

More speed, the thing that'd make it vaguely good because generally if your belts are being attacked, you're already dead, because that means there are no turrets left between the enemy and your core.

In this level which sends T3 walkers at you also has artillery turrets capable of annihilating more things on the ground with impunity. They are located in a position swarming with anti-air turrets, both of which are also defended by very small heavily defended chokepoints. I had played on this map for a total of about 12 hours before effectively rage quitting because, for all intents and purposes, the enemy could not kill me, and never would.
And I couldn't kill them and never would, I'd know, because I explored that Entire Map and at the time, found no way to crippled the air defenses, and not matter how many ground units I sent all at once, the artillery would kill most, and then the chokepoints would mop the rest.

I believe it's only 6 levels where I am now, and I believe there are still many more to play on Erekir after that.

I simply have a single question. Is it possible to beat the last mission in under 4 hours? If not, I'd like to ask Anuken specifically why he thinks that's a good design decision in the slightest. Nobody really cares how much of a game people play because ultimately people will play whatever mind-slaves them the hardest regardless of quality.

The only solitary reason I still play it is because I am working on my own campaign (very slowly) and would like to brainstorm while playing, and to drag my friend along for the ride in the level I stalemated in because ultimately I'm unsure if that level is badly made, or if I'm just being dense.

After investing about 70 hours into "Mindustry", I've found it to be an incredibly engaging and deep game that constantly challenges and rewards strategic thinking. The blend of tower defense and factory management is executed brilliantly, requiring not just defensive tactics but also efficient resource management and infrastructure planning.

Overall, Mindustry is a must-play for fans of strategy and tower defense games. Its challenging gameplay, strategic depth, and cooperative elements, coupled with its retro-inspired visuals, make it a standout game that's both rewarding and enjoyable.

Mindustry has quickly become one of my favorite games ever, being a very digestible factory game with insanely good tower defense and rts factors, with two separate worlds basically acting as 2 separate campaigns. The art style is nice, and the music is great. My only gripe with the game is that mods are weird to install; as they are the messing with files to install type of mods that don't use the steam workshop. The steam workshop is reserved for schematics.

This game is a great combo of factory management (ie: Satisfactory, Factorio) mixed with Tower Defense (see: classic Warcraft 3 Custom TD maps) and RTS.

There are 3 major game mechanics:
1) Production - collecting resources and using them to manufacture increasingly advanced and useful products.
2) Defense -  building towers, generating and delivering ammo to the towers, generating and delivering liquid cooling to the towers to protect your base.
3) Offense -  using raw resources to create groups of controllable units, which you control and mobilize in the style of RTS to infiltrate/destroy/capture the enemy base.

The campaign is robust. From what I  gather, there are two distinct campaigns with distinct resources and tech trees. It feels like two games worth of content in that respect.

Both tech trees are quite massive, as is to be expected with a factory management game. As you progress through the campaign(s), your options for how you create raw resources evolves significantly as you unlock more advanced tech. Lots of new ways to generate power, generate and move liquids, generate and move solids. Some ideas are pretty unique and really change how you plan each mission as you unlock higher tier tech.

There are tons and tons of missions. The campaigns are quite rewarding and challenging. Once you get through the initial 5-10 tutorial missions, the campaign opens up and gives you more freedom to choose your next mission among multiple options. Most missions boil down to one of two objectives: 1) survive X amount of enemy waves (so a more typical tower defense objective), or 2) infiltrate and destroy the enemy's base(s) (so more in the style of an RTS.)


The online co-op is essentially seamless. It's wild how some games have so much trouble with netplay, and then you get a game like Mindustry where you don't even think about it because the netplay  just works. No obscure way of hosting/inviting. Literally "open menu-> host server" then "open menu-> invite friend to server." Invites go through steam like all steam supported games should. Super easy like all netplay should be. In about 40 coop hours playing with friends, we have had 1 single instance of desync, which could just as easily be the result of internet lag. Beyond that, we've had no drops, no rubberbanding, no difficulty joining or accepting invites via steam.

As a big fan of Tower Defense games. I'm very pleased with the tower defense aspects of the game. I could easily imagine a lesser game including basic tower defense elements and calling it good. Not Mindustry. So far (have not beaten the purple world campaign yet) there are at least 10 different towers with very different use cases. Many towers use  a variety of different ammo types, which gives you agency as a player to choose the best ammo for your mission, and also gives you the choice to evolve to better/different ammo as the mission progresses. I also really appreciate the water cooling element of the towers, which allow towers to fire more rapidly, but further complicates the way you build your defenses, which makes it all that much more satisfying when you come up with a really efficient/aesthetically pleasing design.

Overall, a great game for fans of resource management, base building, tower defense, and RTS.

Before Update 7's release, I would have called this a hard choice to recommend. Early on, the sectors that can be captured allow a variety of strategies, but as you proceed deeper into the game, viable strategies narrow into one "optimal" path to capture new sectors while forcing you to defend newly captured sectors against an overwhelming assault from multiple others. Update 7 added a new planet that takes a base building/tower defense game and turns it into a subpar RTS that punishes anything but rock paper scissors play. I got my $10 worth out of it, but can't recommend it at this point.

I came back to this game after a year or two. I played it on steam, later even got it on mobile. I saw RCE play it and got excited and I am shocked. The game actually feels worse and barely improved.

First the good parts: I like that you can choose between different planets and each gives you a different experience. I like that you have more control over mobile units in the new mode. The idea of multi-stage sectors is also neat and the enemies having bases has some great RTS-vibes, even though I think of this game more like a factory-game and less an RTS, but if that's the devs vision it is totally fine. I never got into multiplayer or schematics but I hear people love it.

The not so good parts: I dislike the new system. Yes, I can always play the old one, but firstly, even the dev implies that it's the "worse experience" as in unbalanced. Forget that, they explicitly state that the new campaign is the better experience. And I'm not expecting them to work on the old system anymore. So I play an abandoned, unpolished, unbalanced mode. But also most devs will not give you this choice and that's a still a big plus.

But back to the new system. It's... not great. Some redesigns are fine. The wall drilling is interesting and the huge turrets are fun, even though (at least early on) it feels slow and not that great of an experience. I do not like the new minerals. The art, color and names feel wrong, somehow, but that's just my opinion and I can't really explain it anyways. 

But what I can confidently say is bad is the energy system. I hate it. It is clunky. And now you always need to work around those static, straight lasers. I also don't think it introduces any meaningful new challenge or gameplay. You already have a lot of routing management through the conveyor belts so why add this? What is its purpose and why choose it over the "smart" radius connection energy system of the old version? Maybe I am missing something, but so far it was more annoying than fun. 
Also why are there lasers connecting to machines when they have no power? I had many machines not running because I thought they were connected until I found the one segment where the lasers weren't connected. Again the visual language is unclear. 

The second thing are the new conveyor belts. What were they thinking? It is not only unsatisfying, because watching small thingies move is one of the big appeals of these kinds of games, akin to old sims like rollercoaster tycoon and the settlers. And now I can't, because they are obstructed by those arrows. Again, the old system solved it much more elegantly by just animating the belts. Am I crazy for feeling like they moved backwards? 
Next bad aspect of the new belts is: I can not for the love of good see if its a normal belt, a router or something else. Because that too is obstructed by these arrows. It's frustrating. The visual design is cluttered, much harder to read, both in type of belt part and what is transported. Not to mention that there are lasers everywhere adding to the whole readability-aspect. Theres also a glaring lack of adjustment options in the menu for these things. 

Lastly, what I think is absolutely terrible: The controls. They are bad. I actually, and I can't believe I'm saying this, prefer the controls on mobile. Why can't I move with a mouse click, unless I completely rebind many controls? Why is there no button to toggle the conveyor arrows? Why do I have to push "shift" for the unit control mode and why is there no toggle for that either? I had to rebind those because I got cramps from the hand contortions I had to make to move the camera with wasd, while pressing shift (I am a leftie). Why can't I move the camera independently from my character except with mouse 5?! Why is there no border scrolling? Why can't I zoom while I have build placement selected (just change rotate building to Q and E like most games do). Why can't I move the camera by clicking on the minimap. Also why is the minimap so tiny? Why oh god why is respawn on V? I respawned so many times while hitting space to pause. V is another key that is traditionally used for actions that are performed regularily like dodging, melee, etc. Is respawning really that important and used that often that you have it on V and not on something like F3 or Del? In general why are many keybinds so unintuitive? The controls have gotten much more convoluted and counter-intuitive since I last played. Why are there so many gameplay options that I don't know what they are doing and other more essential ones are missing? What is the difference between Hints and Logic Hints? Why does it say "double-tap to mine"?`I am not playing on mobile. If I remove the checkbox next to "Hold for command mode" does it toggle then? Why name it in a way where it is already enabled but doesn't tell you what it does when you disable it? What does "control unit" mean? I though I control my unit with wasd and other units by holding shift, selecting them and right clicking? Why group left and right and forward and backward movement into pairs and name it X and Y? I am not on a controller. And as far as I know this game doesn't even have controller support. What the hell is "Mouse Forward" and "Mouse Backward"? I deduced that its mouse 4 and 5 most likely but that naming scheme never came across me in 20 years of gaming. Oh, also what does "Auto-Create saves" mean? That one is actually funny to me because it might just be a translation issue (idk the native language of the devs, but I would assume that if english is not their native language by now they should have had a capable translator). I think what they mean is "Enable Auto Saves"? And I hope I am right but if that is true then Why is that option not immediately below the "Save Interval" slider? In short: The options are a jumbled mess and need a serious decluttering and rework. Change default keybinds, remove or reword confusing options, add some more meaningful options and clarify existing options (maybe even add tooltips on a mouseover? But please give them a delay, because instant tooltips in menus that obstruct other lines are worse than no tooltips).

Yes, many people can and probably will say that "just change the settings", "You'll get used to it" and "just don't play the new mode if you don't like it" but that's often a sign of being too used to a clunky system or not knowing that it could be better. And some people might think that I say this because I hate the game. But I WANT the game to be good. I used to enjoy it and I do like some changes and I think there is lots of potential. But I am very confused by many decisions the devs made and I would love to know why they choose this instead of improving on the old system. Especially because many of the issues are quite obvious and also rather easy to fix. And even though this is somewhat emotionally charged I hope the devs, if they read this, can hear the honest criticism.

I want this game to be great. But at this point I can not recommend it and would rather play the old version.

During 2018, I was bored and had no money to spend and a end of the run laptop. I was looking for simple free games on my phone. That's when I found a certain game. 

[h1] Mindustry [/h1]

At first it was a simple pixelated game with a basic goal of defending against some towers. What was appealing to me at first was the complexity already available to me. I could create a system of automated production to help me go against endless waves of enemies. The game continued to receive support slowly and then I soon discovered tiny servers of people playing as well. One of my favorite pastimes was to play this game on multiplayer learning new build ideas and try to survive as far as I could. I downloaded the game on my phone and showed it to all my friends. Sadly all great stories come to end. After a while I would play less and less. I tried to switch up my games and find new ways to entertain myself. The app stayed on my phone untouched, doing nothing. But then again I became bored. I played again and something spectacular happened. 

[h1] The update [/h1] 

My phone said it was ready to update. This update became the starting foundation of the current version of Mindustry. I was amazed by the new graphics, mechanics, enemies, strategy, etc. I bought it on steam and started playing non stop. The game received constant updates and support. 

[h1] The Good [/h1]

The gameplay on PC is very seamless. You have a flying ship that can move anywhere you want and you build anywhere to. Each game follows a similar progression of starting off with limited resources, trying to get top tier resources to build defenses and armys. but depending on gamemode or map it can change this. What is amazing is the amount of complexity you can include. The game gives you the option to use logic in your conveyor systems to help you maximize efficiency. If you are worried about having to manually build giant systems of factories and conveyors each game, the game has a system called schematics which allows you to save your builds to paste for later use. 

Once you master the campaigns your first objective is to play multiplayer. The amount of servers constantly running is amazing. There are PVP, Attack, and survival maps. Playing on these servers, especially PVE, will help with your strategy and schematics. My favorite gamemode is PVP. You must build as fast as you can try to take out other players with your own bot army. The scale of these battles can be team's vs teams or solo players battling it out in a royale. 

The game has a decent mod following already. The steam workshop is lacking in overhaul mods but the ones present are very good. 

[h1] The Bad [/h1]

Sadly nothing is perfect, (But this is close) 

The campaign itself can be grindy at times. You have to gather resources and then launch (which ends the game) to collect them. Then you can research new items. This can get annoying if you don’t gather enough stuff, but at a certain point you unlock the launch pad which automatically launches items for you without leaving the game.

Multiplayer is one of the best parts of the game but can be the worst. A problem in the game is griefing. Every few games a griefer will join and try to destroy as many blocks as possible. Usually though it only takes 20 seconds before they are banned and the game continues. To avoid griefing you can join a PVP server with no teams but you can join when a game is halfway complete. You will instantly spawn on an army of bots that will destroy you instantly. But these problems are not enough to stop me from playing. Griefers aren’t common to ruin the game yet and hopefully before it gets worse, a better anti grief system is implemented. To fix the PVP problem just make your own game or try to join at the beginning of the game. 

[h1] Final Choice [/h1]

It should be no surprise that I highly recommend that game greatly. This is one of the few games that I constantly play. 

For a game that only six dollars it over delivers. And if you don’t want to pay six, you can easily get it on sale or just get it for free. But if you want to support the developer, I would buy the game. The game offers so much and will continue with more updates

[h1] Tips [/h1]

Check out the official discord, which can be accessed from the game, to get schematics and advice. 
play multiplayer to discuss ideas and builds.

[h1] TL;DR [/h1]
 
You like sandbox games with tower defense mechanics, buy this game. If not, its only six dollars.

EDIT: VERSION 6 IS HERE AND I LOVE IT (rip instant transport)

Tower Defense where supply chains and resource management are both important.  Frustratingly enough: a turret (or tower) won't shoot without ammunition (or power) after all. You therefore not only need to manage the enemies on their way to your core, but also the factories and power supply as well.

Comes with both the 'Survive' mode, where waves come in and have to be eliminated, as well as Sandbox variant. Furthermore there exist PvP and Attack maps as well, where multiple parties have a core: here you'll be sending in waves and attacking the opponent's core yourself.

Fun and updated regularly! Since the first version of this review an entire extra planet with slightly different energy sources & mechanics was added.

I've played off and on as the game evolved, the soundtrack hits as you delve deeper into the game, as you unlock more tech, fight new enemies.. and fight true terror...

The game gives me the nostalgia of Total Annihilation but with the micromanagement of building a city of towers, resources, and an endless wave of destruction. 

I highly recommend everyone to give the game a go you won't be disappointed and it even has co-op which is addicting to say the least.

Mindustry is everything that is great about the open source community introduced to gaming. It's a popular game format; a logistical factory defense game a la Factorio, but has it's own fun and unique twists. But the truly impressive part is that Mindustry is both open source and highly moddable. Want to know EXACTLY how X works? You can just look at the code. And with the recent additions of 2 campaigns and a world domination mode...it's truly a great game, and you can literally download it for free from the source repository. Or come get it off steam and send the devs a nice kickback.

The game is self-described as "An open-ended tower-defense game with a focus on resource management." The resources management part of the game is the one that is played like Factorio, but simpler. You collect some resources, you build something with the resources, and you collect new resources, and you build something new with the new resources, throw in some electricity management, and you get the gist of it. There is a tech tree in the game, but unlike Factorio, you only need to unlock it once to be able to use it in the future; technology limitation is usually caused by resource limitation (in sum and type) in the current map.

While you're building up your resources and facilities, enemies will spawn in waves, the longer you play the harder (in general) the waves get. This is where the tower defense part comes into play. Tower-defense gameplay usually starts with you building some of the cheapest towers near the enemy spawn point, after building up some resources you start upgrading your towers. You could also build some mech factories, where you can make some combat units with limited commands (either stay, attack, or retreat). Planning usually involves consideration of the geography (where land units will come from, where air units will come from), resources availability, how much space you got for the towers and it support (ammo lines, electricity, and cooling), and most importantly, how long do you plan to stay in the map. This brings us to the last point...

Open-ended. The enemy waves never end. Every certain number of waves (different for each map) you'll be given a chance to launch your core and leave the map, bringing every resource you have in your cores home; these is the resources you used to go up the tech tree. Depending on how long you stay in the game, you may also unlock the next map(s). This is one of the game's great points. If you just want to play some light game that won't last an hour, you can plan your game for several waves only. On the contrary, if you want to test your limit and play for hours and hours to mine every resource on the map, build every facility you want and tons and tons of towers and try to get that 500 waves clear achievement, you can!

In short, yes the game plays like Factorio but with a simpler system and much faster pace, but the same level of enjoyment (some would argue it's more!). The dev is also very active; new features are constantly added to the game. So again, with this price, there is no reason not to buy the game.

I saw this game on youtube and I must admit, I was skeptical. I love Factorio. I love Satisfactory. I love Dyson Sphere Program. All three great games. Most of them fairly chill and even Factorio is more or less chill, with you simply having to advance in tech to defend yourself every now and then from not too threatening enemies.

This game was described to me as a combination of the three + RTS. And I wasnt too sure that I would like it. Well I think my number of hours kinda speaks for itself here. For 10 whole bucks, this game is genuinly worth your money. From the general level of creativity you can have as well as really engaging gameplay and a ever expanding level of difficulty the longer you play. 

New ways to defeat enemies, new ways to gather ressources. More ores, more liquids, ways to make more out of your ressources and even using other ressources to make the same you already have but without ever having to mine for the rest.

It is a fairly complex and fairly indepth game and I cant love it more. For 10 bucks, its way more than worth your money. Id even pay 40 bucks for this easily and this isnt something I say a lot about many games I played. Tho granted, 40 bucks would also likely set very different expectations so the price the game has also does a lot for its accessible popularity.

If you got a few bucks left and nothing to spend them on and love the other three games mentioned: Go buy this game. You wont regret it.

I mean... on the logistics side, Factorio is far superior. So all this has going for it is the tower defense/RTS gameplay. But even there, like, building up your base in factorio, encasing it in thick walls bristling with guns, then setting up artillery emplacements to clear out the next area for expansion, before you tower-creep your way over there and control another heavily-defended outpost in the middle of the creep... that's so much more exciting and engaging an experience than this game. Which is just, there are spawn points. Enemies spawn at those points at predictable intervals. And then you just build a wall at the spawn point(s) and they run into those exact points over and over. The maps are tiny and claustrophobic, with indestructible mountains everywhere; every successful map makes you start over from stage 1 with another boring basic spaghetti build, where you again have to set up all these stupid mining drills that only mine directly underneath themselves and block outflow from neighbouring drills so you have to directly place these stupid anthill-looking drill setups, to make room for all the belts, in the most unengaging base-building ever.
And after you've done all that, here comes the boss, and while the boss in the last level died in 5 seconds, this one walks straight through your defences, that so far haven't even taken damage in even the biggest waves (should've built those defences 3 times as deep as the level teaches you to build them!), and then he walks all the way to your core and destroys it. But at least when you re-start into the level all your buildings are still there so what was the point?

Even playing Starcraft 1 against AIs better captures both the defence-focus and the "the factory must grow" themes of this game. Just an absolutely failed execution of a great concept.

Mindustry feels very engaging at the start but it falls apart very soon due to its repetitive nature, annoying controls, and overall unpolished feel. 

The loop of the game consists in playing different maps in which you build factories to get materials to build turrets and ammo. As you progress you gain access to levels with new materials that unlock more advanced tech. 

Dealing with the enemy waves can be frustrating early on. Maps are built so they have a lot ot paths to your base, and predicting the route the enemies will take is annoying. Wrangling the enemies so they end up in your defenses feels more like trial and error and cheesing, than actual tactical thinking. The main gripe though is the lack of info in the enemy types. A very common occurence is that all the normal waves are ground enemies while the boss is a giant flying robot that just flies over terrain to your core and annihilates it. 

The point where I couldnt be bothered anymore was when levels have enemy bases and you're expected to destroy them. This is an extremely slow and tedious process of either advancing your turret line inch by inch into range of the enemy buildings (this has a limit as you cannot build near the enemy core), or building your own units, which feel tremendously weak so it's a very boring war of attrittion.
Very fun, lots to explore.

EDIT: the game's new update is awful.

-It's more of a unit management type game than a resource farm/tower defense game now, meaning it's kludgy unit management system is something you're going to be working with a lot.
-It got rid of your ship's gun. It was weak, but it was critical when you didn't have units yet (which are expensive) and some random enemy units walk past your defenses and starts shooting up your base.
-The level selection is unnecessarily awkward. I've spent way too much time rotating the globe looking for the next sector I'm supposed to play.
-The enemy is just not fun to play against. It's hard to see where the enemy is coming from, since you need aforementioned expensive units to explore the map.
-The starting resources on most of the levels are incredibly small too, while the computer gets a whole developed base to start with.

The base game had it's flaws, but was also a million times more enjoyable. Just play on Serpulo instead of Erekir, I promise you, you're saving yourself a lot of headache. If the new update is any indication as to the direction this game is going, then that is incredibly depressing, since there were just a few kinks in pre-version 6 that could have been ironed out to make it an incredible game.

After an absurd time investment, I feel like I'm as well-qualified as anyone to judge Mindustry, and I judge it lacking. In particular, I believe it's stuck. After creating one world and never really polishing it, the tiny team creating it created a brand new game with significant differences, added on as a new world, and looked forward to the next content release.

Except the game, as it was, desperately needed polish, adjustment, and balancing that it will now probably never get. If you are one of the many people who, like me, start the game to find your cursor has vanished, you know that there are years-old game-breaking bugs that the developer just isn't interested in addressing. But the bugs are [i]very[/i] few. The code is fine -- you can look at it yourself and see. I can cope with what few bugs I've seen. My real problem is with design.

Because the original game and the new world are essentially not the same game, it's almost impossible to review them as a single title. This is, by the way, a design defect in my view. Mindustry has been around a long time, and it's one sort of game. One sort of game that needed work, but instead of doing that work, the devs took the path that pleased them better, which was to add content. This is the most common disease of small production teams in the entire world of indie gaming (if this game could be described that way, but they've grossed too much money in my opinion to merit the title "indie" at this point. Being provided sufficient time and money, by the way, removes any excuse not to polish your product. And this game has had enough of both to do better.

As I find myself saying again and again, creating shiny new content to please your fans is always going to be more fun than polishing, rebalancing, fixing, and tweaking an existing design. It's the behavior or someone working on their hobby, skipping from the fun part of one project to the fun part of the next project without creating something polished enough to present to the public at large. This isn't cosplay, it's software engineering.

I could go on, but I'm past the emotional high of a new review, so I guess that means I can now legitimately just go work on something more fun. Or maybe I'll review a different game and add it here and pretend that's the same as continuing the original one.

Absolutely fantastic game, worth the 10 dollars.  The game has seen so much progress and has more to come, I can't wait for it to receive more polish and development. Instead of making a better story line, or a more enjoyable game play, or creative puzzles to get the user thinking. The devs just make enemy units OP and nearly unbeatable. Games should be fun and challenging, not feel like I need to dedicate 8 hours a day just to beat one level.  
The unit descriptions are garbage. They don't give you information about what's required for the buildings to run. The information about each unit is a single phrase that tells you nothing. Good luck figuring out what you need per building with the small icons that tell you nothing instead of unit names. There's no way to find out either. No documentation and no guides online. You need to memorize every icon in the game in order to read what's on the screen. 
Could be a good game, but the devs are too lazy to include information that a casual player doesn't know. They expect you to know the game inside and out just to have a single play through of any level.

This game is a gem. It's an interesting mixture of factory-building strategy, and defensive strategy. You can be as greedy as you like, and try to build a big factory to grab as many resources from a planet as you want. [b]But[/b], can you then [b]defend[/b] that factory from the inhabitants who don't want you stealing their property? I'm not very far into the game at the moment, only three hours in, and I'm going to be attempting the map called "The Craters" straight after I finish this review. But the learning curve and difficulty seems to be pitched perfectly at the moment. Looking at the screenshots on the store page, it looks like things will get a lot bigger and a lot more complex later on - just how I like it. 

And I must mention the price - this game is excellent value for money. I got it for [b]less[/b] than £5UK, and I can already tell that it's going to be a good investment. 

I think I'm going to be putting a lot of hours into this, and if you like living on the knife-edge of balancing exploration with defence, if you like factory-building games and tower defence games, you should too.

UPDATE: Well, I found the usual problem with a game which is developed by a small group or single developer: Lack of QA testing and lack of balance. Shortly after completing my original review, I started finding maps where the difficulty level suddenly jumped up by a BIG amount. You start with a time limit before you get swamped by waves of strong enemies. Instead of planning strategically, the player is reduced to simply spamming defences as fast as possible in order to survive. And unless you find the EXACT defensive pattern that the developer is demanding, you will get wiped out. So you have to repeat the map. Again, and again, and again, until you learn the right pattern. So boring and frustrating.
Many people compare this game to Factorio, so I will too. At this time (Sept 2023) I have 15 hours playing Mindustry, and I have 1,477 hours playing Factorio. That gives you an accurate illustration of the relative quality of the two games. Factorio is properly QA tested and properly balanced. Mindustry isn't.

You owe it to yourself to get this game. Steam version costs money to pay for fees/etc., I believe, but it's freely available elsewhere. It's made by some madmen on GitHub and it's got a completely unreasonable amount of content for the price tag.

[b]If you enjoy factory games:[/b] it's so smooth and easy to place everything down that next time you play factorio you'll be annoyed it's so clunky. It's got elaborate infrastructure networks and plenty of room to maximise efficiency.

[b]It you like tower defense:[/b] There are towers, small ones, big ones, giant lasers, swarms of units and even some weird Evangelion stuff later on. You can douse the enemy with water (physically pushing them back with the force) while elecrifying them, or soak them in oil and light them on fire, or just set up artillery a half mile away and dare them to get through your minefield. You can build any unit you fight, including vehicles that are bigger than any buildings you can craft.

It's even got some puzzle-solving elements in how you lay out your base, particularly on Erekir. 

In short: Buy it. Support the devs. Give 'em a headpat. They've created something special and asked for practically nothing in return.

One of the few games I've bought where I felt the price was legitimately too low for how fun it was, and that was [i]before[/i] the 6.0 update dropped.

Edit: This review was originally written (at least as far as I remember) before a price increase occurred. The current asking price of $10 is still very fair, however.

This game is a lot like factorio, but focuses on defending your base from waves of enemies. 
My biggest problem with factorio was "progression paralysis" where it took lots of comittment to find ways and room to retrofit your "starter base" with newer technologies and eventually ditching it to build the "actual base for real this time" that can be scaled to the end game, assuming you know how to design it efficiently. This game solves this problem by dividing the world into isolated regions where you set up and defend your mining and material production to reach a point where you can advance to the next region. In a region you have certain amount of enemies to beat in waves and new resources you can find to research better technologies.
In the beginning you supply your turrets with copper and lead ammo, but later you unlock new materials to create for use with the turrets for higher damage output. More mechanics get introduced like new buildings, electricity, logic elements and enhancements like water cooling.
Compared to factorio, his game has a more streamlined item transportation system with belts only having a single lane, but also more types of belts like overflow gates, routers/distributors and junctions that are contained within a single element. All this makes it much easier to work in the size constraints of your spaghetti factory.
You can also pause the game and set building plans that start getting built by your player drone when you unpause. You have infinite time to plan how you will build defenses, but you still have to worry if you have enough materials gathered to build everything in time before the next wave appears.

I really wanted to like this game but the mechanics are too opaque and it is extremely punishing forcing you to redo entire levels that sometimes take hours to build up, because it is very unlikely that you will be able to predict the correct defenses until you have already lost at least once or more.

The core game design is fun and interesting but the UI is not very good, and I regularly find myself confused or with questions that have no answer. The game just feels unfair when you suddenly lose to things. The way it is designed, usually once something unexpected happens there is not a single reactive option that you can use to try and salvage it. You just lose and wasted an hour to make no progress on the campaign.
Really recommend  it if you enjoy tactics and resource gathering

developed by Anuken, this indie gem offers a refreshing take on the genre, combining strategy, creativity, and relentless action. I found Mindustry to be a truly delightful experience.

Mindustry's gameplay is a unique blend of tower defense and resource management. The objective is simple: defend your core reactor from waves of relentless enemies. However, what sets Mindustry apart is the way it intertwines resource gathering and manufacturing into the core gameplay. Players must extract, transport, and process resources to build defenses and upgrade their production chain. This adds an engaging layer of depth, strategy, and creativity that is both challenging and addictive.   

Mindustry opts for a minimalist pixel art style, which may not be everyone's cup of tea. While the visuals are functional and clear, they lack the polish and detail found in some other games. However, the game's simplicity allows it to run smoothly on a wide range of devices. The soundtrack complements the gameplay well, creating a tense atmosphere during waves and a calming ambiance during downtime.   Mindustry's learning curve is steep, especially for newcomers to the tower defense genre. The game doesn't hold your hand, and understanding its mechanics and systems requires time and patience. However, this complexity is a strength for those seeking a deep and challenging gaming experience. The sense of accomplishment when you finally master the intricacies of resource management and defense strategy is incredibly satisfying.

With a wide variety of maps, each with its unique challenges and layouts, Mindustry offers substantial replayability. The game also features a level editor and a thriving modding community, allowing players to create and share their custom content. This extends the lifespan of the game and ensures that you'll never run out of new challenges to tackle.

One of Mindustry's standout features is its passionate and supportive community. The developer, Anuken, actively engages with the player base, listens to feedback, and regularly releases updates to improve the game. The modding community has also produced an abundance of user-created content, expanding the game's possibilities further. 

Mindustry is a hidden gem for fans of tower defense and resource management games. While its pixel art style and steep learning curve might not appeal to everyone, those who invest the time to master its mechanics will be rewarded with a deeply satisfying and addictive gaming experience. With its active community and continuous support, Mindustry is a title that can keep you engaged for hours on end. It's a must-play for strategy enthusiasts looking for a fresh challenge.

The game itself isn't bad and it's very appealing if you're a big fan of games like factorio or bloons, but it befalls the same problem that both of these games have:
Firstly, it becomes repetitive quickly. Sure within the first 50-100 hours you get bombarded with new content, but a lot of that content becomes obsolete as you unlock new things. Then, once you have everything you find yourself building the same couple of defenses in every level - and the game even encourages this with the schematic option.
The second problem is that the game makes you wait forever for resources. Maybe I'm just not good at optimization, but I'll spend up to an hour just waiting for my resources to fill up so I can start the next level without getting screwed over immediately. And the worst part is - you can't even AFK! When you tab out to another app, the game automatically pauses.

So all in all I have mixed feelings about the game and I'm sure some players will love it, but it's definitely not for everybody

It could be good, but it's spoiled by a terrible saving system; an illogical conveyor belt system and technologies gated behind completing specific maps.

Cons: [b]#1.[/b] No speed settings, so there's no way to play at 2x, 4x or whatever. This is a big issue in a game where the goal is to collect resources
[b]#2.[/b] The save system is idiotic. You have ONE save slot and you can't just quit to the main menu without saving either, so you're routinely forced to overwrite your save slot even when you don't want to. Massively spoils the game.
[b]#3.[/b] The different sectors on the map are NOT connected and considering that you have literally dozens of sectors and you've built a base and factories in each of those sectors (which takes dozens of minutes PER sector), the fact that you can't even get resources from those sectors that you've already built, is stupid. It literally makes all of the previous work and progress you've done pointless, since you can't get resources from it.
[b]#4.[/b] A massive part of the game, involves defeating wave-after-wave of enemies, and since this is essentially a Tower Defense game, you'd expect an 'attack path' to be highlighted for the enemies to show which route they plan on following, just like you get in all other TDs, but this game doesn't have that, which means that you have to guess which way the enemies are going to come when you reach a new sector, and if you've guessed wrong, then you just die and have to start the sector over.
[b]#5.[/b] The game's conveyor belt system isn't logical, since it doesn't function like a conveyor belt, because it allows inputs from ALL directions, and this massively complicates production lines because now you can't have a conveyor belt that is flanked by production buildings.... you're forced to leave a space on one side of the conveyor belt. I don't know why the dev couldn't just make the conveyor belts function like conveyor belts in reality (or like it does in games like Satisfactory, which again, is based on reality).
[b]#6.[/b] Many technologies are gated by certain scenarios... and you can go where you want... so if you just keep on avoiding these specific scenarios on the map, then you will NEVER unlock specific crucial technologies in the game... so instead of having the tech tree function like a regular tech tree where you can research using points or resources, the dev instead opted to have it be gated by specific maps, which goes COMPLETELY counter to the open-world aspect that the game has.
[b]#7.[/b] The game is for sale in russia

When I first got a hold of this game, I was really expecting something more like an aesthetically pleasing Factorio where there would at least be some complexity and interest to resource gathering and maybe some interesting freedom to build to your liking. While the aesthetics are admittedly nice, this unfortunately plays straight as a Tower Defense kind of game, but is also admittedly clunky. You're often feeling at odds with the gameplay because unlike the earlier mentioned Factorio, where you usually have some time to build up a base and figure out your surroundings before you have to engage anything, every level here plays on a timer. 

When you first get in to a level, you have 3-5 minutes to not just get your bearings, but get your resource stations built up, your weaponry online, and prepare for your first waves of opponents to try and tear you apart, with the understanding that resource management is a live and constant endeavor even in between rounds. 

It doesn't punish you too badly for failure. Every round you lose, everything stays where it is, but more beat up and destroyed, so you have to spend some time and resources rebuilding it. But that unfortunately means that the time limit the game itself imposes on you is meaningless, as you won't lose everything from total failure, and also that you will immediately be replaying the same exact level multiple times and progressing a little bit further in each wave, with each wave feeling exactly the same. And since you're focusing on not just base management but also expansion, you often won't actually be where the action is ( Not that your pea shooter of a space ship is particularly competent in battle ). This also means that when an enemy actually breaks through, though, that you won't be there to see it, and that the enemy has pretty easy access to your major supply routes from there. You could spend more time buffing up exactly one area so no matter what it will always be protected, but most of the time, you do not have the luxury of having only one choke point of a defense position to maintain, so enemies will inevitably get around your one blockade and just wreck your shop from there.

All in all, this means that you're going to be quickly resigning yourself to losing multiple times, not even caring because your extra attempts are all being made in the sake of progress. it makes the limits the game imposes on you less impactful, and at the same time makes you dread each subsequent playthrough of a level as you waste precious seconds rebuilding the damaged infrastructure so you can then ignore it and go back to any actual planning you were doing. In the end, there's no room for originality, and a combination of optimization and overkill is the name of the game. 

I honestly do wish I had better things to say. I do think the game is playing as intended, and that to some extent it can be fun, I just got disappointed quickly when I realized how quickly I was already repeating myself.

Don't get the impression that this is anything like Factorio, it's an RTS/tower defense game with conveyor belts, but for what it is it's very fun. It just keeps getting better over time; unlike most developers, they're not afraid of major overhauls to improve the gameplay, and the latest major update is a big improvement over what was already a great game. Mod support extends the life of the game; though the mod making community isn't huge, there's plenty to explore. Worth it at full price, a steal at a discount.

A Transcription

By the President of the United States of America:

A Proclamation.

Whereas, on the twenty-second day of September, in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and sixty-two, a proclamation was issued by the President of the United States, containing, among other things, the following, to wit:

"That on the first day of January, in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and sixty-three, all persons held as slaves within any State or designated part of a State, the people whereof shall then be in rebellion against the United States, shall be then, thenceforward, and forever free; and the Executive Government of the United States, including the military and naval authority thereof, will recognize and maintain the freedom of such persons, and will do no act or acts to repress such persons, or any of them, in any efforts they may make for their actual freedom.

"That the Executive will, on the first day of January aforesaid, by proclamation, designate the States and parts of States, if any, in which the people thereof, respectively, shall then be in rebellion against the United States; and the fact that any State, or the people thereof, shall on that day be, in good faith, represented in the Congress of the United States by members chosen thereto at elections wherein a majority of the qualified voters of such State shall have participated, shall, in the absence of strong countervailing testimony, be deemed conclusive evidence that such State, and the people thereof, are not then in rebellion against the United States."

Now, therefore I, Abraham Lincoln, President of the United States, by virtue of the power in me vested as Commander-in-Chief, of the Army and Navy of the United States in time of actual armed rebellion against the authority and government of the United States, and as a fit and necessary war measure for suppressing said rebellion, do, on this first day of January, in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and sixty-three, and in accordance with my purpose so to do publicly proclaimed for the full period of one hundred days, from the day first above mentioned, order and designate as the States and parts of States wherein the people thereof respectively, are this day in rebellion against the United States, the following, to wit:

Arkansas, Texas, Louisiana, (except the Parishes of St. Bernard, Plaquemines, Jefferson, St. John, St. Charles, St. James Ascension, Assumption, Terrebonne, Lafourche, St. Mary, St. Martin, and Orleans, including the City of New Orleans) Mississippi, Alabama, Florida, Georgia, South Carolina, North Carolina, and Virginia, (except the forty-eight counties designated as West Virginia, and also the counties of Berkley, Accomac, Northampton, Elizabeth City, York, Princess Ann, and Norfolk, including the cities of Norfolk and Portsmouth[)], and which excepted parts, are for the present, left precisely as if this proclamation were not issued.

And by virtue of the power, and for the purpose aforesaid, I do order and declare that all persons held as slaves within said designated States, and parts of States, are, and henceforward shall be free; and that the Executive government of the United States, including the military and naval authorities thereof, will recognize and maintain the freedom of said persons.

And I hereby enjoin upon the people so declared to be free to abstain from all violence, unless in necessary self-defence; and I recommend to them that, in all cases when allowed, they labor faithfully for reasonable wages.

And I further declare and make known, that such persons of suitable condition, will be received into the armed service of the United States to garrison forts, positions, stations, and other places, and to man vessels of all sorts in said service.

And upon this act, sincerely believed to be an act of justice, warranted by the Constitution, upon military necessity, I invoke the considerate judgment of mankind, and the gracious favor of Almighty God.

In witness whereof, I have hereunto set my hand and caused the seal of the United States to be affixed.

Done at the City of Washington, this first day of January, in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and sixty three, and of the Independence of the United States of America the eighty-seventh.

Fantastic entry in the automation genre, with a much heavier RTS focus than Factorio. (If you're in the "I want to play more Factorio but don't want to start another game of Factorio" boat, definitely give Mindustry a try)

The game largely revolves around a split between logistics to gather, process, and transport materials back to your core - the starting building which causes you to lose a map if it is destroyed - and unit management. The current map's resources are used for construction, but the global totals - all cores in all maps - are used for research, which is simply a matter of spending resources to unlock stuff. Tech progression is gated by how far you are into the game, giving a nice learning curve. The game starts out simple as a pure wave-based Tower Defense game but it soon gives you the ability to make units that you can order around like an RTS, opening up the concept of attack maps where you face endless waves until you go and stomp all over the enemy base with your army. From there things progress: better units, more materials, more complex recipes, upgrades, and so on.

Mindustry also contains what is effectively its own sequel, added to the game for free, in the form of a second planet. Erekir is very much like a second game in the same engine, except it's actually part of the same game: total shift in gameplay (much heavier unit focus), completely different resources and buildings, new mechanics, rebalancing, anti-cheese measures, and overall a very different experience. It's much harder than Serpulo (the first planet) but in a good way, requiring you to be good at prioritizing, setting up construction quickly, and picking your targets and attacks carefully.

Absolutely recommended, especially at $10 which is criminally underpricing itself.

Excellent real-time strategy mainly focused on resource gathering and management and defense through towers and through increasingly powerful units. The management of one's base, resources, energy production and strategy to succeed are excellent and make it a highly recommended game (especially at the price it is sold at). 

HOWEVER, I think it would be good to focus on some "flaws" that could make it really better and in my opinion of a much higher level.

1. the movements of the units are not up to the mark: in complicated and crowded situations the units get stuck inexorably and have to be managed by intervening manually

2. I would have expected the classic controls on the units typical of RTS (said that here is very nice the possibility to command directly the single unit) that instead are lacking: attack, stay on defense, attack only if engaged, patrol a certain path, return to a point automatically (usually repair) if critically damaged etc etc (here there would be really a lot to do and it would take very little to make the game really superior). Lacks the ability to automatically deploy units on certain formations etc. It lacks the ability to tell for example certain units to follow another one to remain in its defense (example: it would have been very useful to allow you to directly command a vanquish and keep for example a locus team at a distance in its own defense) etc etc. 

3. also defense turrets side it would be nice to be able to give some more evolved commands... attack only certain enemy units (useless to dump or waste resources of powerful turrets on weak units...), attack only if the enemy enters a particular zone configurable for each turret, attack with a certain cadence a certain point in your range etc etc

That said I highly recommend this game and I really look forward to its extensions and/or improvements.

The only major complaints I have is that I wish the map editor was more polished.

Firstly the menus could be better if compressed or made more digestible. There's 2 "generate" menus and they could easily be squished into one. The only difference between the two I have found is that one allows you to apply the generation like you drew it onto the map, and the other does it when you play-test it (or publish it).

To add onto the compressed/digestible menus, the left side of the map editor, right below the 2 buttons "Center" and "Walls to cliffs" there's empty space. Some of the menus when you press "Esc" (or the button at the top left of the editor) could be moved there. For example the play-test, save map, and all 4 of the menus in "map info". It's not the best option for a new menu but it's something to start with.

I wish (at least some) modifiers are live in the map editor. The mirror modifier would be much easier to use if the changes were live in the map editor. I don't know the limitations of the engine, but it would be nice to be able to see the blocks do that blend effect live in the editor.

The blocks on the right side of the map editor are really messy and hard to find, the only thing that helps with this is the search bar above it. Making categories would help greatly in this regard- specifically separating the 2 campaigns buildings.
