Absolutely fantastic game. Modded or vanilla, it provides a great experience. Creating and optimizing solutions to problems is crucial, and each sector requires higher and higher levels of thinking. I bought this game after playing it for free (from the game's GitHub/Itch.io), simply to support the developer.

The campaign is well planned, thought out, and non-linear. You are a rogue mech, your faction has been shred apart and spread across the equator of a war-torn, spore-infested planet. On the poles lives the enemy. You must invade their bases and capture their sectors. Scavenge for resources, craft stronger items, build stronger defenses. You can strictly follow story sectors and never stray to other bases, or you can capture the entire equator before interacting with the enemy, creating mass production bases, eventually being able to launch those resources to your sectors under attack. It's an unparalleled experience I would never give up.

Engineering has a high precedence in this game. You need to build the most efficient systems you can, while still defending your base. You can make Surge Alloy, the most valuable resource, simply using scrap, found on nearly all sectors. Logic extends this tenfold by allowing you to control buildings based on conditions. For example, when a Thorium Reactor starts to heat up, you can disable it with a logic processor until there is enough cryofluid to cool it down.

Mindustry is a very easy but very extensible game to mod, due to it's versatile mod types. You can place configuration files and images in a folder and have a working factory for custom items in no time. You can then attach JS scripts for special behaviour. If you want to get more advanced and dig deep into the game, you can fully make mods with Java. Many great mods have been made that extend the limits of the game, such as BetaMindy and Project Unity.

Overall, I highly enjoy Mindustry, and I hope to complete the campaign soon.

[h1]What is Mindustry?[/h1]

Mindustry is a good mix of tower defense and Factorio-like resource automation. You can either play the two big campaigns or use the Steam Workshop to find thousands of maps to play for free. Or use the map designer to create your own maps.

In Mindustry you have to free a sector by building up your defense and surviving mob waves. As you progress, you get to unlock new units, towers and technologies from the tech-tree, using the resources you harvested. Once you’ve freed a sector, you can move on to the next, but you continue to gather resources from a freed sector, allowing you to use those to progress faster through the tech-tree and get a better starting base.

[h1]Who is Mindustry for?[/h1]

If you do enjoy casual-oriented automation games AND/OR tower defense games, Mindustry might be for you. However, if you’re looking for a Factorio clone with heavy focus on automation, planning and doing some math, Mindustry won’t scratch that itch.

[/h1]Are there annoying/negative aspects I should know about?[/h1]

I am not a big fan of the pacing and the degree of difficulty: Especially in the early missions your defense will be ‘done’ by wave 8, but you need to sit through 35 waves total. And then suddenly the last wave will have a stupid boss or units you’ve not encountered before. They will not only wreck your whole defense, but also destroy your main base. So you will have to start the mission again, this time getting special defense for the last wave. Which is annoying and frustrating.

Also, some UI-stuff could be better, I guess.

[h1]Should I buy Mindustry?[/h1]

There are currently 18 different turrets, 35+ units to control and 2 big campaigns to play through. I bought the game in a Steam Sale for 2 bucks and I don’t regret it at all. The game is also free on mobile and you can find a free version on itch.io. The Steam version however has achievements, the Steam Workshop, and easy multiplayer access. If you want to play with friends, even 10 bucks is a fair price.

[h1]What games are similar to Mindustry?[/h1]

This is a pretty good game that combines factory building, automation and tower defense.
But there are some flaws that are very obvious and makes the game very tricky to play well and makes optimizing your base extremely tedious. 

A few of the problems are how conveyor belts, splitters and bridges work when places in vicinity to each other. If you build two bridge blocks close to each other, they will bridge whether you want it or not, so you cant place a splitter between two bridges. The unwanted bridge can not be removed without shifting it to the side, which means that making compact bases is very hard compared to similar games.

Another big problem, and the reason I stopped playing after 100ish hours, is the lack of graphs and statistics. If you have a huge base and power draw seems big, there's no way of seeing what buildings draw how much power. There is no way to easily switch off a building. You could remove the power distribution, but due to how they work, you'll probably disconnect a bunch of other things that you didn't want to.

There is also nothing that stops your factories from producing things that are no longer needed. You could have a full base, a full supply line, and despite not having the ability to absorb or use any of the materials, they are simply moved into your base and anything above the storage limit gets destroyed. That means your production lines draw 100% power, even when you can't use the products.

If you treat it like an RTS with tower defense mechanics, you'll most likely enjoy it. Unfortunately, it's right now being sold as a "factory-building game with tower defense and RTS elements", and these problems make the game fall quite short of this description.

Mindustry is a genius approach of resource gathering and management with tower defense element. Don't let the graphics fool you! This game is Open-source made with small group and a huge community building mods and finding tricks and writing guides to be most efficient in the game. 

Surprisingly, this game is very addictive with giant tech tree to research, many units to create and control, vast resource gathering, procedural world map to select mission from and many other things. 

You can play this game online PVP or PVE or any other type of game anyone made but you need to play on dedicated servers.

About update 7.0:
WOW! I'm shocked with this amount of content the creator packed with this update. Update 7.0 adds a new planet with complete different buildings and units and mechanics. It can be its own separate game or be called Mindustry 2! I just started it but even at the beginning I was shock how mechanics are the same at their bone but in another shape.

TLDR: If you like RTS, resource management like Factorio, and tower defense, don't hesitate to buy this game or just play free on Itch.io

I was recommended this game by my friend and I first got it on mobile. I then bought it on pc and OMG its such a good game! It has fast paced wave-based action for all my tower defense people and then some relaxing time to build up your resources to research new items and towers. After researching everything you can or want to research, you can gather resources to move to the next sector, bringing new enemies, bosses, a new map and more! On top of this, if you want to instantly have access to the all the items without having to deal with research (with the downside of not being able to go to new areas) you can use freeplay/custom mode to do this. a

I would say that I like this game more than factorio, as it's a lot easier to digest than factorio. however, it does get kind of boring as as soon as you figure out a decent strategy to defend a base then you kind of do the same thing on ever map.

The new 7.0 campaign feels like a severe downgrade to before. The RTS control mode is a good upgrade, but everything else feels slower and more complex, for no good reason, and disallowing switching between maps makes getting into the new game mechanics much more frustrating, as you can't switch back and forth to create blueprints or look up how you solved problems before. 

The original campaign is still good, though, and provides plenty of fun.

Planet Erekir is so well crafted it reminds me of playing Starcraft II: Wings of Liberty. 
It uses simple mechanics to make a myriad of strategies possible, and the player is rewarded for considering many strategies. The satisfaction of building your own empire of efficiency and order, defeating the enemy, and becoming stronger is unmatched by other games.

Being my first game that has introduced me to others similar in the genre, Mindustry really had a pull on me as a game that became quite addicting at a low price tag.

Public Servers

I spent many afternoons/nights in the past on servers problem solving & working towards constant growth.

This however did not last long. Ever since the implementation of schematics and the easy availability of absolutely anyone experienced or not in making use of schematics from places like the internet and the steam workshop very easily. This is a blessing and a curse. Most people who end up relying on them do not understand how they work/function and this really skews that past experience of collaborating with strangers while having a sort of expectation of who you will meet and what you can learn. Now it is an endless uphill battle if your goal is complete understanding like I do.

It went from moments of everyone trying to figure out problems through the challenges of the maps to most people having everything solved and right out the gate copy pasting a massive schematic that self sustain beats the level or solves a massive challenge of the level in a matter of a few clicks.

The Experience

This indeed is a game better with others, though at this current time, only with at least one or more dedicated friends. Trying to complete later levels on your own without proper planning and/or the use of some schematics ends up being quite the slog. Though being able to expect failure for the first go at a level will enable you to succeed eventually. You can easily rebuild with the "B" binding, this makes it still enjoyable and viable but suited to the more dedicated. The base of solo players to be able to go lengths with it will be very low imo.

As a casual game, this will bring good fun and challenge for a few sessions. Though expect if you want to dive deeper into the layered additions in additive content, the complexity will ramp up linearly. It's difficult to recommend this if you do not have at least a friend, (preferably more) of friends dedicated to learning at least a bit.

Disclaimers, Warnings, Counters/Rebuttals

Progression is not shared, all tech, resources, and world progression goes to the host. This is unfortunate and a shame.

There is a tedious loop that will bore many and quickly. The engaging nature of this game only lies when you push past repetitive parts that keep appearing in the game and new challenges appear only when you drag though that which leaves most and many to be bored and put it down. The more likely reality is a friend will drag you through their progression and you will be left feeling exactly that if you don't find your own charm in the game. You will feel dragged through dirt.

RTS elements and the UI is weak. The RTS is minimal at best, I have also found that I am asked where is this building where is that item all the time. The tutorial as well does a poor job in showing where things are. Most of the game's actions are hidden behind keybinds and smooshed into the bottom right of the screen. Unobtrusive & Immersive, yes. Unintuitive & Tedious, yes.

Who should play it and why

There is a little bit for each person whether it's the RTS elements, Tower defense elements, or Base Building/Automation & Resource Management elements. Some good complexity without being overwhelming or forcing you into a crawling state for too long. (You can skip waves at your own pace, if you fail you don't restart at zero. You see all your old builds and can use, "B" to quickly rebuild everything.")

I have no hesitation to recommend the game. It's base price was $6 USD but has moved to $10 USD, no doubt still worth it.

This is a great game to just kill time or also spend some time and have fun. Basically this game is sort of like games like Clash Of Clans, and Rise Of Kingdoms, but instead of logging on real quick and waiting forever, your builds are finished quite fast, which add a rapid pace into the flow of the game. The game overall is kind of a blend of minecraft, terraria, bloons td and zombs.io. In this game you can play two modes, Campaign (My personal fav) or custom modes. I will talk about Campaign because it is what I have been playing the most. In campaign the main goal is too keep control over many other planets. The way you do that is by first gathering some materials, second setting up a defense to "take over" the planet, to "take over" the planet you must finish off all the waves that come at quite a rapid pace so you cannot hesitate to start your defense. But after you took over the planet you can increase your production, research new things and also go onto the next island or manage previous ones. This game can have up to 16 friends so would be great for your friend group, especially if you have had a minecraft/terraria phase together. I personally have enjoyed this game so much and so have my friends and would give this game a solid 9.5/10. -.5 stars because in the very beggining the tutorial isnt perfect and leaves some detail out, but other than that this game has been very good and enjoyable.

For years I searched for something that would satisfy the endless craving that I had for a "Desktop Tower Defense" type game. This game filled that role and then took it to the next level. This is an amazing little game. It's very simple and intuitive. It's basically a mix of factorio, tower defense, and an RTS. If you like factorio or other factory building games, you will most likely like this.

It's a great game with a fun style. I'm hooked! I have two main quibbles:
1. Sometimes when the game says "research" it means "get this item into your inventory", not "click in the tech tree"
2. There are too many tiles which are just a > with tiny variations.

If you like tower defense games or games like Factorio/Satisfactory then this game is right up your alley. 

It has a bit of a learning curve, but the first few levels do a very good job of teaching you mechanics.

Once you get into the late game, it really starts to shine - it really does a good job of scaling beautifully and letting you approach a map through your own style. The maps are highly varied, and the developer just added a whole new campaign that I haven't even touched.

I really love that it is a beautiful melding of tower defense / resource management / RTS. The devs really did a great job of getting all three to fit together beautifully. Even at full price, I think it's an absolute steal for the amount of time I've spent playing the game.

This is an interesting mix between Factorio and a real-time strategy game.  It's made a single choice I intensely dislike and has some rough-around-the-edges programming, but the core gameplay is really good so it mostly makes up for it.

As far as logistics games go, Factorio is king.  It's a perfect blend between logistics progression and the tower defense mechanics needed to defend your base.  Way over on the other side of the spectrum, you have Satisfactory -- this is all logistics and building based, with almost zero threat.  There's also some fun exploration elements mixed in.  

Mindustry is kind of like taking Factorio in the opposite direction of Satisfactory.  What is Factorio was ALL combat and tower defense?  That's essentially what you have here, and it's done really well.

You will slowly take over zones, each a different map, by landing there, gathering resources, building towers to defend the waves, and the moving on.  Some zones have more or less supplies, or could be missing a key resource compeltely, changing how you have to defend.  They will also have harder or weaker defenses depending on how many enemy bases are nearby, but this is basically what you get -- repeat that clear-a-zone process for an entire planet and you got yourself a game.  

This is mixed up a bit by enemy bases, which are done in a really cool way -- they are functional factories exactly as you would build them that you have to invade.  This is the most interesting part of the game in my opinion.  You get these RTS-style units to take them down, which feel a little clunky at first but eventually I got the hang of them.  The factories are really interesting to approach, because they'll have a mix of air and ground weaponry and you have to use the right troops in the right way to get through.  An example would be that you might dive in and bomb the turrets, but you'll lose a lot of troops that was, so sometimes you can snipe out a single unguarded conveyor belt that is feeding those towers with ammo instead.   Then you can do strategic drive-bys to waste the ammo in the turrets and disable them that way.  Since so many turrets rely on an ammo input, water tube or electrical pole, there are a lot of ways to approach the factory assault levels and I find them really fun to attempt.

There's a bit of a grind to this gameplay though -- you're gonna want to be the kind of person that sees 100 pretty-similar maps and wants to clear them all to get the most out of this game.  I believe you can kinda streamline this and only target maps with enemy bases, but I haven't tried that.  The benefit of taking the whole map is you can start shipping out the resources to your newer factories, so it gives them some value to clear beyond just completionism.  I find the easier maps fun to do while watching a movie or doing something else to distact me, and I usually take on the harder maps for a more concentrated experience.

Now, for the bad.  One glaring issue is that this game is un-minimizable.  Why?  I'm very used to not being able to minimize my games, but that's usually becasue I play oldschool broken games that need Windows XP compatibility mode to even launch.  If I'm trying to run something from 2004 and it crashes when I minimize it, I blame myself for not having a computer from 2004.  Mindustry is a modern game with no excuses and seemingly no plans on fixing it, so if you're playing this game, prepare to have your computer held hostage until you're done with it.

The choice they made that I absolutely hate is the decision to erase all your plans when you die.  Oh my God, what a terrible design decision.  This almost ruins the game for me.

This game, in single-player at least, is very much a game of "pause at the start and plan all your buildings out in schematics for 30 minutes".  People that have started a bunch of new RimWorld colonies know the experience -- you barely start playing that game until an hour after going into creating a new world because of all the setup a new map requires to approach it properly.  This is similar -- you can plan out everything, and doing so is often very advantageous because you won't screw yourself on space or resources if you plan ahead for it.  I can't tell you how many times I forgot about one of the various coal byproducts and had to jam it somewhere stupid afterwards before I realized you can pause and plan it all out at the start.

The issue here is you can die and if you do, the game erases all of your plans.  Again, WHY?  What a terrible punishment.  You don't lose any resources, you don't lose any limited lives, you just lose all your planning work for NO REASON other than to be punished for dying I guess?  You might say, well don't die then, but it's not really about that in this game.  There is zero punishment to dying besides having your plans cleared and it's easy to do by accident.  This is a game where just looking around the map at the enemy's base can get you sniped out, or you can get randomly gibbed by passing enemies while you're in a menu looking for something.. the fact you don't typically fight directly in this game means you don't really consider your life very valuable.  In fact, the game doesn't either -- as I said, there's no punishment except losing all the time you spent planning, which is not even a mechanical downside, because you can just pause and plan it all again.  It's literally the game telling you your time is worthless to them and they don't respect you and basically nothing else.  This is doubly frustrating when there's a keybind to suicide your ship that will also kill all these plans.  WHY???

I've quit playing multiple times for weeks because some big base I planned for an hour got erased for no reason by a developer that doesn't understand how to add a compelling downside to dying and instead went for the most frustrating dumb solution they could instantly think of, and that reason alone (and partially the lack of ability to minimize a modern game) is why I don't recommend the product.  The rest of it is solid though, so if you think you can get past those downsides, you'll probably enjoy it.

It's a tower defense game at its core.  But you extract, process, and refine resources from the terrain to build up your defenses, like it's a factory game.  The main planet has over 200 sectors.  In each sector, you must fight off varying numbers of waves to capture it.  Captured sectors remain safe until the enemy decides to attack again at some point if there's a nearby enemy base sector.  All sectors produce their resources simultaneously; nothing gets paused if you visit another sector.  Use your total accumulated resources to unlock new technology such as conveyor belts, turrets, walls, mining drills, combat/utility drones, cores (the building you must protect), and more.  The gameplay progression is quite long.  You start out small, having weak tech, but after many hours you may finally acquire more advanced things that are incredibly powerful.  Each turret, enemy, and combat/utility drone is of a certain tier.  I think there are six tiers in total?  I haven't gotten that far yet.  To conquer all available sectors, you'd have to spend hundreds of hours fighting off hordes of difficult enemies.  Some sectors are enemy bases, where you're the one attacking them, so you send in heavily armed drones to do the damage.  Also, there's PROGRAMMING LOGIC!  You can do so much with the very few tools you're given to program things.  There's actually almost no limit to what you can do.  It's incredibly versatile.  There's a lot more to this game than you may initially think, as it is definitely based around a tower defense game, but it has quite a few unique things about it to distinguish it from that genre.  It's a well-designed game, and it's really fun!

Mindustry is what you get when you put a tower defense game, tug of war game, Factorio, and some cool own ideas into the blender. There is also workshop support and blueprint export and the campaign can be played cooperatively. It doesn't have the depth and complexity of a Factorio but it has more explosions to compensate. The way this game plays/handles makes it feel like a triple A title. An incredibly shallow learning curve, however good luck mastering it. The combination of fueling your turrets to protect your production and having an efficient production set up is key and incredibly addicting to try and maintain. You can't just overproduce a certain item like electricity or copper and spam defenses as you will run out of either space/materials, so being efficient and having a dynamic defense system that uses several materials is key. Different combinations of blocks can always help you out of a clog so try things in downtime or do a custom map by yourself and practice. 

PS: Use B and drag over destroyed items to rebuild them so you don't have to manually replace them. Thank god this feature exists.

The combination of a Factory Simulator, Real Time Strategy Game, and Tower Defence game is such an ingenious idea, and the mixture of genres just works so well!

I find it fun to construct machines to gather materials and watch the conveyors move items to machines for processing, and the need to defend your base against threats keeps you in the game on what can be an otherwise slow experience once you get a factory set up, in other words: A perfect balance.

Some might say that its just too complex, but once you play the game, it feels more simple once you get a closer look at it... if you are good at organising, unlike me...

My only complaint is that the pace shoots down through the floor after completely capturing a sector, but its just a small problem that I can shrug off.

Looking for a game that lets you flex your programming skills while building your industrial empire? Look no further than Mindustry! If you're a fan of Factorio or Satisfactory-type games, you're going to love this one.

What sets Mindustry apart is its powerful scripting system. With this system, you can program your factories to operate with maximum efficiency and deal with enemy attacks. It's incredibly satisfying to see your automated system work flawlessly, and it's even more satisfying to know that you're the one who wrote the code behind it.

And it's not just the programming that makes Mindustry addictive. The game has a perfect balance of challenging gameplay and rewarding mechanics. You'll need to think strategically to defend your base against waves of enemy attacks while managing your resources and production lines.

The game also has an active and passionate community that has created some incredible custom maps and scenarios. But what really stands out is the level of detail that players have put into their scripts. From simple conveyor belt optimizations to complex enemy AI routines, the community has pushed the limits of what's possible in the game.

The developers of Mindustry have been consistently pushing out updates and new content, making it clear that they're committed to creating the best game possible. The game is well-polished and stable, with a user-friendly interface that makes it easy to get started.

In summary, if you're a fan of programming and industrial automation, Mindustry is the game for you. It strikes the perfect balance of challenging gameplay and rewarding mechanics, all while giving you the freedom to program your factories to perfection. Don't miss out on this hidden gem!

Mindustry is a great experience that's almost a worthy upgrade from Factorio. It's definitely got more of a charm than Factorio did in my opinion - a combination of the graphics style and the gameplay. I had a ton of fun playing through the new campaign, and beating the final enemy base with a friend was a great experience. The campaign that was recently released - version 7.0 - added an entire planet with a new system of enemies, blocks, items, weapons etc. - it's really well balanced, easy to get in to, and provides a good challenge from start to finish.

However - that's the new campaign. The game has two, the first of which being brutally difficult to the point of being borderline impossible. You begin with a small and modest tech tree, slowly exploring the concept of production and weapons and eventually power. Those three concepts power the base of Mindustry - get things into the core, build units and weapons to defend it. On a per-level basis - this is fine. Beating the final waves of enemies is fun, and capturing a sector is challenging but good. The problems begin with the 'invasion' mechanic. Essentially, you capture a main area of the game, and suddenly every hexagon space around it shows up in red. This means you need to go to every one of them and capture the sector there. So you launch, set up a base, and begin working. These areas are randomly generated too, so it's completely up to random luck if you get a decent base with good working conditions, or are almost immediately screwed over.

As you're playing, you'll get to a certain point and suddenly you get an alert at the top - 'sector lost'. Confused, you check the map, and the area you were just playing in has at some point been 'invaded' - the core will have blown up, everything around will be destroyed, and you won't now have the materials to rebuild. And the waves will be coming in every minute, then every half minute, and then eventually every 20 seconds. Sending larger and larger units, until eventually they're sending in enormous ships which just bomb the entire base and you can't do anything about it. You could build huge unit production facilities to build ships that are just as big - however once a sector is lost, you spend more time rebuilding it and getting it back up online than you do expanding it, so it just becomes a game of diminishing returns. Once you spend hours and hours building a base, just to have it randomly get blown up by enemy units faaaar above where you're currently at, you quickly lose interest in the game.

There is a 'pause' feature in the game which allows you to stop everything and fly around planning stuff, but you can only build when the game is unpaused. This is fine to plan things but it almost proves a point about the (unfortunate) way you're hinted to play the game - spend more time panic planning to have a slim chance of winning instead of just playing it in real time and having a reasonable amount of time to plan and defend your base. Even with two players pausing for 10-15 minutes at a time and building up insanely armored, back-to-back-gun defended areas of the base, by wave 90 they're sending in so many huge mechs and ships that you have absolutely no chance.

I want to believe that the new campaign was created and balanced with what I've mentioned in mind from day one. If that's the case - perfect. I'll still recommend this game even despite what I've said, but if you're wanting a laid-back fun base building game, this isn't it. You will be enraged to see 5 hours of your time get nuked by a huge green ship you haven't even unlocked yet. If you want a challenge, play the new campaign. It kinda breaks my heart to say this as I had tons of fun playing through the game with a friend, and over the weeks of playing the old campaign it turned from a 'let's play Mindustry' to just a 'let's see if we can get any further on that level' - to then just watch everything get blown up and give up and play something else. I'm always up for a challenge in these games, but parts of this game are borderline impossible.

If future updates are going to be like the new campaign, I'm all up for it.

Claims it is multiplayer, but it does not have a co-op campaign tech tree, and only the host can do research. Since research is tied to your personal profile, co-op is only viable if the guest has already played the game all the way through to the end.

Dev appears to take the position that having shared tech tree progression separate from your profile is not happening, and sharing tech tree progression in co-op would therefore be an exploit against your personal profile. (e.g., if you join a host who has everything, it would auto unlock everything for you, since campaign tech tree is not and will not be separated from profile tech tree.)

The factory building is simple, like a slightly easier version of factorio, with more focus on tower defense. You do need to build a *lot* of factories if you're planning on actually beating the game on Surpelo, due to requiring a high amount of high tier resources to beat the last few sectors in the campaign. Erekir's campaign is more difficult and works more like individual missions instead of the 4X style Surpelo has, though it does feel a bit weird having a research tree on that planet when you cant transfer resources between sectors and thus progress in previous ones has no impact on the game beyond the research tree.

Additional notes; The game seems to be heading more towards 3 separate experimental-esque campaigns than one long campaign, Serpulo being somewhat 4x and Erekir being more RTS focused.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

EDIT 7/20/2022:  The next major update has been put into Alpha and at first glance makes HUGE changes that directly address my concerns about unit control. EDIT: 1/27/2023: Consider this a negative review of the second planet.  To keep it short, the new game mechanics are largely just a nuisance that offer nothing new, and the missions are EXTREMELY strategy forced and filled with trial and error. You will constantly have intel hidden away from you resulting in you getting killed by things you couldn't have known about and prepare for.

I feel like I burned myself out with how much I played for the sake of achievements, but at $6 I would feel stupid not recommending this.  Campaign is a chill grind, online runs nice, good chunk of modded content to try out, can use custom wave survival for some sandbox replay value.  Base construction is simpler/more approachable than something like Factorio. Definitely got my moneys worth.

My main complaints:
-Many PvP servers allow schematics to be used, which personally makes it feel like the base layout aspect of the game is pointless.  Having commonly downloaded, highly efficient and compact schematics makes me feel like I would rather just play a regular RTS game.  
-Wish there was an easier way to copy snippets of code.  You can save code as part of a schematic or import from a text file, but I would like to import/save reusable snippets in game so I could quickly apply the same logic in different use cases.  Mostly because>
-Mobile unit control is so stupid and basic.  I know its not the focus of the game, but there should really be more default command options. In RTS terms, your options are attack move with the most direct path to the enemy core, regroup to the closest command center, and remain idle.  These options apply to ALL UNITS ACROSS THE MAP.  You HAVE to have program scripts ready if you want any meaningful control over your units without taking direct control.

I admit, I quite adore this game. Simple on the surface gameplay which then opens up to a rather complex material management and overall logistics game, alongside building up a presence in each level to either fend off the opposition or crush any enemy bases, there is also having to tinker with various ways to work with the surrounding resources and even a unique way to command units, print out images and do other stuff with a unique coding system in one of the planets.

There is also modding to either change up textures and audio, or add full-on massive additions to spice up the fun of the game. Alongside it, the ways to play co-op like the campaign can be loads of fun and are a pretty nice test of cooperation with other players, especially friends.

To anyone and I mean ANYONE coming from Factorio that wants to try out something a bit different, or if you want a quite interesting combination of base building, rts-like combat, and tower defense, I highly recommend picking up this game.

I have roughly 100 hours with the free version offered on the devs website. I'd strongly recommend trying that to see if you like it and if you do then buy the steam version for the full online experience. overall this has been my go to, perfect game. It's very complicated, while being open enough to anyone patient enough to be far more accessible than a game like factorio. The tower defense mixed with the factory building mechanics coupled with the mid game ability to start sending resources from one map to another, allows you to create some truly wacky and "unnecessary" defense builds. Capturing a map and turning into another production line to feed into my war machine is always satisfying and sending my massive pool of resources to an enemy base to take it over with a hoard of my own drones, tanks, giga space ships, and mechs is just fun, seeing all the chaos of the "final take" unfold as you watch your armies collide. The pvp is fun and methodical and is a more simpler RTS experience than something like starcraft 2. The mod support naively and through the workshop is amazing, adding hundreds of hours of new content to the game, and the community servers are  very welcoming and I've been having a fun time learning pvp strats on them. Overall if your looking for something where like factorio but with a higher focus on combat, then this is def your game, and for the price of free on their website, and only being 200mb, there really is no downside to trying the campaign to see if it's something you like.

This game absolutely shines in multiplayer. I also played quite a bit of Factorio multiplayer, and I prefer Mindustry. While Factorio is definitely the better factory building game, Mindustry is more based on relatively short maps that you have to solve in a variety of ways, which lends itself well for multiplayer sessions. having more of a tower defense focus added on top of building a good factory also helps for multiplayer enjoyment.

The developer also supports the game well, and you can find the source-code of the game on Github! (and for open-source aficionado's, downloadable from F-Droid for your phone).

While I didn't enjoy Mindustry, it seems like a strong game. The intricate interweaving of the conveyor belts is enjoyable, and the complex mining and refining process of different materials is ingenious. But I found the tower defense element too frustrating, because I had to restart a number of times when my base was destroyed. I think Factorio might be a better match for me, because as I understand it, there is no, or limited, combat.

Before the v7 release, I would have said that Mindustry as a factory benefiting from and being brought down by its own maximalism. It has everything from tower defense, RTS units, a campaign map, multiplayer, and a brilliant/elegant machine/conveyor interface system that avoids the usual cludge of inserters or input/output slots. But the visual design was clumsy (a lot of grey squares with slightly different grey pixel art) and the campaign map, while a fine sandbox for the tools provided, quickly becomes unbalanced and unable to provide interesting challenges.

All of these criticisms were fixed with the release of Erekir in v7, down to the blocks having much more distinct design involving bold colors and readable silhouettes. Towers are bigger, more expensive, and more specialized (with less overlap) and units all have distinct niches due to their movement and attack abilities in addition to being more interesting to construct. The maps themselves take advantage of this more impactful design and are more like a professionally designed RTS campaign, complete with fully formed enemy bases that have their own (100% functional) factories and chokepoints.

If I have remaining criticisms it's that the build speed is too slow (waiting around for endgame structures to build might be balanced but it isn't fun) and that the line of sight on units is too low as many of them have attack ranges that are significantly longer leading to fights that you can't actually see.

The game's mining, building, production, etc. systems are great.

The game's first planet, before version 7.0, has better levels. There's enough things to do on a map for a group in multiplayer. The first planet has terrible unit control and objectives. It plays more like a speed-run puzzle game, as there are only specific ways to win and you are constantly against the clock with waves that get harder and harder.

The game's second planet, version 7.0, has, in my opinion, better mining, building, production, and unit control. The only flaw of the second planet, is that a new objective system was created that gates off the map until the previous objective is completed and you have no idea what the next objective will be. One map the game just tells you that your main base is going to be nuked in 5 minutes or so. If you have no resources, then you will likely lose and will have to play the whole map over again now knowing the nuke will happen and can prepare for it, which is just a waste of time... This is compounded with the fact that the maps are void of resources. It seems to be overly balanced for single player and to be intentionally limiting. There is just nothing for other players to do.

Overall, I enjoy building in the game and the combat of the second planet is fun, but the first planet's end game is atrocious and the second planet's resource-scarce, multiplayer-unfriendly and punishing secret objective-based maps are not fun.

Campaign is just bad. (Buggy, Frustrating)

It can take hours to build bases in this game. Especially the further you get in the tech tree.

Instead of introducing new mechanics. The campaign throws some new unit at you that you've never seen before without warning that just walks in the back of your base, bypasses all your defenses, and kills your core. Forcing you to restart the level, 1-2 hours of progress. 

There are no save points you have to learn the hard way making you repeat hours and hours of game play.

The AI will bug out and stop sending attack waves. Which seems fine, until you realize these attack waves have still been spawning infinitely. So next time you attack the enemy base you'll be met with an army 20x the size of yours and it will crush any defense you've made and kill you. Restart.

They'll throw in random mechanics like, after spending 2 hours on a map, they'll just nuke your entire base. All gone, forcing you to start from scratch 2 hours into building, then 30 mins later throw new units at you that are three times as strong as the units you can make. (Again without any hint it's coming.) That, again, just fly over/past/around all defenses you have and kill your core before you can make any pivot to stop them. Restart.

If you could introduce new mechanics without resetting hours of progress EVERY TIME, that'd be great.

The game seems very simple and very easy, something a child might like, but then the complexity builds and before I realized, I was hooked. This is a truly addictive gave with hours of game play and well worth the fee.

 1. Mine for Cu and make copper cannonballs to shoot from copper cannons and I deliver said ammo to the cannons using copper conveyor belts. Watch enemy tanks explode.
 2. Mine for Pb and build antiaircraft guns that shoot lead bullets and I use the copper conveyor belts to feed ammo to the guns. Watch enemy aircraft explode.
 3. Mine for Coal, burn some in a combustion reactor to make electricity, compress some into graphite.
 4, Mine for Sand, make some Glass in the Kiln, make some Silicon in the furnace.
 5. Drill for water or use a water pump from a nearby stream. Water is used for cooling, putting out fires, hosing down enemy droids before you spark them with electric jolts. Watch enemy droids sizzle.
 6. Build a steam engine, a pneumatic drill for Ti, droids of all types, and a plethora of other items.
 7. Mine for Ti, Titanium is used for high-speed conveyors and other high tech components.
 8. Build massive steam-powered factories to mass-produce graphite, silicon, glass, droids, aircraft, tanks.
 9. Mine for Scrap, use as ammo in antiaircraft or meltdown into molten slag, store in tanks, use to spray molten metal on enemy droids, and send to an extractor for Cu, Pd, Ti. Watch enemy droids melt down.
 10. Mine for Th, Thorium is used in high tech aircraft and highly advanced technology.
 11. Mix Ti and H₂O to make CryoFluid, fill the CryoFluid tank. 
 12. Mix Th and CryoFluid in Thorium reactor to make large amounts of electricity.

At this point, the enemy boss shows up, blows up the power line that powers the water pump that fills the tank that feeds the CryoFluid factory, the CryoFluid tank goes empty, the Thorium Reactor continues to make vast amounts of electricity but with no cooling, it overheats, the core has a meltdown, my base explodes.

I need a fault-tolerant electrical distribution grid that maintains power for critical systems, we have a diode for that. I also need the reactor to be far away from my base. Back to the schematics for another try.

This game is extremely addictive.
[hr][/hr]
[h2]Update after almost 2000 hours of play and release of v7.0[/h2]

There is only one way to play this game, the [b]ISO 9000[/b] way.

ISO 9000 is an international quality assurance standard which can be summarized with a quote from Horton from the book, [i]Horton Has an Egg[/i]. “I said what I will do and I will do as I say.”

So my suggestion is to use a notebook and regularly pause the game to evaluate, and record progress made, long-term and short-term goals, prioritize and schedule.

It is in the nature of the game that you must be able to multitask, but multitasking can also distract you from high-priority goals. Making a list helps you keep the most important things as the most important things.

When you first land on a planet, you are briefed on what to expect and how to proceed. But until you land, you do not know for certain what has to begin. Until you explore, you do not know the map, and until you engage the enemy, you do not know what to expect.

After you have landed, you know what you will be starting with and what facilities you have. Once you have explored, you know where the minerals are located, and once your base has been destroyed you know how they are going to attack.

You may go back to a previous base to do research before your return but when you return, you know what to expect. You have a plan, and you may even have the schematics as well.

This game is a good combination of Factorio and Tower Defence genres. There are still many aspects which could use more polish, such as keyboard shortcuts and easier to recognize graphics for the items.

I finished the Erekir campaign and it wasn't trivial. Some maps, I was even defeated after a few hours and had to repeat two or three times. The balancing and difficulty could be better tuned, but it was still fun enough that even a loss isn't so bad.

This game won't be on my high rotation list for long, but it is certainly worth playing.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

One of the best RTS/tower-defense/sandbox games I've ever played. I purchased it on Steam as some kind of support to this game after v7 released (Google Play version is free and the project is open-sourced on Github, where java executable could also be downloaded). Steam version adds achievement system and steam-based multiplayer functions (which is more convenient).

SERPULO is a place where u need to build some cleverly designed factories to maximize production & transportation capacity in order to defense and build units to attack on a new sector (also late-game research could also cost a lot of high-tier materials [spoiler]and SILICON[/spoiler]). Blueprints are kinda necessary for most endgame players. 

EREKIR in v7 update, however, is a different place with a different tech tree and different mechanisms. It offers a more balanced PvE rts experience that relies less on production rate since resources are much more limited and enemy bases are better designed in most sectors, which means u should also care about structural layout & overall strategy of development. It's also less of a pain to research new items on Erekir.

Original review:

I have been playing Mindustry on Itch.io for over a year before the Steam release. It was quiet and fun and the community was very friendly. 

The single player campaign is fun but easy and can be completed in a matter of hours.

The Steam release ruined the game with Steams abhorrently toxic community. Multiplayer is now a toxic haven for griefers and people abusing kick votes.

The Steam release ruined multiplayer as it usually does for most games.

Just bought it at 1.0 to support Anuke, the Dev that made this, because, let's be honest, the man's a 1 man army, a hero, and 100% deserves it.

I can't believe how much Mindustry has evolved over the years, amazing! it's inspiring to say the least!

And if you like games like Factorio, Satisfactory, and the like, but you want a new refreshing experience, and also a x10 times better or even just the fact that it's designed with Factory PvP in mind, Blows our minds AWAY

An excellent game that's been getting continuous updates. I recommend it for people who like logistics-focused base building games, as the gameplay largely centers around gathering resources on the map and developing grids of conveyors, pipes, etc. to bring them back to your base or deliver them to structures that can produce more complex materials, ammunition, and fuel. These materials are then used to build your base and armies to defend against waves of enemies.

The recent update offers a different take on the gameplay basics with a second world to explore/conquer, offering a greater variety of game experience. While I've only just started with this second world, one thing I like over the first is the ability to control the units you construct more directly. Other changes include the way in which resources are mined, requiring different approaches to your layout.

One downside is that after you unlock a number of the structures and units via the Research screen, the maps can feel a little same-y. There's little in the way of terrain obstacle variety, apart from different map choke points and bodies of liquid. This can become tedious if you're trying to win all of the sectors on the planets. However, you don't have to start completely from scratch each time, as you are able to send resources from your other sectors to kick-start your new base's industry, or to bring in resources that are completely absent in the new map.

Overall, it's a fun game that's easier to get into than screenshots make it look. It's a good game for playing in sessions, then putting down for a bit and coming back later.

Mindustry is one of those games that can feel extremely grind-y in the campaign solo, but super fun and entertaining on a custom map with friends. 

I think Mindustry shines when it's played with others. But regardless, there is still an extremely fun solo mode in the campaign. 

Something I enjoy a lot about Mindustry is that the game seamlessly applies its simple rules in factory building, rules which when stacked against each other can produce complex, efficient and compact factories.

I think everyone should give this game at least an hour of play, at least once. You might find out that the game is rather charming.
A surprisingly great and deep game

I wasn't expecting much at first, but this is a great game. Zachtronics/Factorio meets tower defense and assault.

You can have friends or strangers join your campaign at any time you choose to. There is also some PvP, though I haven't tried it yet.

The game keeps getting bigger and better with every update, it has been updated for years now, and it is still one of my favourite games.

I also like that it is open source, and available on other platforms. I first discovered it on Android (via F-droid).

Keep it up, and keep it open :D

An extremely fun blend of the real time strategy, tower defense, factory, and even puzzle genres, this game will take months out of your life and years out of your lifespan if you play multiplayer. Current campaign (V7) is excellent and extremely fun in its own right, but serves more as a tutorial for multiplayer, where the real meat of the game is. The community is tight-knit but easy to integrate with if you have enough time on your hands, and the modding scene is excellent. The game does have some unwritten rules (NO ROUTER CHAINING), and players seeking to start designing schematics may find little community support, but there are players who will help you learn the ropes. If you want, you can even DM me and I'll try to teach you. Overall, I would recommend this game to anyone looking for a fun, cerebral time with an incredible game that has practically defined a genre of its own.

all in all, this is a great game and if you like both tower defense and factory management games, then this is a game for you.

After playing it for nearly 50 hours in just over a week I gotta say it's worth it. Bought it sale too.

It's a base building game with unlimited resources but you can only harvest as fast as your harvest building is. So there is a balance.
Yes you will get faster belts and it will make a difference. After that it takes a bit too long to get new belts. Had to install a mod for it.

For the combat part. Turrets are everything. The Salvo turret will most likely be your go to turret for most maps in the start. It's powerful, uses Copper and has decent range. The ground laser turret is also neat. High damage.
You get stronger turrets later on and you can start using them.

Now for the Guardian enemy that shows up. There is no such thing as "Too little Defense". Can you fit more turrets into your choke point? Put more turrets there. That Guardian on later levels will eat up your bullets as if you are throwing pebbles at it.
Ridiculously high amount of HP on them.

It's worth going into the Workshop to get Compact blueprints for various materials.

As a software engineer I find this game frustrating and satisfying in all the right ways. Failure is always your fault, because there are so many ways to approach any given situation. You will learn design patterns, best practices, and other heuristics as you fail iteratively, but one of the great features of the game is the ability to quickly rebuild broken structures. This means you can spend more time engineering, and less time repeating yourself. If you are that guy on Minecraft who just builds weird redstone contraptions and tries to make a computer or automated defenses, you might love this game. This game will never force you to do something manually that could be automated. Even to the point of copy-pasting structures of arbitrary complexity, this game empowers you to focus on higher levels of abstraction, and therefore actually learn principles beyond the mechanics of the game.

I feel bad giving Mindustry the thumbs down. I don't really regret the time I spent playing it and it was certainly very reasonably priced, but it is disappointing in a number of crucial ways that have caused me to lose interest in it long before I have unlocked all of the game's "content".

The biggest problem is that Mindustry seems to have quite a lot of contempt toward how valuable your time is. When you unlock a new tier of technologies the game [i]could[/i] simply give them all to you right away. Instead, it asks that you accrue enormous quantities of resources with which to buy them. And so you wait, and wait, and wait... eventually letting your factories run afk for significant periods of time accumulating the resources required. It doesn't change anything about how the game plays at all, it just adds enormously unnecessary dead time to the experience.

The "campaign" too, such as it is, comes packed with dreary and needless repetition whether you're just starting out or entering the endgame. Factorio for example asks you to slowly expand across a single contiguous game space, slowly unlocking new technologies and resources as you push deeper into an increasingly hostile world. This progression perfectly matches the cadence of the gameplay wherein new challenges come in lockstep with new capabilities. By contrast, Mindustry asks you to defeat a small play area so that you can... do that again under very similar circumstances somewhere else. There's some connectivity allowed between sectors, but this system seems like a clumsy fit for the moment to moment mechanics of the game.

None of this is helped by the extremely simplistic wave defence that forms the core gameplay loop. There's no indication of what units are about to attack and no indication whether it will be a ground or air attack, which is initially annoying until you realise it's utterly irrelevant. Rather than assaulting you in a pitched battle that attempts to penetrate your fortifications, the most threatening enemies appear to be the ones that can simply walk or fly over your defences and keep heading for the core regardless of where you have placed walls. The net result is that you end up arraying such enormous firepower against them that every single hostile unit is vapourised seconds after setting foot on the map. It's tremendously anticlimactic. If you were genuinely able to wall out your attackers they could be made much tougher, more numerous or both and result in longer, more exciting and more interesting engagements. In my play time a battle amounted to little more than a handful of hostile units spawning, being immediately bathed in the incandescent glow of a hundred laser cannons and vanishing almost immediately.

Mindustry is not a bad game and plenty of people will be (and clearly have been) able to overlook the issues I have with it, but I cannot give a "neutral" or "your mileage may vary" score, so here we are. There's a very solid foundation of attractively stylised and pleasingly complex factory construction contained within, but a lot of the stuff hanging off that core doesn't do it justice or seems actively detrimental to player enjoyment.

This game is essentially Starcraft mixed with Factorio. It's the conveyor-belt hell grind mixed with building units to attack enemy bases. While surviving waves of enemies as a constant threat to your base, you have to manage resources and design efficient systems in order to survive. 

The complexity is just at the right level where it never feels like too much. I think the developer tried to make it more combat focused, where you need actual strategy in order to destroy enemy bases. There is a research tree where you unlock everything in a manner where you're slowly introduced to new mechanics each level. Different units are used for different purposes which allow you to traverse the terrain and infiltrate enemy bases in different ways. Oh, they have a super strong turret right in the front of their base? Just bait the turret with weaker units while sending your strong ones to flank.

Progression has a great pace. Combat is fun, involved, and requires planning/strategy. Resource management and building/designing farms and mines are simple, yet intricate. Multiplayer works amazing and is insanely fun, albeit much easier.

The developer just came out with a huge update that introduces a new planet and a completely new gameplay feel. This update is what makes this game so amazing and is what I'm basing this review off of. The older planet from the previous version of the game, is much different and not as fun IMO. So, everything in this review is strictly about the new update/planet.

Overall an amazing game worth at least $20. If you are a fan of Factorio-esque games and like the thrill of strategy RTS combat, then this game is perfect for you.

Essentially, a simplified Factorio with a twist.

You research stuff, based on materials you collect and supply to your core. This unlocks new stuff and materials to work with and you expand the production in order to get new materials and research. All while you have to defend your base from waves of attackers, creating chokepoints and defending your core. No need to design your bases/production layouts but you need to design defensive chokepoints, if you want them to hold enemy at bay.

Coming from a Factorio player, who enjoys complexity and the logistical challenge puzzle of building and organizing a huge factory, this gets really boring, really quick. I bought it from sale for 5 euros and it's worth it. I might play this on and off, but there is no "Get sucked into this game" kind of thing, like the Factorio has, at least for me.

If you think Factorio is too complex, demanding, or it feels like work, you might like this. It has simpler gameplay of the stuff, that makes Factorio great.

When looking at the screenshots I wasn't very optimistic about the game, but after watching some gameplay videos it really got me interested and after playing it.. it's, in a good way, much different than my initial idea. It's NOT a Factorio clone at all. This game is a mix of real-time strategy with factory building, and it does it so well. Unlike Factorio and similar games, that are an open world, here you have the world map and you select a small sector to play on. Each sector has specific objectives, so you are not doing the same thing over and over and factory efficiency is only important if it helps you to fulfil the sector's objective. It's a super clever twist on this genre.

I've played Factorio for ~170 hours, Satisfactory for ~130 hours and Mindustry for 160 hours. I have finished neither game, though, but what can I say: Just play Mindustry. For me, it's much better than the former two, although maybe this depends on what you're trying to achieve.

In Factorio, you just have one huge map, and all you do for the most time is expand the production. You never have enough resources, and you always have to find new ore deposits, protect them, transport them and later use in production. Rinse and repeat. The optimal strategy for Factorio is just to build a straight line. Enemies? Just annihilate them. Cliffs? Explode them. Lakes? Landfill them. Space is almost unlimited, and the only problem for you is another building that you made. The optimal strategy in Factorio is simply to use a bus -- i.e. many conveyors in the straight line near to each other, so that every conveyor carries specific -- and just build all the production around it, getting resources from the bus and returning the result to the bus. When bus is not enough, you make city blocks, etc. Coming up with new design is always interesting, but at some point it becomes a game of Copy-Paste.

In Satisfactory, you just follow the research tree for all of the time, and the existing production is almost enough. I think that if keep just one constructor for making copper sheets on all the time, you'll have enough of them to the end of the game. The only problem in Satisfactory for me was logistics: when there's not enough resource deposits for your production, you need to go for 30 minutes just to find it and find the path to it, after what you can start exploiting it. And that means placing many foundations, many electric pols, conveyors, rails, train stations, conducting pipes and other boring activities. And there's no even copy-paste function out of the box, although it doesn't help much in context of 3D world.

Mindustry, on the other hand, plays differently. In Mindustry, you never feel yourself like a factory worker, doing always the same. Instead, Mindustry makes you build your factory under constant enemy pressure. You're never safe, and your factory is never safe, so you either think fast and understand how to restart the impact reactor that failed due to wrong distribution of fuel and lack of safety power plant precautions, or your surge alloy smelters fail and turrets are left with no ammo, and you'll have to witness how some other turrets are desperately trying to hold enemies. Oh yeah, and did you know that there aren't many turrets that shoot air targets? Well, it doesn't matter anymore because your core is on fire, and you don't have enough metaglass to build a system to extinguish it, so it's better to ignore that fire and get back to the impact reactor until the next wave has started, or maybe abandon it and just use another, worse yet simpler generator.
The production chains of Mindustry are all simple and short, but building a factory is not a trivial task. The space is always limited and there's no way to circumvent this. There's often not enough resources, as building is expensive. There's always a threat of a building being destroyed. Some buildings (like late-game turrets) take too long to construct alone, so you need to use helper robots to finish them in the limited time you have. And sometimes just having a defense is not enough: you need to *attack* yourself. You need to start building robots and rebuild them very quickly when they die.

Mindustry is a strategic game, and, IMHO, it's much harder to master than other factory games, and it's much more challenging (if we don't compare it to Factorio's death world, of course).

I never write reviews, but I love this game, simply put. I put well over 200 hours in before the 7.0 Update, and around 50 to clear Erekir + the new levels on the first planet. Had a blast the whole time.

If you are a fan of Base building, tower defense, and/or RTS games, this is a huge win of a game. The 7.0 update makes it even more so able to be played like an RTS, which really just means you can utilize your units instead of them being lemmings. 

Unsolicited commentor advice: I will say that if you are someone who wants to super optimize and go FAST on Erekir, consider slowing down and playing at the pace the game sets for you. Resources are, in general, extremely limited. The game is paced to be fair based on what you have available to you, so don't rush! I found myself waiting on resources more often than not, or running on 50% power the whole time because I wanted to tech up and build up industry at the rate I could at a maxed out campaign from the first Planet. Obviously, that didn't work very well. I almost got frustrated with things a few levels in, maybe by level 5 on Erekir, at the pacing of things, but eventually as you get better tools, it really opens up.

The first planet is kind of able to be cheesed a lot, which is understandable.
Erekir, however, has actual requirements, and progression to each level. You might not have all of your resources for the whole of a mission, and you need to go defeat your enemy to be able to advance. Once I learned that the game was entirely differently paced from the first planet, I started having way more fun.

All in all, I absolutely recommend this game, and had a ton of fun playing it. Heck, it's even 50% off when it just had a MAJOR content update. That's awesome! So, thank you to the Dev for making such an enjoyable game!

This game is perhaps the most hours of entertainment per dollar I've gotten from any game in my library. While there are some games I've played longer, I can confidently say that every hour I've played this game, I have been having some sort of fun.

As far as gameplay goes, while many will make the comparison to factorio (a valid comparison) I would say that it's closer in nature to a tower defence game, like many classic flash games. The primary distinction between Mindustry and tower defence games of course, is that you have to supply all the material and ammunition for the turrets yourself, destroying enemies only protects your currently existing factory, it does not give you resources. With the release of the new planet, the game instead takes on RTS elements. having played through a few levels with a friend, each level, rather than being a factory building simulator, has become a strategic campaign.

The addition of a world map has added a new dimension to the gameplay. While in most games of similar types, whether that be factory managers or tower defense, once you are finished with a level, all your progress resets, in this game however, factories built in other levels persist, and can be used in a variety of ways to assist your progress, whether through transferring resources between levels, continuously producing material for research (even when you're not in the level) or providing a fallback base in case you lose a level, everything you build can be at least marginally useful throughout the game.

The world map has also largely changed the way that the AI affects gameplay, whereas before they were just a continuous nuisance until you had repelled a certain number of waves, now the AI spreads across the planet just as you do. In the case of neutral territory, land claims by the AI are simply on a timer, but in the case of player controlled territory, the player is given an option to either personally defend the level, or to build automated defenses to protect their territory, either way, the AI does a fantastic job of proving to be an excellently balanced challenge for experienced players, and an impetus to learn for less experienced players. On the new planet, the AI has become a *much* more significant threat, and less vulnerable to cheesy tactics.

This game is genuinely fantastic, and the dev is charging very little money for the experience, if you're on the fence, trust me, I was too, but the care, quality, and content put into this game far exceed expecations for the cost. With the recent release of the second planet, I find the general opinion of those I play with (myself included) as asking, "Why was this not a sequel or DLC? I would have bought this again for the full price of the game."

TLDR; This is a great game, with a blend of elements that you've probably seen before, but with nuanced twists. 10 dollars genuinely seems unfair to the developer, especially with more content on the way.

This is quite the hidden gem of a game. If you enjoy the complexity of building a factory, and you're more motivated by defeating the enemy (and robots that go boom) rather than just hoarding resources, then get this game. it's well worth it. 

While it may seem that this is a tower defense game, I would argue it's more of an RTS with tower defense maps. There is an attack mode, where turtle strats pretty much won't work. but you have plenty of time in the first campaign to learn and understand the base building before you have to worry about that ;)

the campaigns are able to be played coop, along with custom maps. Honestly, the tower-defense style mixed with factory building makes for one of my favorite coop RTS experiences. 

It can be tough to learn, but we already covered that you like complexity :) regardless, I do recommend doing the campaign to get exposed to the different mechanics at a more digestible pace.

A factory wargame with deep replayability, a massive number of curated maps, stunning logistics management and fun combat that doesnt get bogged down in micro. AnukenDev is a wonder, and I can only wish them the greatest success.

After playing this game for another hundred hours, I can safely say that this is still one of my favorite games. With the release of the V7 update, the one and only thing I felt was wrong with the game was improved so vastly that I would honestly argue that the unit system is now one of the best aspects of the game. Anuke has managed to beautifully combine a factory simulator, a tower defense, and an RTS into one amazing game. There's several hours of content on both of the planets, with each having their own incredibly cool, unique take on the original ideas. Serpulo is very open-ended, and is more focused on the factory and tower defense elements of the game. It's a really fun campaign to play with friends, and the whole planet is available to siege and take over. Erekir is also an incredibly cool campaign, being much more involved with strategy and launching carefully crafted attacks to slowly break through the enemy defenses. Overall, I love this game, and if you enjoy ANY of the three genres mentioned above, you'll almost certainly love this game.

I've played this game for about 1k hours on mobile and another 500ish on the itch.io pc version. Here are some opinions on the game (spoilers: its a pretty god damn good game)

Core game:
The core game is split into two parts that depend and benefit off of each other: Combat and Production. Each map asks the same question of what to do with your resources, to spend them on units/defense or producing more resources. The game boils down to a compromise between the two and planning your builds/attacks ahead. Want to capture the enemy base that has good resource deposits? better plan ahead to optimize your resource belts so they can support more resource flow, build/plan a generator that can supply the increased production, set aside resources for a new line of defense to protect your new base and produce some units to counter their defenses. Do any of the above wrong and your base will somehow find a way to pop out of existence. This game's tough learning curve and high skill ceiling makes it very satisfying to play, and the constant pressure along with the countless ways to optimize your base gives it very high replay value.

Singleplayer:
The campaign is pretty long and can be very difficult without prior knowledge of the game, I suggest messing around in sandbox or load up a survival map to get the hang of this game's mechanics, picking a couple early game schematics off of the mindustry discord can also help tonnes but is not mandatory.

Multiplayer:
Multiplayer is one of mindustry's greatest strengths, in big thanks to its diverse line of units, turrets and resources to manage. Pvp gives off heavy RTS vibes with the objective of out-pacing your enemies and to cripple their buildings with constant pressure from your units. Pve is a great way to learn the in-s and outs of the game as it's basically a more hands on tutorial given by the community. Multiplayer is also a great place to find schematics.

If you are unsure weather or not the game is a fit for your taste, search 'mindustry itch.io' to find the official itch.io download of the game (which can be bought for free). You can try the full game for free and decide if you want to give the devs some cash.

Have you played tower defense or factory games? This is if you had both of those at the same time. You scale up a factory while fighting off waves of enemies but the depth is so much more than that. The defense towers have to be given ammo and each ammo type does something different. Plus there are performance boost you can give them which further increases the complexity. Once you claim a map, the resources that you make on that map go into a global pool which means you aren't done playing after you 'beat' a map. You can spend a whole lot more time per map maximizing its output because those resources can be used to unlock stuff in the tech tree.
Only recommended for people who can controll their urge to optimize, otherwise it will ruin your life.

There's 2 campaign, for 2 different types of players.  Really.  Big time.


The old campaign.  That one that ran up to V6.  And than, then new one, added on V7.


The old campaign has some messy mechanics and convoluted rules.  It's huge.  Simple but complicated.  With high difficulty spikes...  Winning oftenly feels like you are cheating/exploiting...... which is kind of AWESOME.  I mean, like I said... it's... not for everyone.  But it does feel awesome to figure out the mechanics and weaknesses of the systems and use that knowledge to... win !   It will mean to take a few steps back here and there... grind a little bit here and there.... learn to optimize your setups and all.
It's messy.....  but AWESOME if your the targeted type of person. 


And than, there's the new campaign.  The v7 one.
Meh.  Streamlined, linear, controlled, limited, scripted. 
It... made me miss the old one.
It's good... fine-tuned... clean and clear... not too hard, not too easy... but probably will not fully satisfy those that loved the old one.
But will please more... "casual" players.


Luckilly, you get to choose which campaign you want to do.

there's two planets in this game. serpulo (base game) and erekir.

Serpulo sets the game mechanics (that work allright: build mine>process resource>mix>get the end result.)
there's things like drones to speed up the process (which is quite frankly mandatory) and bots that can be used to attack (and are needed to finish capture)
there's a certain meta when capping the map... let's just say that once certain techs are unlocked (which takes forever, even with multiple maps and 50+ factories doing that resource) you can pretty much cheese the game to the hardest difficulty. with one pair of turrets, running mid/high tier ammo, and some ducting.

and there's blueprints if you struggle with the relatively iffy routing design (things like bridges are just terrible, connecting automaticaly lanes that shouldnt, and links and sorters that feed omnidirectionnally, thus requiring specific resources to make tight constructions. 
Thanks to drones, once you got the process in mind, game's a cakewalk. it has less than a fifth of factorio recipes and all require 1-3 resources max.

erekir is so grindy it's cancer. 
almost all resources are different, mining is worse, power production is worse...
Everything needs to be built by hand (because drones are locked for a massive proportion of the campaign)
YOU ARE FORCED to idle by design (objectives are triggered by base cap, so you can pretty much decide when you get to the next phase on most maps)
and on top of that, you're choked on water, fuel or energy on every single map.
And the ai gets repair drones.
every now and then the game introduces a f*** off mechanic that makes you loose hours of progress, 

it's not that hard to set an alarm when your base is getting hit, especially when it's large.... 
But this game doesnt do that. so you're stuck getting forward inch by inch, setting up a ton of turrets that will be obsolete before you know it (because the devs think hard = hiding ennemy bases and giving them cheaty advantages, thus getting you hit from virtually anywhere) and backtracking constantly because you never know, one of these flying drones might have bypassed your defences and blasted your mines.
