I originally gave this a down-vote, but it turns out my issues with hard to distinguish details and overall visual design was Windows effing up the game via the DPI scaling  -- it made this game look like utter crap.

in the v7 alpha, the game didn't even launch in any normal resolution any more. when I told windows to stfu and let the game itself do all the scaling (you can do this by clicking on the .exe file and click on a checkbox in a submenu) - ALL MY ISSUES WERE SOLVED

so just in case you have an issue in this or other games, it may just be windows.

I've read this "game looks unclear/blurry/...." and similar stuff in games that looked crisp and sharp to me.

so I bet those people had a windows scaling issue and the game was innocent. FI_ICK WINDOWS 11

Use factorio style production chain to defend against waves of enemy like a TD, the campaign is divided into many level where you restart with new tech and new resources to play with. Toward the end you will have to setup export and import between level creating a huge production chain to manage the late game.
You will have to invade enemy bases and create units to attack in a mix of factorio and an RTS, the latest update on a new planet brings more RTS element making the new added level feels a bit like a warcraft 3 campain map.
There is also a logic system to code behaviors for buildings and units, a bit lacking for creeps style games but enough for productions loops and kamikaze units.
The game is huge and provide a lot of hours for automation fans, not a brainless game so avoid if you want a game to relax.

I found this game very moreish, but highly unsatisfying. The enticing things were the Factorio style logistics, the expanding resource and tech tree, and the nice look and theme, the fact that it slowly unfolds from a Factorio-clone into an RTS.

The highly unsatisfying parts were:

1. the complete lack of in-game help regarding things like power and ammo etc. Sure, it's on a wiki, but I want it in game
2. the horrible mobile-port style UI and controls
3. but most importantly: lots and lots of  waiting around, which made the first few maps I played really dull.


I'd really like a fast forward button (yes, yes, I know you can skip waves, but I want to fast forward time). And it's on that point that it gets the thumbs down, I guess.

Still: It's really cheap, so it's probably worth it if you're exhausted on Factorio and other logistic games.
Highly Recommend

Edit: the developers have converted this into the third option I presented below, the "base building" genre. I watched a play through and the gameplay loops seem solid now. Old review left below for reference.

------------

Sadly, I cannot recommend this game. 

Excellent concept (what if we had dueling Factorio bases?) and clearly a labor of love, but needs a serious gameplay overhaul.

Campaign was exceedingly weak: the first 8 defense levels (all that I played) are effortlessly winnable by copy-pasting the cheapest turrets (ground/air) and the cheapest ammo. The first "enemy base assault" level you just mass artillery. There's no forced adaptation, no tradeoffs, no creativity; just build a lot of what works and then wait. You can start with a couple thousand copper each time and immediately build defenses that will hold for the remainder of the level. Alternatively, you can start with minimal supplies and go through a near-identical bootstraping process each sector.

For meta-progression, you could play a base-optimization game to maximize throughput; or you could just let the game idle for 10 minutes and buy the upgrades anyway.

--------------------------------------------------------

To the dev: my biggest complaint is this constant waiting. Please rebalance so that gameplay is continually engaging. Consider moving tech unlocks to depend on resource throughput rather than resources accumulated. Consider have fewer ore patches and simpler maps, but more diverse enemies to encourage the re-tooling of supply chains.

I want to see this game prioritize ONE genre, rather than being a wishy-washy mix. Here's some possibilities:

Real Time Strategy -- Make multiplayer the default play mode, add skill-based match-making, collect data and actively balance units. Keep single-player as a gradual tutorial. Something like "Starcraft" or "Age of Empires".

Tower Defense Game -- Add enemy variety, make players rethink approaches each map. Have discrete challenges where the player needs to restart several times before finding a winning strategy. Something like "Kingdom Rush" or "Creeper World". 

Base Building Game -- Make the map "live", have constant attacks on established bases, have ongoing inter-base logistics (transporting rare resources back from an outpost, hauling expensive mechs to the frontlines). Something like "Factorio" or "AI War: Fleet Command".

-------------------------------------------------------

If going the multiplayer route (eg Starcraft), keep the enemy as is. Otherwise, please make an asymmetric enemy such that the AI doesn't need to design/repair/understand complex bases. Look at Factorio's biters, or Creeper World's creep, or Slay the Spire's monsters. Hold a simple baseline and let the player optimize a complex system to surpass it. Offer a difficulty progression system to bump up this baseline for added challenge.

I recognize that some of what I suggest (attacks from enemy bases) is already in the game, but I didn't get a single attack within my first 7 hours of gameplay. If "live map" is supposed to be a core game mechanic, please launch a tiny invasion 30 minutes in to inform players "this is a thing that happens". Likewise, I assume that at some point in the progression I'll be forced to use more advanced turrets and ammo, but that should happen earlier and more frequently.

I'll revisit Mindustry on its next major release, and I'm hoping for a big improvement.

Factorio popularised the logistics sim. Mindustry hybridises that with the tower defence game. Do battle with waves of enemies, or launch your own at enemy bases - victory is determined not by who has the best tactical skill, but who can build the best sprawling manufacturing chain to keep the front lines fed. And these are good, challenging logistics systems, with much scope for the satisfaction of seeing them work well - and for disaster should you make mistakes, or fail in hastily revising your network for changing needs.

Take this review with a grain of salt. This refers mostly to later game and is subject to change with updates. I thoroughly enjoy this game despite its lackluster explanation of how to play the game. It has a strong basis but has a crutch of relying on either immediate set-up or sending materials from other locations. The first requires intensive initial planning and use of partial schematics to create a usable material supply. The latter requires going to another map to redirect shipments by map. On some of the more difficult maps, leaving the map (even before a wave is spawning) will cause the core to fall and to lose the map, making it impossible to abandon any location. The "off-screen" mechanics of other maps feels a bit over simplified. Some maps can be impenetrable while playing but will be lost within a few minutes of switching map. 

This game has great potential for end-game and further elaborating game play. Currently, it falls a bit short into a clunky "can't reach the phone to call for help" way. The expectation to build complex units while the enemy can spawn dozens of units at the start, doesn't feel like a consistent challenge. It feels more like an initial slog with higher difficulty that can eventually be overcome. 

If you would like a simple factory style building game with a good research tree, I would recommend this game. For more experienced players, I would say to put it on your wishlist for later.

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
Purchasing this game was a good use of $6. It might look like a simple game, but the tech tree and quantity of blocks is really crazy. Calling this game a Factorio clone just because there's factory management elements is comparing apples to oranges; like comparing Valorant to TF2. My point being that both games specialize in very specific elements; sure they're similar at a quick glance, but they play very very differently. This game is much more small-scale and combat focused. The time pressure is very heavy. Like Factorio, this game has a pretty good modding scene, and sharing blueprints with one another is really streamlined.

The v7 beta update honestly does damage the fun for me due to some of it's "QoL" changes. It removes processor blocks (what you use to control units) on the new planet, and changes the old v6 unit control system for something honestly far, FAR worse, requiring much more micromanagement of your units. You can set rally points, but you still have to manually command them to attack... which is not very fun in a game where you're already micromanaging several different things and an entire factory; it makes attack maps extremely frustrating, because you can't command an army and plan out your big silicon expansion at the same time. The update does add some pretty cool stuff though at least.

There are a couple of things that hold this game back from being perfect, though. I'm a big proponent of being able to criticize things I like, so while I do love this game, I am going to point out its flaws:
- First, the time pressure is really intense. If you're in a high threat level area, expect to be multitasking like an insane CEO would, managing both a crumbing defense and poorly planned logistical nightmare on a pretty large scale; this is one thing the game's multiplayer really helps at (and is very engaging, to be fair).
- Second, also relating to the time pressure, is that most of the maps only go to ~30 or so waves. While this may seem like a lot, the difficulty scaling is kinda weird, and a wave typically spawns between once every 30 seconds to once every minute. The waves do NOT pause while you're fighting an already spawned wave, which can lead to a tidal wave of BS knocking down your entire factory.
- Third, the difficultly scaling is kinda wack. Base assaults are absurdly difficult in singleplayer; you have to both manage a defense against INFINITE waves that scale in difficulty very very quickly, AND manage to scrape together enough resources to produce an army strong enough to cause a dent in the enemy's fortress. This orients the game more towards designing good schematics and knowing when/where to place them down.
- Lastly, another issue with the difficulty scaling (even on normal wave maps) is that either a map will be really easy or incredibly difficult. There is rarely an intermediate, and this gets worse when you're playing with multiple people and there's literally nothing to do but try to speed through the waves. Of course, just when you start to feel safe is when you have to remember that there IS a guardian (the boss) that will most likely spawn from some awkward angle and casually walk around your defenses, defeating you on the last wave. Nothing more frustrating in this game than that.

Updating my review.  I used to prefer the android version, but the PC version has long since surpassed the level of QoL possible on a mobile device.  

My favorite QoL so far is the : When you drag conveyors over obstacles, bridges are automatically placed over those obstacles, and junctions are automatically placed when you cross conveyors.  You'll still need to place things manually when making spaghetti, but making simple conveyors lines over long distances has never been easier.

The game is what it looks like, and it does what it tries to do well.  It's basically a simplified, streamlined Factorio that focuses on combat.  Did I mention that blueprints are unlocked from the very beginning?

The difficulty of "winning" is low, but if you want to try mods, personal challenges, or win with "style" the game has quite a bit of replayability.

I haven't seen many reviews comparing Mindstry to Factorio, another popular base-builder, so I'm gonna give it a whirl. 

Factorio is one of the shining pillars of base-building games; having to actually move your resources from one place to another to use them is a very novel idea and one that Factorio has pretty much perfected. In Factorio, everything is made to reward you for careful planning and frequent optimizations: resources run out, forcing you to replace your original builds with your new, better designs, and careful use of space & energy is necessary due to the aggressive bugs around the map that discourage rapid expansion.

Mindustry, however, rewards players for the opposite behavior, encouraging players to rapidly expand early on so that they can defend themselves from enemies that progressively grow more difficult. Bugs in Factorio simply serve as a tool to keep your base size in check, but in Mindustry the enemies are the main attraction! Flying units target vulnerable outer bases, some units climb over walls, and others are tanky but march directly toward your base. 

To help combat this, there are a ton of different buildable turrets, each with unique requirements that make some better than others on certain stages. All this makes the base building dynamic and sometimes a bit chaotic, which is a nice change of pace from Factorio. If you liked factorio but hated the combat, you'll probably love Mindustry.

Really, though, the TD aspect is only scratching the surface. Mindustry has a lot of really awesome mechanics (like the ability to manage multiple levels at once or send resources from previous bases) and some bizzare ones (RTS-style units that you can control *with assembly language*) that are fun to explore and experiment it with. For $6 you'll find it's well worth the money.

This game is a creative sandbox. It requires you to use your brain to figure out the best routes while also creating a considerable challenge in the form of a tower defense. If you leave a gap in your defenses, you'll get hit hard. 

I highly recommend this game to the fullest of my capacity. Best game I've found myself in the last 2 years.

This was the first automation game I found. I played it on my cell phone in like v.3 or 4 or something and went total ham for it. It sparked a love for what's now become one of my favourite genres. I've got my sister into it now too. Mwahahaha

That being said, the difficulty curve is wild. And the progression is such that you have to eventually go back to all the old sectors and rebuild, because there's no amount of defences that'll ever hold. It becomes impossible after a while, and (even though I destroyed previous versions) I had to give up. There just wasn't any way to win. I remember packing like half a map with nothing but the best turrets, and coming back 15 min later to a ruined map. I'm really hoping v.7 will bring that curve to a more reasonable level. If a player wants ultra challenge, there's better ways besides hard-boiling them into your main campaign.

I picked this up for free on itch.io but felt compelled to buy it on Steam in order to support the wonderful work this dev is doing. This game does have quite the learning curve, but if you stick with it, you'll be rewarded with dozens, or maybe hundreds, of hours of interesting and challenging gameplay. Two quick tips for those who do decide to pick this up:
1. Pause early and pause often. This game (at least in single-player) has a super important pause function which you can use to help with planning. You can browse the map for the various resources while paused, but keep in mind you can't see the enemy spawn location unless you physically bring your ship there. Don't be ashamed to pause, because thinking through the placement of your construction is very important here (big surprise, I bet).
2. Stay active on the map. It might be fun to watch your carefully crafted defenses or units crush your enemy, but that's time you could be spending adding on more resource generation or working on other elements of your defense or offense. If you need time to think, refer to my first tip above.
That being said, I highly recommend this game. If you really need to try it before you buy it, go grab it on itch.io like I did (or on Github if you're somewhat tech-literate). But please do buy it, because this project is super impressive, and financial support is an excellent incentive to continue its development.

This game exists somewhere between Tower Defense and Factory Building games.  The graphics are VERY simplistic, but for a Factory Game where you're building all the time, at incredible speed, it makes buildings and their functions immediately apparent and easy to manage.  The enemies are very simple, and very simple to counter, so there is very little in the way of strategy against the enemy.  The strategy comes from utilizing the resources available at the given level.  
In short: I'm a big fan.  The creator views this as a labor of love, and the Steam community offers blueprints for very complex machinery necessary to simplify your life.  Great job!

Mindustry is an excellent mix of Factorio and tower defense blended together in a nice and entertaining way. The game has quite a bit of content in store ranging from an robust campaign mode to custom games and even multiplayer. As the review currently stands, the game has an overwhelmingly positive score (Which is very hard for a game to get that type of score). There is a ton going for this game, but there are some pitfalls that can be seen from time to time

[h1] Breakdown [/h1]
[b] Score: 83/100 | Excellent! [/b]

[b] Graphics: 7/10 |  Great Quality [/b]
     The game's graphics is an arcade-style visual and fits the style of game very well. these graphics are visually appealing, especially the robots that you create and the responsive animations the machines uses. However, It is sometimes hard to distinguish certain buildings from one to the other. A good example of this is related to bridge and the junction blocks being close to similar in texture. even the bridges themselves look a bit similar. 

[b] Gameplay: 16/20 | Excellent [/b]
     This game nails the delivery on gameplay. the is a decent amount of content to go through as well as other options for you to do afterwards. The difficulty of the game is fairly stable in the difficulty curve. It is easy to learn but very hard to master for those who want to take optimization of the factory to the next level. One thing to note is that the campaign does take a long time to finish. Just be very careful as you might find yourself up at 2 AM in the morning optimizing a setup you created. It is very addictive to play.

[b] GUI: 13/20 | Inconvenient [/b]
      I do admit, the GUI of the game does need a bit of work. It is vary thematically appealing in visuals, but does have its downsides. It is sometimes hard to find what you want to place in the menu, especially with some of the visuals being similar (Look at Graphics for more info on that). The buttons are well Icon'd and placed conveniently, but can be repetitive to have to get a specific part you need. Fortunately, There are well placed tool-tips and even keybindings for you to help circumvent the issue which is not as problematic once I got it down. otherwise, the Graphic User Interface is quite robust.

[b] Content: 16/20 | Decent Variety [/b]
     The game has quite a bit of content to go through. There is the campaign mode which has a great learning curve to the game. you will be going through the early game quickly while quickly slowing down to mastering the gameplay as time goes by.
     For those who want a quicker or a command and conquer style, there are custom games for that! There are pre-made maps that suits to what type of game you want to play. Sandbox? Endless waves? PVE/PVP? They are all there along with visual icons that represent the mode they offer! 
     Finally: There is also a robust and well made map-editor. the editor is not as responsive as the other features, but it's quite solid where it stand at the moment. you can also edit in gameplay which works ironicly well.

[b] Stability: 18/20 | Bugs? What Bugs? [/b]
     For a developing game, the game is extremely stable! bugs are almost unheard of during gameplay and the ones that are currently in does not impact gameplay at all. Yes, all games do have bugs and there are a few that might be a tad-bit inconvenient, but otherwise the game is very well made

[b] Price 10/10 | Extremely Underpriced [/b]
    For a game like this, the pricing is extremely low! As of this review, the price is [b]$5.99[/b], which is way more than just a great deal. on top of that, there are occasions where the price went even lower due to sales, making this game way more than just worth the buy. (estimated value: $14.99)

Fun game, even if a lot of things are stupid. Still fun, but frustratingly stupid.
Stupid:
-Machines don't have outputs. So products will often jam up lines, even if the input has a don't fking put this here node. It won't care, and will put the thing you deliberately tell it DON'T FKING PUT THIS HERE into that fking node. So you're CONSTANTLY deleting and rebuilding lines that jammed up for no reason. I hate silicon. I hate it. I hate rebuilding stuff that randomly stops working, even after it's been working for the last 30+ minutes. Oh woooww... why am I out of silicon? Let's see.... Oh I see, I've got to rebuild a whole bunch of lines, because the DON'T FKING PUT THIS HERE node broke. Again. It makes no sense, why the hell isn't there an output node? This is an obvious and predictable problem. If you don't have an output, and the machine can ignore the don't fking put this here node, you'll obviously get jams. Constantly. From working lines breaking for no fking reason. Sorry, it's the dumbest thing in the game by no small margin, and it happens a LOT.
-Arbitrary unit caps.
-Most guns do crap damage(even endgame lvl/using endgame mats).
-Hidden mechanics. Apparently if you spray mobs w/ water, they'll take more damage from lightning. Even though water doesn't conduct electricity. Unless the water is filled with impurities, that are close enough to allow the electricity to pass through them, only then will it conduct, and it CERTAINLY wouldn't strengthen it.
-Everything will become spaghetti, as a whole bunch of nodes you wouldn't expect to do so, will eject on to either side, if lines run next to them.
-A bunch of machines(especially late game) need more than 3 materials. Why is that bad dev? Idk, maybe because some of them are 3x3, machines don't have fking outputs, the DON'T FKING PUT THIS HERE node only works when it feels like it, and a whole bunch of other belt nodes will offset to either side, even if you'd expect them to be unable to. 
I.e. A bunch of stupid crap is frustrating for stupid reasons.

it's factorio but simpler, but much more focused on combat. it's a simple loop of gather resources, fortify emplacements to defend your base against the enemy us armed forces, gather and combine more advanced resources to strengthen your defense and fend off more advanced units, or create your own troops to raze the american territories, repeat. this simple cycle is honestly addicting, and it's only made better by the campaign, as more and more new content trickles in as you, the soviet union, conquer more of the alien planet.

it's also open source on github, completely free in itch.io (steam has better multiplayer though), and it's linux native. very based. I can't recommend enough.

Outright, if you are looking at Mindustry because you are bored with Factorio and want something similar, look elsewhere. I came to Mindustry looking to get my Factorio fix and found out that Mindustry is all about fast-paced RTS gameplay before it is about automation and factory building. I will not be playing any more Mindustry given that I have now reached a point in the campaign where the time limits presented by the waves are insurmountable to a slower player such as myself. While the early game was fun and I loved, loved, loved setting up factories to supply turrets and machines, I could not get over the barriers presented by more difficult regions. 

That said, I cannot dogpile a game because I am a crappy RTS player. The game is incredible - it is a very cheap title for something with such engaging gameplay and a solid framework to build around. The game does an incredible job of combining RTS gameplay with Factorio's factory construction. The building mechanics, especially how items are moved into and out of machines, is quite obtuse but an understandable hurdle after some practice. The game has all of the systems of a factory builder that I would want to be present, I just suck at the RTS components too much to really enjoy the game. It looks good, sounds good, and has solid gameplay for a simple indie game, I'm just to bad at it. If you like RTS titles with an emphasis on resource management like AoE or SC2, this is a game for you.

It has promise, but also enough flaws to make me dislike it. 

As Einstein eloquently said once: As simple as possible, but no simpler. This game has done some things too simple. Perhaps the biggest source of annoyance is that every output connects to every single conveyor or other input there is. This makes logistics a hassle because the auto-connection means that to get things routed efficiently, you need a lot of space to avoid them colliding into each other. 

The research tree is something that just makes you spend a ton of time waiting for resources. It would be far better if the game just had a planned tech progression. This thing just makes it so that the player, in order to max his capability for the next level, lets the game run in the background for 20 minutes, buys a tech, then 20 minutes more, etc. That is horrible game design. 

UI is too simple too, making it hard to see what traits things have, etc. When every facility is dedicated to producing a single recipe, then you should be able to make UI elements displaying this in a neat way. Weapon systems also should be so that you can see what is anti-air, what is anti-ground, what is both. 

and dear god, the need to shove all the resources back into the main base that's so far away.... 

I also don't understand why the game lets you bring a high amount of resources along with you. Only worsens the whole "afk to get resources" trend. 

This game seemed to want to be open but also have a strong direction. It suffers as the game dev couldn't pick one of the two.

I first rated this game thumbs down in 2019.  I am changing it to a thumbs up.

In the same way people praise this game over Factorio, I found it not at all similar, except that it has transport belts.  This is less of a base building, systems engineering game, and more of a light tower defense game with logistics, more akin to creeper world.   The logistics portion of the game requires very little planning in earlier stages and can be slapped down without much thought at all.  The result is repetitive and somewhat tedious.  However the game scales nicely and the tedium of placing the same structures can be avoided by using copy paste and schematics.

Basically, this game is a tower defense game with logistics.  The downside is that the logistics aren't difficult to solve, and I wish the waves of enemies were more constant.  As it stands, sometimes beating a level is a waiting game.  All in all there are alot of units, structures, etc...  I enjoy it.

Well, I don't do reviews too often. However, Mindustry is probably the best game I've ever played. I would highly recommend it, however there is something you should know before buying. And it's worth the price too.

Mindustry is often tedious in the campaign, while it starts off nice it easily becomes just a chore to play. You need to go steal other people's schematics from multiplayer otherwise your schematics will be far too inefficient to make any good resources. Plus, most late game sectors are attacked by bases. For example, Nuclear production complex is attacked by FOUR different bases, all of which require tier 5 units when you probably haven't even made ONE tier four unit. This game is a chore in the campaign, and I recommend you stick to multiplayer. Just forget the campaign altogether. Use a cheat mod if you have to, this game's campaign is just a chore.

Oh yeah and the game doesn't really give you any helpful tips. I was duo (weakest turret in the game) spamming until Ruinous shores and Stained Mountains, and was surprised when I got wiped by the bosses because the game never made me make complex defenses, just encouraged duo spamming. I had to go to the wiki to find people to tell me I should be using Lancers. Thankfully, they no longer send a T4 unit to people on Stained Mountains, but the quasar isn't much better.

But frankly, for all this game's flaws, you can easily find yourself surpassing 700 or 800 hours on some $7 game.

An absolute master-class in the tower defense genre. I've logged dozens of offline hours in this, it's been my addiction after work and on the weekends for weeks.

This game features a campaign, custom maps, map editors, and multiplayer game modes. But for the purpose of this review, I'll focus on the campaign (which is, to me, the meat and potatoes of the game).

The campaign features 2 different game modes: Survival and capture. You'll have hundreds of sectors in the in-game world to capture, and you'll either have to build defenses to survive a set number of waves, or build units (while managing defense) to capture an enemy sector. The game works in real-time so while you're capturing a sector, a sector you already captured may come under attack. The game does background calculations to determine whether or not it'll survive, so you can't just ditch a sector after you capture it; You have to build defenses.

Resource management is also a huge factor in this game. Some sectors are perfect for producing glass, others are good for producing plastic (plastanium, in-game). You'll want to launch to new sectors with the right amount of resources, so perfecting resource production is essential to this game. That's where I like to sink my time; Perfecting storage, extraction, and production.

The game is fabulous. It's like factorio in a lot of ways, and scratches the same itch, but there's a more `obvious` short-term goal. You're essentially playing a form of factory-building tower-defence, and there's a little more emphasis on the defence piece than there is in factorio. It's also quite accessible, but has enough complexity lurking in there to keep you occupied for quite a while after you've gotten past the basics.

It's very well put together, and it's just a single dev. Definitely worth the full price, no question, and the overwhelmingly positive review score is definitely justified.

This game used to build up in difficulty, but since the planetary update its curve increased dramatically.

I have 4 bases. The 5th base I continually try to take on has prebuilt defenses that my level 2 drones cannot get past. So stalemate right? No. Even after destroying all of the production surrounding that base for the enemy, they still spawn extremely strong waves of enemys that my defenses cannot handle, wiping out most of them. This is because after wave 53 you get a guardian every single round, along with the usual medium weight drones the enemy throws at you. So instead of being able to focus on how to up my drone-game, it turns into me focusing on rebuilding my defenses all the way into the next wave of enemys, creating a self-fulfilling cycle of defeat.

I also just learned that the quintessential base I need to take to unlock one particular upgrade that *might* help is on the other side of the planet and locked. 

I'm all for a challenge, but the guardian every wave bs pushed me over my limit with this game. The drones that help you rebuild your base automatically should be unlocked way earlier in the game. It does not make for fun gameplay to have the layout of your base put together so nice and neatly with logic processors to ensure it runs correctly, just to have it turned into a rats nest the next wave. I can't even focus on the main objective because I'm too busy trying to keep my base supplied and defended.

Also, air enemies spawning randomly some distance outside of the spawn circle is really becoming annoying. The spawn circle shouldn't even be there if enemies can spawn well outside of it.

It's like this game was someones second passion project, which started off well, but has since been maintained by free contributions from the community and developers-in-learning, some of whom I have met and they just behave like pompous entitled children. This game saved my life.

I am 22.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realise that.

Thank you

Recommended BUT it has some issues that has resulted in me not having the desire to play it any longer.

This game was really good a year ago before "V5".  It was just a factory + td game and was fun to play.  Then V5+ came out where the dev tried to make this an RTS too.  There were some great improvements in V5+, but the core gameplay/maps became less about TD and more about your units/RTS.  This is why I don't like this game anymore:

1. Gameplay now relies heavily on "logic" (programmable code attached to units/buildings):  AI is horrible; can't control groups of units (like in any RTS);  can't give them specific orders;  units need 'sight' (you can see enemy units anywhere on the map, but your units won't respond unless a tower or another unit can see the enemy too) to do things.  There isn't any default logic from the developer - it is all player made.  Also good luck figuring it out as there is little documentation and the community can be unhelpful as well.

2. Power management is still awful.  If a power node is destroyed, all buildings connected to it lose power even if another power node is in range.

3. Pre-V5, building units was simple.  Now you need to move units from one factory to another to improve them - it is overly complicated imo.  This problem becomes more apparent when you reach max capacity for a unit type.  Pre-V5: the factory stops producing; doesn't affect other factories.  Post-V5: all connected factories/units stop producing (conveyor belt jam) unless you use logic/whatever to reroute the unit conveyor belts.  As far as I know, you can't make one unit and send it to a factory to be upgraded, you need low tier factories connected to the higher tier ones.

4. "Smart" pathing for conveyors is a joke.  It will often go through existing conveyors instead of pathing along side of them.

5. Upgrading conveyors to higher tiers is tedious.  There is no way to upgrade them in a single action - you have to manually build better conveyors over the older ones.

6. No way to disable night/day graphics.  This wasn't a thing in pre-V5.  The night time is too dark and can make it hard to see the terrain.  I found it straining for my eyes.

7. Can't preview enemies in upcoming waves.  On a certain level, there is an air boss in the last wave and it will likely destroy your entire bases - this is because the previous waves are ground-heavy and the air attacks do little damage.  So when the final boss is air, it flies over your ground-focused defenses and destroys everything else.  Since you can't save, you have to redo the level again.


With that said, this game has some good factory fun.  There is a lot of strategy for efficient layouts.  The tech progress is fun too (again, I feel pre-V5 was better for feel of progress/accomplishment).  The TD aspect of the game is a lot of fun.  Lots of cool turrets and utility buildings.  The enemies has good variety and some are quite challenging.  Controls are decent.  Workshop is great.  Modding is possible and you will even find recoding of the main client (not via workshop, look online).  Never tried co-op but people seem to enjoy that as well.

If you like factory and TD games, you'll probably enjoy this.  However you won't like it if you are expecting an RTS factory type game.

I've got a lot of hours into Factorio and love the game, and all the reviews seemed to indicate Mindustry as "Factorio Light" so I was never in a hurry to play. I was expecting a relatively simple game that'd be maybe 10-12 hours of playtime, but boy was I wrong. The price point was great so I didn't really mind picking this title up on sale and letting it sit. After finally getting around to playing, however, the game devoured my attention: it's not a simple Factorio clone. The same guts are present, sure, in the form of belts and pipes and production buildings, but beyond the similarities is a clever, dynamic real-time strategy game with a phenomenal level of polish.

You play off the concept of capturing a planet by building factories in different sectors, and the progression between them is stellar. There's a total of 16 resources, all of which have interesting and unique quirks, but their introduction is gradual. You start off with simple mechanical drills and pumps, but more and more sophisticated tools become available as you move from map to map. Each time you change locations, you launch a new core with stockpiled resources, allowing you to move to new zones without the feeling of completely "starting over." Resources are very cleverly designed, and each map has unique challenges be it scarcity, tight corridors, or enemy factories to conquer.

Overall, the game feels remarkably rewarding as you move from simple copper and lead contraptions to gigantic assembly lines putting together walking battleships. While I do not think the game is overly challenging, it does have its moments and frustrations, and the power grid is balanced very nicely to make all your tools come with proper cost. Getting the biggest, baddest reactors, for example, comes with the need for large quantities of coolant and high-end fuel processing, and one slip into blackout conditions around a guardian span will give you a quick trip to restart. The maps interact with one another, and research steps beyond the factory on a simple map producing resources. True to its name, the game has a feeling of building an entire planetary industry, and the logistical challenges heavily avoid "copy-pasting" the same strategy map to map.

What really adds icing to the cake, however, is the sheer breadth of quality of life features that make the game an absolute joy to play. Placing belts is highly intelligent, and tools exist for managing required spaghetti in a quick and efficient manner. The end result is a game that clearly is an immense labor of love by the developer, and is absolutely worth your time if you're into the city building/logistical web genre like Factorio. Just don't expect it to be a carbon copy -- this title stands absolutely proudly on its own two feet, and comes at a pricepoint that seems ridiculously too low for the amount of content present.

Mindustry is a fun, novel hybrid of Factorio-style production line simulation, tower defence and RTS. Landed on an alien planet with but a humble home base and zippy scout construction drone, you must set to work scraping up ores, refining them into components, and building an industrial and defensive infrastructure before enemy hordes set upon your fragile conveyor belts. Be sure to keep your walls in good repair and your towers stocked with ammunition, or armies of enemy robots will quickly send you back to the drawing board.

With serviceable pixel graphics that would run comfortably on a pocket calculator and a pleasing drip-drip-drip of escalating power and enemy difficulty through the course of its campaign, Mindustry offers relatively punchy 30 – 60 minute encounters over Factorio’s staggering length and depth. This structure provides plenty of accessibility and lends itself to dipping in and out of a variety of scenarios, but also results in a repetitive early game worsened by a slightly fussy, clunky interface. A few more quality-of-life features, including perhaps the ability to automate some building placement and – especially – an auto-rebuild option, would be very welcome.

Mindustry nonetheless offers a generous and replayable campaign with a satisfying core loop, and for all its lo-fi trappings represents a unique and successful fusion of production line management and RTS-lite. More accessible than Factorio and a much more satisfying sandbox than most tower defence games, Mindustry offers something to both top-down strategy veterans and players looking for a jumping-on point. For a game as cheap and well-supported by its devs as this, it’s undoubtedly worth taking a punt.

Defiantly another game that uses similar parts to that of Factorio. Of course the recipe has been remade into a tactical resource management game. 

To start off on the differences Mindustry works with smaller maps so it makes so that a good layout of industry and tech can make a difference. In the campaign you can hold multiple maps or sectors as the game calls it to load and stock up materials to supply the front line or send off the goods to make the stuff in a different area. Of course not all the sectors will have each resource available in one area or another.

Going on the next part the enemy of the game is another mining/military force. These guys will test your forces and strength to keep the sector. Depending the difficiulty of the sector you will have to deal with easy or hard enemies. At the same time if you capture a sector next to a enemy base. Those bad guys can send a attack force to take the sector from you. 

The main campaign is a fair good way to get a idea how the tech and buildings work, but also includes a sandbox game for getting a less stress way of learning how to use the tech. Or in some cases Teach you to make sure you have what you need before you have a spectacular failure. 

For how much your getting in this solid game I say its a good one even if it take some study to figure out the best method

I have only put in 40 hours into Mindustry but I feel I have enough of the game to provide a preliminary review. 

For me, I wanted to know how this compared to Factorio. So that’s where I will focus.

In case you get bored reading the entire review, my findings are simple. I recommend both of them for different reasons. If you are looking for a unique Tower Defense Game with elements of RTS and resource mining, then Mindustry is the game to get. If you are looking for a resource management and automation games to challenge your engineering skills with elements of a Tower Defense Game, then Factorio is the game to get. Besides both having resources and conveyer belts, and some similar elements in the gameplay, these games are very different and will provide very different game experiences. I hope you enjoy both as I have.

First, let’s look at the obvious similarities and differences:

The player in Factorio is a person. When that person dies, game over so make sure to save often (and watch out for trains – the most common killer in Factorio). In Mindustry the player is a ship that respawns at the “core” building when they die. If the core building is destroyed, the game doesn’t end, buy your attempt at taking the sector fails. You can immediately try to retake the sector and most of the stuff you built will already be there giving you a huge advantage the second (or third) time round.

At first glance Mindustry looks and feels much like Factorio. It has an overhead view, patches of different resources like coal, copper, and iron. You build a miner on the patch of resources to extract the resources. Multiple miners can be placed to cover the entire patch of resources. In both games conveyer belts are used to move the resources to various types of buildings to produce advanced resources or units. 

One of the biggest differences between the games is the gameplay. In Mindustry, the game feels much like a tower defense game. Like is a tower defense game, the map begins completely revealed, and enemies come in waves from an identified "spawning zone". Thus the first goal is to get the “towers” built to kill off the waves. Each wave has a countdown timer and each wave intensifies in units and strength. If you successfully survive the set of waves, the sector (the level you’re on) becomes part of your territory on the planet. Also Mindustry has an RTS feeling to it, most useful when attacking enemy bases. Units of ground, air, and water can been built and either directly or indirectly controlled to attack.

In Factorio, the gameplay is very different. The end goal is to ultimately launch satellites, but I think most players would agree the real goal in Factorio is to make the most efficient, automated factories, and to have fun tinkering with the factories to make the smallest improvements. But there is an element of Town Defense in Factorio. As the pollution from the factories grows, the native bugs will begin to attack. But they do not come in “waves” with a timer, not necessarily always from the same place, and they grow in intensity only if you provoke them with more pollution. Although Factorio has a Tower Defense element to the game, it definitely does not feel like a tower defense game. Likewise Factorio does not really have units or the feel of an RTS game. There are vehicles the player can build to ride in, some of which have fire power, like the tank. But in the Vanilla game you can’t create 10 tanks and control them all in an attack. There are many mods that allow armies of units to be created in Factorio, but it still doesn’t have the “feel” of an RTS. 

Also, it is important to note Mindustry has “levels”, each with a static, completely revealed map, which can be seen at all times. Each level is a sector on the planet. Factorio is played on an endlessly generated map, which uses fog of war for areas the player does not have radar or another means of seeing it.

Now that we’ve covered the basics, let’s take a little deeper look:

In both games there is the concept of global resources. In Mindustry it is very simple. There is a “core” building and by sending resources to the “core” building, the resources become available globally. In Factorio the global resources are handled through the logistics system, which comprises of a number of connected Roboports to create a logistics sector, various types of storage chests to store things, logistic bots to transport things, and construction bots to build things. The most obvious difference is the complexity in Factorio. But with the complexity also come a great deal more flexibility in what you can do.

Both games have the ability to place blueprints on the ground to build buildings and conveyer belt systems to transport solid and liquid resources. In both games, construction bots (known as Poly ships in Mindustry) use the global resources to build the placed blueprints. 
In Mindustry, the blue print approach is the only way to build things. Also buildings are only used to create more advanced types of resources, electricity, defense structures, or to create units. In Factorio, many of the items and buildings can be built in the player’s inventory, and then placed directly into the world. Like Mindustry, the buildings in Factorio can produce advanced types of resource or electricity, defense buildings, and to create units. But Factorio also has a complete factory system, to automate the creation of anything in the game, from simple parts to locomotive engines to even creating entire bases.
Both Mindustry and Factorio have a blueprint catalog where the player can save a building plan. In both systems, you select the buildings to save and click create blueprint. I found both systems were about equally usable. 

Both games have a research tree. In Mindustry you simply “buy” a new technology. In Factorio you must create Labs and feed them scientific resources to research new technologies. Both games require more advanced resources for more advanced technologies. I felt Mindustry’s research tree was a little small for my liking. Factorio’s is much larger.
Mods can be applied to both games. Being around longer, Factorio seems to have a larger library of mods to choose from.
In Mindustry, focusing on Tower Defense, it has a good variety of enemies and bosses to defeat. In Factorio there are maybe a dozen (probably less) different enemies to defeat. It’s pretty easy in both games to setup a defense system that will protect your base.

Getting into the complicated parts of both games, both games have a complete logic system, where you can “program” things to happen. In both games you can tap into the properties of any part of the game, such as the total number of coal in the logistics (or global) network. Based on the number, you can choose to enable factories to start or stop consuming coal. In Mindustry, the system reminds me a great deal of the good old Assembly language, placing numbers into memory blocks, and performing actions on the blocks, bit operations, etc. Took me back to the good old days. In Factorio, the system uses more of a logic gate based system. But provides the same degree of control. The only real difference is Factorio’s has more things to control, and since the gameplay promotes automation of factories, the logic system fits more naturally into the game. Mindustry on the other hand, is simplified is so many ways, that such a complex logic system doesn’t fit naturally in the game, and many players have commented on never using it.

There is much more that can be added. Both game are good for different reasons. I personally prefer Factorio more as I really enjoy games that have an “Open World – I can do anything”, but that doesn’t mean I won’t pick up and play Mindustry every now and then when I feel like a Tower Defense game.

Great game, sort-of a stripped down Factorio with RTS elements. At a superficial level it definitely resembles a tower defense, but the game also requires you to make units, manually direct them, and take out enemy bases, so I'd hesitate to put it into that category.

Most of my praises have already been sung better by other reviewers, so I'll mention some of the shortcomings I found. As of v6, the difficulty ramps up far too quickly near the end of the main campaign, and the enemy attempting to 'take back' their sectors in the last few levels can get quite infuriating. Micromanaging units is haphazard and would definitely be better served with a Starcraft-like control scheme; the workflow for making them could also use some polish, and would be great if it were possible to move units between sectors somehow (obviously would need to be expensive to be fair).

One last thing I can say for certain is that this game is criminally underpriced; most highly rated games with a low price tend to be pretty short. Not Mindustry; the main campaign will require at least 40 hours, after which you can continue on conquering dozens of optional sectors on the main planet (many of which are absurdly difficult), or move on to multiplayer/custom maps. So if you're a fan of the resource-management genre and like getting bang for your buck (both in-game and out), you should absolutely pick this up.

Mindustry is such a great defense game, in my mind it overshadows every other defense and TD game I've played since.  It's a lot of what I love from Factorio: defense and building new bases, coming up with designs and adjusting to your environment and doing all that while under the threat of being annihilated.  Building stuff (and tearing it down) is very fluid and satisfying.

The campaign is structured to send you to a new proc-gen map which each lasts less than an hour usually, building up a defense, surviving, exploiting resources, then you move onto the next, picking upgrades and new technology on the way, slowly accustoming you to more complex materials, buildings, towers and enemies.  It's paced really well.

Even in the early game, simple copper mines belting copper to copper-shooting towers, or a copper mine with several turrets attached, adds such a satisfying feeling of accomplishment to base design that most TD games can't even come close to.  Then you start using more materials, refined materials, start adding power generation and consumption, and later into the game, liquid cooling.  It's also very cool that many towers can use multiple ammo types, giving them a boost or different effects.

The only itch it doesn't scratch that the other automation games does is exploration.  Though you technically explore a world by visiting many new proc-gen maps in the campaign, it doesn't give me a sense of exploration, just expansion.

The developer(s?) seem to be actively developing the game as well, you love to see that.  Big update in 2020 which redesigned the campaign into what it is now, and content updates in progress.

Also, you can play the full game free from their website.  I tried it out and decided to buy it on Steam.

Well, what do I say when it comes to Mindustry? There is so much.

First off, Campaign will certainly take a long time to finish, making it something worth playing for a long time.

Custom games where you can host servers to the rest of the network, or play by yourself by your own rules.

Multiplayer has an incredible community unlike any other, and the multiplayer experience is pretty hetfy in terms of the server bandwidth. You can either play games hosted by players, or servers, enabling you to play on any device and still play with others.

There is also mods. They either do a little or do a lot. Most may only be played with players who also have the mods that you do, while Multiplayer Supported mods can be used anywhere. For those who wonder how you make mods, there is a fully documented manual talking about the available types, variables, etc.

Not really into modding, and want to make it a guarentee of multiplayer use? Try the Logic Processor and many others inside the Logic category. With the way how Mindustry logic works, there isn't a single finite number for how many possible combinations you can make with one processor alone. Some mods even add more logic blocks, and even blocks that are used to boost processors.

Even when it was in it's classic phase, this game is unique and fun in a way that no other game is. It is super difficult to put into words how much I love Mindustry. It is:
-Both simple and complex: You don't have to be an engineer to play this game and have fun, but the super complex commands and schematics provide another way to get through and get more out of the game)
-Multiplayer: You can have fun with friends, do a solo campaign, or even play on online servers with lots of people.
-Campaign: Absolutely massive, with more being added in updates.
-Community: The Mindustry community is the nicest community of gamers (and programmers!) that I have ever encountered. (Ex: Most of the members of the Mindustry Discord server got on to voice chat one time. And everyone actually waited their turn to speak. That doesn't even happen on a server with 10 people.)
-Involvement: You can just enjoy the stuff the community makes, or you can make your own mods, maps, schematics, guides, and a bunch of other things with ease, using built-in support and the Github files. You don't even have to leave the game to download and make awesome content.
-Platforms: PC and mobile versions are available.

This game was a massive disappointment. The idea of a tower defense automation game is cool, but the game really messes it up. First off, the level-based design means you end up with a bunch of factories that you just leave behind, which sucks if you like seeing your factories grow. In addition, the tower defense part of the game is really weak. All you have to do is place a shitload of towers near the front (electric towers are best), place walls to funnel the enemies int a small area, add some healing towers, and you're basically set. This wouldn't matter as much if the factory part was good, but unfortunately it really sucks. The conveyor belts seem to connect their inputs and outputs for no good reason, turning logistics from a fun challenge to a fucking chore as you fiddle with the incredibly finnicky conveyor splitters, mergers, and bridges, as you set up 3 inputs on 1 factory. This could've easily been avoided by adding some sort of sorter arm, like in Factorio or DSP, but they didn't, so the game suffers a lot. Maybe I just needed to go farther, but by the time I had reached the first boss, I decided this game wasn't for me. Huge disappointment.

I bought this game ages back as it had multiplayer capability. Since then I haven't touched it until now.

Why am I reviewing now?

I am reviewing for the single player element at the moment, I can't remember the multiplayer bit but if I recall I couldn't set a password for the match back then. (no idea if you can still, would have to look).

If you ever wanted to play Factorio but do not agree with their "never put it on sale" stance like me, this is the game for you. It's basically the same type of game. It's not dead easy and I think the waves are a little too close together for a newer player who has to constantly rebuild for 10 waves or a player using a touchpad instead of a mouse (yes people do that apparently).

What can you do?

Join a bunch of buildings up together with conveyers using crazy methods to try and reach your "core". At the beginning when you are hardly gathering anything you don't realise but your core is tiny.... really tiny, I have just unlocked a large core which means up to 16 lanes of conveyers can enter at once (4 a side) and the logistics around distributing the junk you chuck in needs a lot of thought.

You can join buildings directly to their output so for example, a mining building can be connected directly to a turret, you wont get as many turrets or as strategically placed but you can make quick and dirty anti enemy placements along their route.

Do I recommend, YES. I wouldn't have picked the yes option otherwise!

Is it worth it when not on sale? Yes, unless your a cheapskate like me :D

A fun game that scratches the Factorio and Tower Defense itches at the same time! Easily worth it at full price if those are your jam.

One caveat: It was disappointing to discover that inter-map shipping was broken as of the last time I played. Often I'd set up advanced production lines in safe zones and try to order supplies to the fronline only to see advanced materials barely trickle through or never make it at all. Make sure to set up good blueprints, and try to rely on inter-map shipping as little as you can.

After some digging I'd _guess_ that this is related to "sending" off-screen maps updating at a slow pace or not at all. While this makes sense for performance reasons, it would be wonderful to see 100% safe off-screen maps simplify their updates down to steady-state production (given the infinite resources and safe zones' inability to be attacked), instead of what seems to be a deeper if infrequent simulation as of now.

Regardless, I still heartily recommend this game, and will return to it (again) in time.

So its time for me to finally review this game! ive spent a fair time playing it (My Steam hours are only a fraction, this game is FREE on itch.io if you really want to try it out but it doesnt have the awesome steam servers and the workshop. It is also available on IOS and Android). 

A lot of players compare this game to factorio, and the only comparison between the two in my opinion is that they both have factories and enemies. Nothing else is the same. Mindustry, in v6 added an entire planet for the campaign (Which the developer, Anuke, is working on! other things are more important but if you want to know more you should join the active mindustry discord!) which has tiles for you to capture. build up a base, have some tower defense action, and try to capture the planet! the multiplayer is really where its at, but its best to play through the campaign a little bit to really understand things. they come easily in this game and quickly, as opposed to factorio where you might spend hours before you make any real progress. i have bought this game for several of my friends, and i think 6$ is an absolute steal. again if you wanna give it a go, its free on itch.io. youll come buy it here eventually! :D <3

I really love this game it is so cool and I have been enjoying it since it was just first getting out there. My issue right now is that I HAVE to play this at work. The amount of lead and copper to move around at the start of the game is too much. After getting up and going it is not too bad but I wanted to checkout the planet a little only to find I had to leave my computer AFK for more than 30 mins to accumulate the first two and most basic materials in the game. In my opinion it feels too slow to start Maybe I think 1,500 would be a reasonable launch amount in reality there either needs to be attacks while you are at a secured zone or there needs to be a fast method of moving so the player doesn't feel like that are dragging through a pool of gravel. Immediately after that tough the game comes back alive and feels so fun to play.  The concept is solid, the game-play loop is active and engaging, the enemies are varying and I NEVER feel like there is one solution. For instance in Balloons tower defense eventually you find a build that works, or like factorio, after spiters you feel like you make the same FOB's and setups over and over. With this game I often am changing which weapons I am using where and what ammo, but not just "because i can" I HAVE to change ammo because of different needs and wants.

I don't think one should have a 1:1 comparison to Factorio, because the games go different directions. It is a different game, just some of the mechanics are similar.
Mindustry is a much lighter game, with much more focus on tower defense, less on the production. But the production has enough for a casual player to meddle with. Since the focus is tower defense, the goal is very clear. 

In the main campaign, you play different maps. So it doesn't necessarily suck up endless hours. Usually I can finish one map then get to sleep for my day job. (unlike factorio and dyson sphere program).

Also recommend to check out mods that add materials, maps and structures.

On the surface, it's a fun tower-defense, resource management and automation game. 
The building is enjoyable, being fundamentally simple but still allows for complex creations and contraptions when you put everything into place.
However, the problem arises within how enemies go about attacking your base.
Enemies will ALWAYS know the fastest, least-defended route to your base, even if it's their first encounter with it in your sector. On paper, such an idea sounds like it's a sensible thing to include in this game - but it leads to essentially wasting resources on the more defensive parts of your base due to enemies straight up ignoring them and choosing a different route, be it mid-wave or at the start of another.
This is also extremely frustrating; it doesn't feel all that enjoyable to put all this thought into the various parts and functions of your base in the hopes of making a base that can withstand heavy assaults while also being efficient at sucking up resources, and then seeing on the map that bombers just flew around the border of the game world to get to your Core. 
Sure - that just means that you need to plop down more defenses, but you can't really do that in early stages of a round because of extremely limited resources unless you draw from another base's stored resources - but even then, I feel like this'd defeat the point of expanding across a map if you need to constantly have rows upon rows of high-powered anti-air cannons and all-purpose turrets around your Core, because, outside of gaining more resources and protecting the sources of said resources, what purpose is there to place defenses in more spread-out portions of the map if there's a great chance the AI will just choose an obscure route towards your Core?
I think this issue could be fixed by giving the AI more goals/roles/etc. outside of "go towards the player(s) Core and shoot at it until it explodes" - perhaps only a certain number or percent of spawned enemies could be allowed to be on the direct offense, advancing towards your core, while others try to whittle away at the integrity of various parts of your base, be it by random selection or what the AI may see as especially threatening or hindering towards future progress.
The AI should also not be able to instantly find the most efficient path towards your Core directly after the start of the round - such information should be drip-fed to it as the game progresses, and should also be subject to change gradually. These changes could make combat/defense feel much more engaging, giving more purpose to the various emplacements you may make use of in base building as the AI may decide to try and weaken your defenses, as well as making the AI much more "intelligent" than "artificial".

I love factory games and mining games. I have a couple hundred hours in both Factorio and Satisfactory. I also enjoy tower defense games from time to time. I especially enjoyed the Defense Grid games. So I figured a mashup of these genres would be interesting. Unfortunately after roughly 10 hours or so of Mindustry, I got bored and it never really made me wanting more. Even with a huge tech tree to unlock, the gameplay felt a little too simplistic - especially the combat. Also, the gameplay has you basically starting all over again every hour or so in a new (and small) map/sector, and you're starting all over building a whole new small factory and defenses. The one upside is that every few sectors or so, you should be able to build more involved factories than the last as you unlock your tech tree research. But honestly, this approach of having to start all over with another factory on another map every hour or so is much more tedious to me than it is fun. I'd be more interested in building and growing a single factory into something huge, on a huge map (like factorio and satisfactory), and then throw in a greater emphasis on weapons, combat, and tower defense to differentiate it from those two games.

Love/hate this game. The 7 hours a day minimum we spent together when I first found this game was like a honeymoon phase. The constant attacks on already captured territory, the impossible maps with extremely limited water, and trying to code your AI; these are the settle-in phases of the relationship. 

Is this game worth buying even if not on sale? YES! You've spent more money on any meal you've ever eaten than this game. Just buy it and stop throwing your 60$ at pre-purchase "AAA" titles that are swarmed with hackers.

Would I have bought this game if it were more expensive? maybe not. 
Do these types of things typically lead to a bunch of paid DLC so the game lures you in then nails you with expensive expansions? oh sure.
Currently however, there's no DLC. You get 100% of the game for 6$ and that's an easy buy all day. 

Has never crashed on me. I swear some of the junctions/routers glitch out and mix their lines but, I also may not understand it well enough.

The logic and programming system your units is completely impossible unless you're a professional programmer. It's horrible and requires a lot of learning/testing to figure out. Your customers are not all professional coders. Personally it's the biggest flaw the game has. I love the idea of being able to give units complex orders and purposes but, w/e the duck is going on with the current system needs serious change.

That being said, I've made it almost to the end of the research tree without ever programming a single unit. Will I be able to continue deeper into the game without copying some youtube video line for line? who knows.

*Edit: The constant attacks on your territory are actually an interesting mechanic. Attacks can be defended without you actually going to the zone if your base is strong enough (by some calculation I won't even guess at). However, whether you show up or not the attack waves are cumulative. For example: you may have taken the area initially by surviving a match that started on wave 1/50 but, on the first attack after capturing the territory you'll start at wave 51/60. After successfully defending 4 attacks you'll be at wave 91/100 when starting the 5th attack. 

The difficulty increases tremendously in higher waves and you're compelled to continue developing the strength of every base. If/when the territory is lost you go back to starting at wave 1/50 when capturing the territory again.

Also, attacks only occur on territories adjacent to a territory which is occupied by an enemy base. Priorities, yo.

So this guy (game is developed by a single person) goes out and decides to make an Indie Game, but fails to follow any of the rules of releasing an Indie Game on Steam. Let's go through some specific examples:

1) Who the hell releases a polished, fairly bug-free game? Indie games are on Steam are meant to be borderline unoptimized and unplayable.

2) It has way too many features. Indie Games are supposed to be husks of a game built on mostly empty promises that may or may not get fulfilled 2 years later when the dev decides to abandon the project.

3) AND THEN the Dev has the audacity to charge $6 for a fulfilling experience? The Dev should be charging AT LEAST $50 for his base early-access game and dividing up the base game content into 4 different expansion packs for their early access game. 

4) Made his game open source? How the hell can you hide a bitcoin miner in your game code if everyone can see it? 

Absolutely Disgusting.

Imagine a simplified version of Factorio that is also a tower defense game. 

Game involves mining resources, building factories, towers, support structures, and units to either defend from waves of enemies or attack an enemy base. Each area presents different challenges with regards to available space and accessible resources. 

There is a campaign that revolves around securing zones on a planet and capturing various enemy bases while researching new units, resources, and buildings. There are also custom games to play with or again other players or bots.

Very fun game if you enjoy resource management, tower defense, or puzzle games.
The game supports up to 16 player multiplayer and has very good support for community content (schematics, custom maps, etc.) Definitely worth a try if you're into this kind of game.

Look in theory this game rules and I spent a lot of time with it in earlier versions, but the way the game was changed in version 6 made it much worse to play. The difficulty is insane and chaotic, the game explains nothing and gives you no warning of what you can expect on a certain wave. Even the first "attack" map is very tricky to get through while some of the defend maps are really easy. The planet sector system is very annoying and repetitive and I much preferred the older level based system.

The biggest problem though is that the game now has logic gates and microprocessors. I'm into Dwarf Fortress so it's not like I can't deal with a complicated game, but the microprocessors basically require you to program the behavior of your units in command lines. This isn't optional either, without programming your units they will just attack mindlessly and ignore enemy defenses. I'm not a programmer and the way the game worked before was fine, so I don't get why this was added in as a mandatory thing. It's extremely tedious and the game doesn't pause either while you program the processors or give you time to learn. Halfway through the game it's just like, guess what, you're a robot programmer now and forget about all the fun conveyor belt TD stuff. I hope it'll be improved eventually but for now I'm bummed out by the direction the game took.

This was a very hard review to write, because I'm answering the prompt instead of going with my gut. I like this game. I enjoy it. But it has some of the most finicky, exacting, and opaque systems I have ever seen in a logistics or tower-defense game, and it is absolutely unforgiving of any player who does not immediately understand these systems implicitly. I have had to nuke my entire Campaign save so many times because it is so easy to write oneself into a corner and so hard to get out of it. An option to wipe/restart a sector would solve this issue entirely, but the devs seem resistant so such an option for reasons that I can only describe as Artistic.

Wave difficulty is terribly unbalanced, to the point where a defense that holds for an hour of gameplay (there is no way to Fast-Forward like in most Tower Defense games) yields 29 waves that are easily dispatched, and a 30th that undoes an hour of work. You respawn in the ruins of your last creation, so if your last creation was built on flawed assumptions, you have no choice but to spend an entire run tearing down your previous buildings before you can start fresh.

I like that, to a degree. It frustrates me intensely, but I have a lot of time to kill and a lot of desire to optimize. I do not expect that level of masochistic patience of any other, but there is a very particular segment of the gaming population to which I can recommend it wholeheartedly.

The game mechanics are great, the building and everything (apart from bridges, those are nightmare inducing, why do they act like routers? hate that), it's fun and all, but there are two problems that basically ruin the whole game. The Planet sectors. Capturing sectors is fine, even though there are too many and it takes a long time to capture one since you always basically start from zero but with resources available. And the guardian waves. The normal waves tend to be either really easy or really hard as the enemy immediately starts dishing out T3+ drones at you in the first wave, as you don't even have time to build the defenses. So the game goes like - Jump in - pause - dish out every schematic for every material on the map and run it to the base, schematics for defenses etc, (this can take like 15 mins) unpause and watch your ship build it all, only to get rekt by 10 spider drones that just walk over your defenses directly to your base and set it ablaze. Or if it's easy, watch 49 waves of meaningless enemies die to your uber defenses in mere seconds, and then watch your whole work die to wave 50 because some random ass boss decides that he has bigger range than most of your defense turrets, sits on the edge and snipes his heart out. Or a Boss that ignores everything and rushes to the core from different side where you have no chance of defending. 49 waves of nothing only to get destroyed by the last wave's boss(or several).

The worst thing though is, when you capture a sector, it can easily get under attack and in matter of seconds gets destroyed and lost, ruining everything as you have to capture it again (yes, seconds). Great, now imagine you have like 20 sectors captured and 5 of them go under attack at once. Somehow your defenses can't hold on their own (I am suspicious that drones actually don't even work while you are not there, it seems like the structers just get damaged and destroyed no matter what you have there, even if you have it filled with repair drones and structures). So you have to keep jumping between all the 5 + 1(sector you are currently working on) every few seconds and reset the damages or you lose them all. Awesome, so much fun. You jump in, see there is literally no damage but it said the sector was like 50% damaged. Or you jump in, only to see that for some reason your whole defense is gone, your builder/repair drones sit idle at your base and start working only after you arrive there. Then you sit and watch as your defenses destroy everything without any issue. But if you were not there, it would get miraculously lost for whatever reason. 

Yeah, nope, that whole mechanic is garbage honestly. You either have to focus on a single sector cluster (is it even possible without progressing the tech tree which you can do so only by completing different clusters?) or get destroyed by this dumb mechanic. Unless they address this issue I can't recommend it since all the progress is basically meaningless.
