A strong automation building game that does a lot of things right.

I would consider this a Factorio Lite, it has all the same things with base buildings, enemies that attack you(in this case in pre-warned intervals), resource nodes that need to be exploited as well as miles and miles of conveyor belt spaghetti to try and sort out.

But it also has its own things, the whole world works like a kind of sandbox segmented into nodes, where you have to attack and capture nodes, while there's an antagonistic AI that attacks your nodes with regular intervals which means you have to defend them, and then to help you out you have a tech tree that stays throughout the entire campaign.

a little hard to get into but once you understand basic stuff, its an awesome game, i cant stop thinking about it even when not playing, all the ways you can beat enemies, build your industry. BUY IT. 9/10 from me.

Fantastic game with an astounding scope. Despite how kitchen sink the experience feels in terms of arbitrary features and complexity added in, it is somehow still well-tuned. One of the most notable differences between this and other similar base/factory building games is that I wouldn't consider it a sandbox *nor* a puzzle game; rather, I think of Mindustry as a real time strategy.

The singleplayer campaign is perfectly adequate and can produce quite a bit of enjoyment, although it is a touch on the "too easy" side. So far as I've presently seen, I have not been impressed by the multiplayer, although there is definitely a lot of potential in this regard and the community has worked diligently to host a variety of serves with interesting plugins and game-modes. I feel the game would strongly benefit from centralized multiplayer servers, gamemodes, and matchmaking.

One particularly notable thing I like about Mindustry is that it is open source. While I am not particularly keen to work in Java, it is nevertheless exciting to see high quality open source software on the market.

Mindustry is an excellent first impression. As you conquer areas and try to defend them. 
But it's so repetitive that after maybe 4 days of it, it was enough. Tons of the first levels don't have coal. So you can't build any advance tech. You can't defend them properly. You can't auto-repair them. 

Because of that, you end up coming back again and again in old captured regions to repair them. And eventually redo them because they've been captured and totally destroyed. 

Fun ? Sure. Boring ? F**k yeah. There are RTS games you can play for 15 years. And those you play for ... 4 days. Then abandon forever.

This game satisfies the factory efficiency-builder and tower-defense genres. There are few games that combines these two elements so well.

Mindustry addresses a few problems with factory builders - where other builders are normally open-ended (or the only goal is to obtain X number of material over time), Mindustry instead requires you to survive waves or destroy enemy bases using your factories. With the recent 6.0 update to the campaign and overworld, your successes in each map even carries over to other maps. You feel that continuous success as you finish each wave or map.

Gameplay is deceptively deep. It seems straightforward at first (gather resource, move resource using belts, send to factories to create new resources, etc). Then you discover space-efficient layouts that can min-max different factories, turrets, mining, etc. Then you dig deep into different production/gather rates for each factory. Then you discover logic circuits that use a kind of programming language to automate and better control your factories. Or even display memes.

Mindustry also has tons of great features, including quality-of-life! It has multiplayer with massive maps with lots of collaborative fun. It has easy-to-use schematics that saves your efficient set-ups, and even allows you to import schematics other players have built (simply as a string of text!). Tons of rebindable keyboard shortcuts that lets you navigate menus quickly and raises the skill ceiling. Custom maps and editors allow you to make levels for you, friends, and strangers. Play through a whole variety of maps from the Steam Workshop!

The only problem is Mindustry does not have a great tutorial, and portions of the campaign world's mechanics (especially resources and their use, inventory, transfer between maps, etc) are not really explained or displayed in an intuitive manner. Otherwise, it's great.

$6 is a steal right now!

In a nutshell: Factorio Lite

It's the same kind of gameplay: resource collection and management, optimisation and automation. It also has some rts and tower defense elements mixed in as well. Still addicting, but it's a much smaller game that won't consume your entire life (hopefully) And for the low price point, it's worth picking up

-Visual style is unique, consistent, and pleasing to the eyes
-Controls are easy to learn
-Building is intuitive and also easy to learn. conveyors automatically link up, and most buildings are omni-directional, and inputs/ouputs are universal.
-Campaign gradually introduces you to new blocks and items as you learn the game
-Smooth fully-featured multiplayer

For the low price-point, I recommend picking this up if you like this kind of resource-management game

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

This game is SO addictive and fun! Considering I've gotten over 70 hours of playtime out of it, and I bought it for $6, it feels like a steal. And even as I write this, I'm tempted to start up a new campaign. If you love games like Factorio, with more of a focus on tower defense, you will probably love this. Don't let the minimalist graphics turn you away - there is a deep game under those simple graphics.

Also, multiplayer runs really well and stays synced. 90% of my game time has been in multiplayer with friends. The only things I would say I don't care for are the sandstorms (you can turn the particle effect off, but the wind still blows you around) and the fact that in multiplayer you can't see the global map or tech tree. Only the host can see those things, so everyone else is kind of left out of the loop.

All in all, though, a fantastic game for the price. Probably one of the best values I've ever gotten in gaming.

You don't build as big as Factorio or Satisfactory, but it's great for that quick building fix. Compared to the other two titles, resources and map space is limited - not by *too* much, but enough to induce some creativity on how to maximize resource extraction and how to best use what you get - and sometimes make decisions on if you want to use it for one thing or another.

The negatives, then:
- Among the factory building genre, it has the most toxic community I've seen by far.
- Past a certain point, it's less about defending and a lot more about leading armies/attacking. I don't think the game does this well, and it should have stuck to its basebuilding+crafting+tower defense core. I stopped playing when this became too common and obnoxious for me.

If you like Factorio, this game is probably for you. There are tons of research technologies which change how you set up your infrastructure, and the enemies are dynamic enough to keep you on your toes. I recommend pausing often until you've built up good defenses.

This is a very interesting take on the Strategy builder/ tower Defence genre.

If  you like games like Risk, Bloons, Civilization, Creeperworld, Kingdom Rush, Gemcraft etc you will love this game.
It combines tower defence with some basic rescource gathering and a Tech Tree to prolong the gaming. The solo campaign is fun and long enough to keep you interested. I haven't tried the Multi player.

It is an interesting balance of escalating power and resource gathering vs Tech tree advances. As the tech tree requires resources that you collect on the maps as you are defending.  Certain tech tree developments then allow you to progress thru the solo campaign map progression.

Farming resources in earlier maps will allow you to  progress faster. Progressing the tech tree will also open up farming opportunities on earlier/ previous maps as the map designs have been  made to  facilitate that if you are a mico-manageer. :)

Protect your sides as flyer enemies will sometimes bypass your defences.... Area affect weapons are a must with faster firing/ constant fire for mop up.... ;)

Criminally underpriced for how good it is. It's equal parts automation game and old-school tower defence. Maps are small and enemies are finite, so while your base may grow and branch to make the most of the area, it will never grow so big that you're completely overwhelmed by the scale of it, and you won't find yourself decimated by some unstoppable enemy force.

Much of the complexity and challenge in this game comes from your ability to plan and reason about the space, and not so much from any of the mechanics being particularly difficult or technical or requiring so many layers of automation that it's unwieldy. There's a satisfying finesse to fitting your factory together in those cramped, confined spaces, winding and weaving conveyors and pipes and power around your machines, over walls and through lakes, to get everything running at peak efficiency, all while dumpstering so much ammo into your bullet wall of a defence that your base is both indestructible and unreasonably productive.

Have you ever really wanted to start a war economy? Do you want an intricate logic system that allows you to do things that would blow your mind? Do you want to learn how to spaghetti better than my Italian Grandma? Play Mindustry. The true fun comes from the basic setup and thew progression you feel after ever battle. The game gets hard at times, and takes some time to learn the intricacies and quirks of resource flow, but it is extremely rewarding once you do. Also Multiplayer is great. Buy it here, buy it on your phone, sync the two. This game truly feels like I am connecting my devices. Also it's very easy to mod, and there are some great mods out there. Buy it.

It is an attractive game for those 'industrialists' but I do feel some poor-designed features were added into the game when it went out of early-access. I consider these features may help to provide a better experience of gameplay:
1. Player may choose to 'save', 'load' or 'restart' one level whenever he choose to. Upon the current version of the game one can only wait for the enemies to destroy his base in order to restart one level, only to find the initial state of the map has been changed, leaving some waste of the previous try there, to be removed. That is tiresome.
2. The boss seems way too stronger than the previous waves, and such difference may lead to a sudden death just at the final wave, which can be frustrating. This is also why I strongly suggest to introduce a saving system. Maybe there can be a more smooth difficulty curve for the enemies.
3. It is absurd that, although I can gather the resources together in the researching panel, I have to launch from just one base to another region, meaning that I can only take the resources from that very region, instead of all collectively from all occupied regions. This lead to tedious work indeed. 
I regard Mindustry as one of my favourite 'tower defence' game and I do hope that it can be improved to offer a better experience for all!

I love this game!

If you like Factorio's Wave Defense system, then how about a whole campaign built around it? Researching as you progress through stages, the ability to take on optional stages just for fun as well as the ability to play custom made stages as well. 

Create factories, survive the waves of enemies, expand your influence over the planet, research powerful new tech, create armies of units and control them squad style. 

I should also mention that there's multiplayer. Build a base, send waves of units to attack your foes and destroy the enemy's base core while defending your own.

All in all this game is fantastic and it's gameplay becomes even more vibrant with the inclusion of the steam workshop's machine blueprints and maps as well as the addition of the mods.

I haven't finished the campaign yet, but even if you just do the mandatory levels its pretty fun.
Even if you lose a level, some of your old base is still there for you to repair. So your progress doesn't go to waste.

Re-review: It's a good game, lots of things to learn that the game doesn't explicitly teach you.  Blueprints are amazing and take a lot of the repetitive monotony out of the game.  Once you learn (or master) a setup you like, you can copy and recall it anytime.  This leaves you with plenty of time to actually play and enjoy the game.  The only downside was something involving logic gates and the FPS your game was running at, I don't know if this is still an issue.  Well worth the price, I'd liken this game to Creeper World in style if not substance.

The german Review is below.

The game is great, but has very serious problems:

1) The User interface: The game has no tooltips. This is fatal for the game flow.

a) If you want to produce a unit in a factory and the mouse is over the icons of the units, the unit name is *not* displayed when you move the mouse. Which icon is the unit ou need?? Can it attack ground and/or air units? You have to leave the game and ask google for the answer. :-(

b) If you have found the needed Unit and you want to produce it, the factory does not show which of the 20 different resources you have to supply to the factory to produce the unit. Solution? You have to leave the game and ask google for the answer. :-(

c) The game shows all the icons and their stock of resources you already have. But: If the mouse is over a resource icon, the resource name is *not* shown as hint text. So the answer, which resource is low, is again *not* given by the game, but you have to find out somehow, which icon is which unit.

c) If you are with the mouse over one of the many buildings to produce it, no hint is shown what this building does and which resources it needs for its work. Again, you have to interrupt the flow of the game and click three times: 1. click on the building you might be looking for. 2. click on the help. 3. close the help at the end.

So you have to constantly research outside the game what resources and units you are working with.



2) Balancing 

It happens all the time that the opponent attacks an already conquered sector and if you want to defend it, then after 3 hours of fighting the opponent unpacks the extremely much stronger units and defeats you within 30 seconds: Although your own units have the maximum available strength of the just available and weak tier 1, the opponent destroys your own 150 units and towers with 1 or 2 units.

The only strategy that could help here would be to defeat the opponent in the first 30 minutes. However, with tier 1 units this is impossible because the enemy's base destroys these units in a split second.

If the game either corrects the balancing or warns the user about such battles because the probability of success is 0%, then the game is great.

So: watch again in early 2022! :-) 




Das Spiel ist toll, hat aber ganz grobe Probleme:

1) Benutzerinterface: Das Spiel hat keine Tooltipps. Das ist fatal für den Spielfluss.
a) Will man eine Einheit produzieren, zeigt die Factory nicht an, welche der 20 verschiedenen Ressourcen man der Factory zuführen muss, um die Einheit zu produzieren. Lösung? Man muss das Spiel verlassen und google nach der Antwort fragen. :-(

b) Will man in einer Factory eine Einheit produzieren und die Maus ist über dem Icon einer Einheit, wird der Einheitenname bei der Maus *nicht* angezeigt. Welches Icon ist welche Einheit?? Man muss das Spiel verlassen und google nach der Antwort fragen. :-(

c) Das Spiel zeigt an, wie viel man von welcher Ressource hat. Ist die Maus über einer Ressource, wird der Name *nicht* als Hinweistext angezeigt. Die Antwort, welche Ressource knapp ist, gibt also wider *nicht* das Spiel, sondern man muss irgendwie herausfinden, welches Icon welche Einheit ist.

c) Ist man mit der Maus über einem der vielen Gebäuden um es zu produzieren, wird keinerlei Hinweis angezeigt, was dieses Gebäude tut und welche Ressourcen es für seine Arbeit benötigt. Wieder muss man den Spielfluss unterbrechen und drei mal Klicken: 1. Das vielleicht gesuchte Gebäude anklicken. 2. Die Hilfe anklicken. 3. Am Ende die Hilfe wieder schliessen.

Man muss also andauernd ausserhalb des Spiels recherchieren, mit welchen Ressourcen und Einheiten man arbeitet.



2) Balancing

Es passiert dauernd, dass der Gegner einen bereits eroberten Sektor angreift und wenn man ihn verteidigen will, dann packt der Gegner nach 3 Stunden Kampf die extrem viel stärkeren Einheiten aus und besiegt einen innert 30 Sekunden: Obwohl die eigenen Einheiten die maximal verfügbare Stärke der halt erst verfügbaren, schwachen Stufe 1 (Tier 1) haben, vernichtet der Gegner mit 1 oder 2 Einheiten die eigenen 150 Einheiten und Türme.

Die einzige Strategie, die hier helfen könnte, wäre den Gegner in den ersten 30 Minuten zu besiegen. Mit Stufe 1 (Tier 1) Einheiten ist das aber unmöglich, weil die Basis des Gegners diese Einheiten in Sekundenbruchteilen zerstört.

Wenn das Spiel entweder das Balancing korrigiert oder den User vor solchen Schlachten warnt, weil die Erfolgswahrscheinlichkeit 0% ist, dann ist das Spiel toll.

Also: Anfang 2022 wieder anschauen! :-)

A good game despite some serious shortcomings. 

Having played Factorio a lot, I was hoping for Mindustry to deliver a similar experience. It fulfilled my hopes only partially. Let's start with the good things. 

The crafting system is nice and fairly complex without being overwhelming. There is a fair amount of variety. New belts aren't just faster, but work according to different mechanics. Buildings can be boosted with liquids and some methods of generating energy have their own mechanics as well, including a reactor that blows up if at some point it stops getting the cooling. The techs keep the game fresh and interesting thorough the entire playthrough. 

Building defences and defeating waves of enemies is satisfying. The visuals are a bit simple and dry, but functional and clear, and that's the important part. I really like the sounds of the turrets, they way they shoot and kill enemies is quite satisfying. 

But, sadly Mindustry is far from perfect. 

For starters, every time you try conquering a new sector you have to build your infrastructure from scratch. Resources generated in previously acquired sectors can only be used for research, but that's about it. You can take some resources with you from the old sector, but they'll run out very quickly. So effectively you end up setting up the same production chains over and over every 2 or 3 hours. It can get tedious and resulted in me just conquering mostly only the sectors required to move the campaign forward. 

The game doesn't have a proper sandbox mode. There's a freeplay, but the maps in this mode are fairly small. Forget about procedurally generated maps, or even levels that are very big. 

And that's the problem with the campaign. A lot of the maps in the campaign don't give you that much space. This is especially prevalent on maps where you attack, as the enemy base takes up most of the map usually. It's like the core mechanics are there, they are good, but the devs don't give you the maps to use these mechanics. Having to struggle with really limited space on attack maps can get frustrating. 

Speaking of attack maps. A base building game about tower defence that has attack maps. Not a good idea. Attack maps usually just mean you've got very limited space, and your tactic boils down to just sending wave after wave or units, hoping the AI picks the best route. It gets even worse when the AI base rebuilds itself. The attack maps just don't seem to fit into the game and feel like they were added to it as a hindsight. 

Difficulty is a problem as well, there are plenty of maps that are so easy it's laughable, and others where you can manage alright, but then the game spawns a Toxopid guardian and the last 1 or 2 hours of gameplay just go down the drain. 

I do like the learning curve of the game, but there are some things that I was unable to understand without using an outside Wiki or forums. And I still don't exactly know how launch pads work, despite having almost finished the main campaign, for instance.

Overall - a good, solid game, although I feel slightly let down by poor map selection and a mediocre, a bit tedious campaign. Would really love to see it with bigger maps and maybe a more accessible interface.

Fantastically absorbing. I played the free version on Anuke's Itch page and immediately knew I would have to buy it on steam to support the developer.

This is an engrossing factory/automation/strategy game centered around building increasingly complex factories and supply lines to conquer both handmade and procedurally generated areas. The core game loop involves building a base in a new area and supplying it with resources while also feeding those resources to turrets on the frontline to fend off waves of enemies, or to factories for building troops of your own.

As you play, you'll unlock new machines, resources, units, sectors, etc. But you'll also learn to optimize what you already have, designing your own custom schematics to abstract away a lot of the processes in the early game. You'll even get ways to ship resources between sectors, allowing you to create huge distribution networks to make sure every region has what it needs.

Maps vary between tower-defense style sectors where you have to hold your position against increasing waves of enemies, and base sectors, where you have to build units of your own to take down an enemy base. It's a clever twist on the typical tower-defense formula, rewarding you for understanding each unit and tower's strengths and weaknesses. There are tons of sectors to try out with varying sizes, difficulties, and resources, so you can really take the game at your own pace.

Overall, Mindustry exemplifies the best this niche genre has to offer, and with a free version available to download, there's no reason not to give it a try.

Admittedly, I've only played a few hours of Mindustry, but it's a cracking [strike]little[/strike] game.  Despite some misleading comparisons, the game play is very different from Factorio, being tower-defence at heart, but it still taps into the addictive nature of creating a supply chain then optimising it as you develop more complex materials.

To me, the biggest difference to Factorio is that, in Factorio, you can spend 100's of hours designing, building, and improving your factory and once you've got a well-defended core, you're pretty-much invulnerable and can expand as fast or slow as you desire.  With Mindustry, each level is self-contained but feeds resources into your plant-wide domination, allowing you to field bigger and better forces earlier in each level than you would otherwise be able to.  But equally so, as with all tower-defence games, if you leave a hole in your defence, you will get brutally punished!  Expect to get ROFLstomped several times as you progress through the game, when you take on enemies that outclass your current tech level, or when they field units you've not build defences against and they trash your base in mere seconds after you spent several hours carefully building and tweaking it...  And there are a [i]lot[/i] of levels to complete, all with their own challenges.

If you like tower defence games or strategy games, this [strike]little[/strike] gem is an absolute must.  If you're on the fence, it's cheap enough to buy to see if you like it or not.

I bought this game after putting hundreds of hours into Factorio. Mindustry was only a few dollars, so I did not expect much, but it has nonetheless become one of my favorite games. The graphics are meant to convey information, not to be beautiful or cutting edge; at first that turned me off but it didn't take long before I did not notice because I was so engrossed in the gameplay.

I play the game generally in campaign co-op mode with one other person (which means no pauses or going back to old saves). I find the difficulty level to be perfect--often we get wrecked the first time trying a more advanced enemy sector, but then figure out some new strategies and win. There's always something to work on, so there's no "down time" while playing. 

In terms of complexity, Factorio is clearly more complex in terms of factory design, especially with add-ons. Mindustry is simpler, but there's a whole tactical element that keeps gameplay interesting. There's still optimization and logistics to figure out in Mindustry, however; it's not quite as in-depth as Factorio.

A bit weird, minimalist in some ways and complicated in others. A mix of factory building, wave/tower defense, and RTS. A fun and unique take on these styles.

For the price, it scratches a good itch for Factorio for a while.  However, it's not really well polished for single player PvE.  Most of the YouTube and other resources I've seen are primarily from the PvP players or the high end techniques.  

A lot of the little polishing things, like knowing the types of creeps that are coming (that's just play and learn, no pop-ups/howtos), how much hp's the creeps have (oh, they get shields now?), having to learn that the little blue square with bare slash in it is Graphite to the factory expectations instead of the almost blue grey circle with a slash (which is Silicon).

Then there's Fungal Pass (v6), which takes the game, turn it on its side, and makes it into a Zerg Rush through the side door.  You have no idea it's a complete change of gameplay and the waves start coming like a Typhoon while you're trying to wrap your head around it.  The only way to restart a level is to basically blow up all your defenses, and let them run you over, then you can try again.

Again, for the price...  It's free if you want to go get the download, it's cheap to support the guy who's trying to make this more accessible to the rest of us.  However, know what you're in for.  I've got my money's worth but I'll wait now for a few updates and see if there's a lot more polish in store.

Update Version 6.0 and beyond: 

Woooo! This is the $|-|iT! 

Why? Simple. Logic!

Imagine a future where RTS games are played by programmers. It's no longer a cheat to have a bot play for you, it's a feature! I want to see this game played as a professional intellectual sport. Way better than chess. All the dynamics of poker included. This is actual war! 

Of course, that is my prediction of the future. For now, this game is simple by comparison to that dream. Now is your chanced to get in at the beginning, before Mindustry blows up bigger than Minecraft.

That is my honest opinion. No one paid me to say it.

You'd think that a game looking like slightly gimmicky tower defense with pixel graphics at first glace wouldn't have that much to offer. Having played numerous such titles, I figured something for 5€ probably wouldn't have that many features, but hey... might be fun, right?

45 hours and and a week worth of failed sleep later, i can only say that at 5€ i feel like I robbed the developer blind.

Sure, the basic premise might be fairly simple: mine resources to both build and feed towers to fend off attackers. You start with a small base and simple mining machines you place on the map, dragging out conveyors to both towers and the base itself to fund additional towers and miners, and so on. Mine enough resources and you can unlock new techs giving you better miners, faster conveyors, different towers, etc, to build. New resources to both make yourself and mine on the map keep the progression going, and every new map feels different enough to warrant going further.

However, once you start to unlock a few more techs and gotten some hours in you suddenly find yourself fiddling with a conveyor to juuust make it fit in where you want it, look up and realize its 4AM in the morning. The game has so much potential for tweaking details, optimizing the layouts and coming up with the perfect strategy. With the threat of enemy attacks a persistant issue, you always have a goal to strive towards. There is never a lack of purpose in this game.
The campaign is excellently paced, too, with unlocks always being interesting and worthy to pick up as you go; there are very few "dead" unlocks, they're all useful in their own way.
There's also a whole system for programming included, allowing the savvy gamer to directly control what buildings and units do and when they do it. It's completely optional, no level requires you to use it, and you pretty much _need_ some programming experience to understand it, though (BASIC is enough). You could also get by with a lot of patience as well as youtube videos to instruct you, but without prior knowledge of how programming is structured, you'll likely struggle (or just give up and download an already written script). I feel like i barely scratched the surface of this aspect of the game, but still managed to program my units to restock the front lines and buildings to send different resources across production lines with only a single belt. There is great satisfaction to be had in witnessing a correctly written program come to life as you expected it to (and great frustration when it fails).
A robust blueprint system makes sure that all your designs, programmed or not, can be instantly saved and re-used later with a couple of clicks, and seeing your blueprint collection grow over time is immensly satisfying, serving as an additional reminder of how far you've come compared to when you started.

All in all, Mindustry is a complete steal at 5€. The game could cost 4x as much and it'd still be cheap compared to what you get. Recommended to people who like Tower Defense and Factory games. If that's not your cup of tea, then you won't enjoy this, but if it is...

Well.. 

I advice you set an alarm so you know when to go sleep.

Mindustry is a hectic, but pausable, assembly-line builder mixed with tower defense. Assigned to take over the planet and reclaim it from the various robotic minions that will send periodic attack waves, and even boss guardians against you, you have the ability to build assembly lines, mine resources, refine resources, and use those resources to build more structures, turrets to defend yourselves, and expand your network until you defeat the enemy waves. 

Your "avatar" in the game is a flyer (later can be exchanged for a more powerful model) that can build structures in moments (often, less than a second) as well as having weapons to shoot back, but your shields are low and your craft is delicate, so don't take hits. Use PAUSE liberally to study the terrain and figure out your approach before committing to something. 

You start with a hub, which starts small, but as you progress through the "campaign" which sends you to various spots around the planet, you will gain access to more powerful hubs. EVERYTHING sent to the hub is put into storage up to the max limit for each type of resource, and they can be used for research (and unlock more items on the tech tree), or for constructing new units and/or structures. 

Your job basically is to build drills to mine existing resources, and ship them back to the hub using conveyor belts. But there are many alternate conveyor bits to help with efficiency... Like "router" and "distributor" can help you spread your input onto multiple paths. Router can divide one input into up to 3 separate paths, while distributor can go up to 7 different paths. There are overflow and underflow gates that let you control how much to send down one path. There is a sorter that let you separate different types of input from the same line. By the 4th sector you would have unlocked logic gates, micro processors, and switches that lets you create more detailed controls, as well as robotic minion units that you can give simple orders to, and there are WELL OVER 100 units and structures in the game! 

The drills start out simple, drill, and send back. But you may need to divert some to act as ammo for your turrets. And what's even more interesting... most turrets can do more damage or get greater range or other bonuses if you send it different material for ammo. However, the more advanced materials must themselves be synthesized / processed. For example, you can mine sand, but you'll need sand and coal to make "silicon". Use coal, sand, and lead to make "hyperglass". The more complicated synthesizers will need power, so you have to create a power distribution network by tapping some of your coal supply for combustion generators, then  distribute the power using "power nodes" (think "relay towers"). 

Sounds complicated? Now do it under fire. That's right, each have have waves of enemies coming at you. you start with dumb kamikazes that just blows up when it his one of your structures. But later ones have weapons. You do have turrets, but some are anti-ground (surface) only, while others are dual purpose, and some may be anti-air only. And they obviously need different ammo. 

The main objective is for you to survive ALL enemy waves, without losing your hub. The hostiles go after your hub. You can build walls to protect your structures,  but they will explore your perimeter and find the "thinnest" spot to attack. You can take advantage of this by building defenses along their path, and/or weapons covering their spawn zones. to hit them as they appear and move down toward your territory. 

Oh, and your avatar flying unit has weapons too. But it's mainly designed to construct, not to fight. 

As you go further and further from your hub, your conveyor line gets more complex. And as each processing structure require more and more inputs, and some may require multi-stage assembly, it is up to you to fit your conveyor lines together efficiently. 

Oh, when I say conveyor, I guess I implied solids. But later, you will also extract liquids, which are needed for some of the more advanced constructions and enhancements. Many structures enjoy higher productivity if supplies with water and/or cryoliquid (super coolant), for example. Technically those are not conveyors, but conduits, but same idea. 

A lot of conveyors can criss-cross, and the game will automatically put in "junction" so they can cross each other safely. But there are also bridge nodes that lets you go OVER existing structures of terrains, and other more advanced conveyor bits, such as overflow gates and underflow gates. 

What don't I like about the game? The lack of automatic pathing. You have to adjust the "heading" of the conveyor belt by using the mouse button. Somehow the game doesn't really want to figure this out for you just by dragging direction. There is also no "purge conveyor" that simply empty whatever it was carrying. You have to erase the conveyor and rebuild it. Also, if you build a conveyor next to a structure, it automatically assumes you want to connect it, even though that is not always the case, and the only way to make sure this doesn't happen is leave a GAP between your conveyor and the structure. Some of the maps are REALLY constricting as there is VERY limited path leading back to your own area. It's also not very clear which structures need what and you need to go look for the info in the "-pedia" reference, which contains everything, even though half of the things it referenced you don't have yet (like ability to use advanced materials for ammo, or ability to tap fluids for improved performance).  There is also no tutorial that I can find. The game also had undergone HEAVY revisions (this is V6, with many UI changes since V1) 

So do I recommend it? Yes, as it's different. But be prepared to be frustrated, and try a sector multiple times (and see wreckage of your previous attempt)

I very rarely feel compelled to leave a review, but Mindustry is not only with the $6, it's worth every minute I've spent playing it. It scratches the very specific itch combination of tower defense and automation that my weird brain craves. 

My 540 hours is probably more like 400 and idle time, but I've only recently started playing with the logic stuff. If you don't care about logic and programming, you can totally ignore that part. Mindustry can be as simple or as complex as you want it to be. 

This is the only game I've ever played for hours on my computer then grabbed my tablet and played for another hour or two before bed. The community is also helpful, there are folks making amazing guides, spreadsheets, and documentation. 

I can't recommend this game enough. It's replaced Rimworld as my "If you couldn't only play one game for the rest of your life" game.

Mindustry is a delightful combination of building game and tower defense. It's particularly enjoyable as a co-op experience.

Addictive, challenging, and scratches three itches: engineering, tower defense, and resource scouting.

The learning curve is directly related to some of the elements that aren't intuitive - e.g. mine coal and direct that to a specific factory to make graphite, which is used to make certain other things... The game doesn't hold your hand, but doesn't abandoned you either; you just need to tinker, read a bit, and figure it out. While this can be frustrating at first, you're gifted deeper complexity, which changes your designs short and long-term...

Ultimately, the rewards come from fending off waves of enemies with sturdy defense design, while watching highly efficient networks you've built perform admirably... There's a lot to like here as-is, and I'd be really excited to see a next-gen iteration that makes refinements to the UI and the tower defense elements.

Also, if you're new, do yourself a massive favour and check out the beginner's guides - you'll be glad you did. There's lots to learn and getting to grips with the basics early doors will save you hassle and help massively with your designs.

There's also programming baked in, so you can code in-game too if you want. It boggles my mind how anyone could write all this complexity, amazing.

The fact you can get this so cheap (or free but please reward the dev) makes it a no brainer!

This game has much more content than its pricetag makes it seem. You can really play this game for ages and not get bored. The campaign is so interesting, because after you beat a level, it still exists; generating resources, acting as a launch-point for your next level, and potentially being targeted by the enemies for a coordinated assault. It's really quite fascinating.
Only problem with the game that I can spot is that there are some pretty weird glitches in multiplayer (things on your screen the other players can't see, unit production failures, other desync issues). That and there isn't always a clear indication of how to do things. Say, for example, you want to use metaglass in your gun because you read in it's description that metaglass does a lot of damage. You would have no way of finding out how to make metaglass except by searching around for a while.
This game was made by one person. It's impressive and a lot of fun, but it has it's faults. Despite the faults though, I think the game is worth playing.

Overall the game is good but the enemy base missions were made way worse to the point of pretty much unplayable in 6.0 or whatever the latest major campaign overhaul was. The invasions are a cool idea but just super annoying.

This is a strategy/supply line/factory building game. I can't manage 2 factories at once on separate maps, why am I expected to defend 2 at once? Either I just defend 1 and hope the other one I built well enough or I try to split my attention which won't work.

The enemy base missions are truly horrible. Every time I come back to this game, get to one of those missions then ALT F4 within 2 minutes of playing them since the enemy has a full base set up sending wave after wave of enemies 30 seconds apart to the point I can't even build a simple factory quick enough. You need silicon to build units, but you are given a tiny coal deposit close to the enemy base to use? Come on, these levels are a joke and completely unbalanced. 2 minutes is barely enough to build a basic defense line, I'm getting attacked by 10 flying units with only 1 small deposit of iron far away. How am I supposed to plan out getting those resources and then build it in 2 minutes along with building the defense line? I cannot stress enough how insufferable these missions are, it's so bad to the point I'm tempted to go to the github and just tear out this garbage myself. Maybe I just don't get how to fight those missions. You can mitigate this a bit by going to a non enemy base map and building some blueprints. You can also just blueprint your defense lines to plop them down in the exact same spot and get defenses set up quicker the next time since you're going to lose a few times. 

On to the good parts of this game. The factory building is really fun and has a perfect amount of complexity. The combination of the factory building and defense can be super fun. On top of that some progression is added in the form of upgrades. There are quite a few non enemy base missions available, making this game still a thumbs up. A very angry thumbs down for the enemy base missions though.

Factorio with far better combat and episodic maps in place of sheer factory scale, with perhaps a dash of Creeper World 3 and a hint of Rimworld.

If you like Factorio, but run out of interest in the mid game as the base gets huge and unwieldy - you will probably love this.

Oh, and it's FOSS (Free and Open Source Software) - you can get it free from itch.io and even free (with no microtransactions or ads) on Android/Apple. Only reason to buy it here is if you want to support the guy who originally wrote it and now maintains it.

If you really feel like it, you can even use the cloud to sync your saves between PC and mobile so you can continue your game on the go. Pretty sweet.

This game is exactly what I was looking for after playing Factorio.  My complaint with Factorio was that the enemies waves were meaningless so there wasn't really any need to build up a defense.  This game is closer to what Factorio should have been.  Each wave increases in difficulty and you have time between them to build your factory and defenses. And then there are assault maps where you have to build mechs and ships that automatically attack the enemy base.  

I love that there's a point to replaying levels in campaign because you can launch resources and carry them to future missions.  My only complaint is that campaign is way too short.  I want to keep going and keep completing new wave objectives if not new maps.  Please add more content. 

EDIT: The campaign is now much longer if you want to clear all the optional nodes.  I just started playing the new release with the campaign globe but so far it's perfect!

przepis na kruche pierniczki

     1 kg mąki pszennej 300 g masła lub margaryny 250 g
     2 cukru 250 g płynnego miodu 
     3  1 opakowanie przyprawy korzennej do piernika (= 3,5 – 4 łyżeczki)
     4  2 łyżeczki cynamonu 4 łyżki kakao 1 łyżeczka proszku do pieczenia 
     5  2 łyżeczki sody oczyszczonej 3 żółtka 4- 5 łyżek słodkiej, płynnej śmietany 30- 36% 

     przepis na lukier (można i bez)
     1  1 białko
     2  ok. 150 g cukru pudru 
     3  6 kropli soku z cytryny 

     sposób przygotowania
     1 Masło, cukier, miód, przyprawę korzenną, cynamon i kakao przełożyć do garnka. Podgrzewać stopniowo, ciągle mieszając, aż wszystkie składniki się połączą. Pozostawić do ostygnięcia.
     2 Sodę oczyszczoną rozpuścić w 2 łyżkach wody. Wmieszać do masy miodowej np. trzepaczką. Następnie wmieszać żółtka.
     3 Mąkę wymieszać z proszkiem do pieczenia. Połączyć z masą miodową i zagnieść ciasto. Na końcu dodać ok. 4- 5 łyżek śmietany tak, aby powstało jednolite ciasto.
     4 Ciasto można rozwałkować od razu. (Można je również wstawić do lodówki i rozwałkować później). Rozwałkować na posypanym mąką blacie nie za cienko, na ok. 5- 7 mm.
     5 Z ciasta wykrawać foremkami dowolne kształty i układać je na blasze wyłożonej papierem do pieczenia.
     6 Chcąc zrobić witraże, należy wyciąć pierniczki z otworami w środku. (Otwór na witraż najlepiej wyciąć już na blasze). Do środka nałożyć pokruszone landrynki**. (Landrynki przełożyć do woreczka do mrożenia i potłuc wałkiem).
     7 Jeśli pierniczki mają być zawieszone na choince, należy przed pieczeniem zrobić otworki wykałaczką.
     8 Piec w nagrzanym piekarniku, jedną blachę po drugiej, ok. 10 minut w temperaturze 180°C (grzałka góra- dół). Pozostawić do ostygnięcia. (Szczególnie pierniczki z witrażami pozostawić do ostygnięcia na blasze, aby witraż zastygł lub po lekkim ostygnięciu zsunąć pierniczki razem z papierem na blat i pozostawić do całkowitego ostygnięcia. Z podanego przepisu wychodzi 9 blach pierniczków).
     9 Przygotować lukier. Cukier puder przesiać. Do miski wlać białko. Dodać sok z cytryny i cukier puder. Miksować mikserem ręcznym ok. 10 minut na niskich obrotach, używając mieszadeł (nie ubijaków to piany), aby niepotrzebnie nie napowietrzać lukru. Lukier powinien być gładki i lśniący. (Ilość cukru pudru zależy od wielkości białka. Więcej informacji o lukrze czytaj tutaj: "Lukier królewski").
     10 Pierniczki polukrować i ewentualnie ozdobić posypką cukrową.
     11 Przechowywać najlepiej w szczelnych, metalowych puszkach.
 
     Mam nadzieje że pierniczki wam się udały, smacznego

I have to say after the decent amount of time I've sunk into this game, I honestly can't recommend it. It's an interesting concept for sure, and your first couple runs will definitely be fun... but like all tower defense games, this one comes down to the same sort of core principle, it's basically the same game over and over and over and over. The difference here however is the balance is beyond broken and the core gameplay loop is more mundane than entertaining. Everything is either a cakewalk you can leave running in the background while you afk, or impossible unless you've grinded (which of course is really boring since there's so little variety in gameplay) beyond comprehension. Bosses are either pushovers or nightmares, and there's basically no inbetween. Every game's start is the same too, you do the same process over and over. Unlike your typical tower defense however, experimenting isn't really an option. There's not a lot of variety, just some occasional map limitations that make runs more boring rather than more challenging. It's too complex to feel rewarding and mostly just feels like a punishment when some overpowered boss comes and demolishes a defense you physically couldn't have made any stronger, but too mundane to actually be entertaining for the few times you have the mental will to actually try it.

1,000+ hours in Factorio and yes - this is as close to "Factorio Lite" as any game is. The advantage is it has a more diverse set of opponent. But that is also the games current weakness.
The depth of things you can do in each world far outweighs the challenge any world offers.
You finish the challenge part of any level with loads left you "could" do... Interesting ideas for production and defence you could implement.
But no reason to do it - because the challenge ends a long time before.
Game is still early access, but what it needs (IMO) is an endgame and depth

Though it was only 99p for my Ipad... (I think it is still that cheap for Ipad) If your mobile device has a reasonable processor from the last 2 or 3 years you'll be fine. Though as Factorio users will know, because the game as so many objects each with their own rules that need to be processed every cycle, at some point CPU power and RAM speed and quantity are likely to become an issue. So the PC version might have better longevity. Even a 2019 or 2020 ipad has a fraction of the CPU power of a mid range PC as well as (normally) a fraction of the ram . That might play  into it if Mindustry maps start getting really big.
Either way - for now a damn good game and (IMO) it's pretty clear how to make it even better.

Fun game. No reason not to buy it since it's only six bucks. With that said, it does play like a six dollar game. I played the campaign, which is fun, but it is a bit too linear for my taste. I found myself just spam-building the shock units (with anti-flying units as needed) and that seemed to tackle all the levels of the campaign I played (maybe half of it) without much issue. The maps are all very similar (you have essential resources nearby and have to creep out a little further to acquire the rarer ones) and the unit types, as mentioned, never felt like so much of a challenge that I needed to develop a new defensive scheme. I eventually started the next level, saw it would be go about as similarly as the last, and put down the game for a bit. 

The campaign itself is straightforward but some of the mechanics are a little odd or maybe just unexplained. You slowly gain territory around a planet but there's persistence, so you can revisit your old bases for... some reason. Each time you finish on a territory, you can send a rocket with some resources to the next territory. It feels like there's a framework here for something grander, which is cool, but they don't really do anything with it (as far as I know) so it ends up just feeling like a level-by-level resource management game. Just an odd contrast and am curious to see where it goes.

A very ambitious twist on the automation type of game and the usual tower defense.
The game is made with such attention to detail I'd say it's worth 5 times the price!
It's packed with content especially in places you would expect the typical tower defense to become monotonous.
During the campaign it constantly pushes the boundary of what is possible - from your side or the enemies.
The pace of increasing difficulty is just right and satisfying - you constantly go back and forth saying "OMG THEY CAN DO THAT!!?" and "OMG I CAN DO THAT!!!?". After that there are maps where you'd ask the question "How can I do all the stuff I want with so little resources?" and it is yet another challenge.
For now there isn't a single thing I think of as overpowered - all my most efficient strategies have been overcome by some interesting traits of the enemies - or the environment. Everything I considered underpowered has it's valid use case.
After playing for 41 hours I think I unlocked about 80% of the technology but not even tried half of it - there is so much potential for improving my strategy. After all this time i captured like 20% of the planet which I presume is just the beginning of the campaign. The parts about RTS and PVP are still ahead for me.

And it is opensource :)
Fun, fun, fun...but still a challenge.

Single player campaign currently suffers from severe balancing issues.

You will build up a starting defense, then add to it, only to be wiped off the face of the map as the Guardian wave is a literal Finger of God that you had no hint or preparation for. Attempting to build defenses to fight this new threat proves fruitless - you must either prepare for cataclysm with several redundant defense systems or lose. That's not very fun to me.

(This is a review specifically about the Update 16 changes)

Update 16 added in a new campaign system, a major overhaul of units, and a new programmable logic system.

[h2]New Campaign:[/h2]
The new campaign system is an expansion from the previous mdoe, where it was just a slightly branching tree of 16 or 20 or so levels, in a row. Now, on v16, the campaign takes place on a globe overlaid with hexes, each level is 1 hex. The previous levels still exist as distinct named hexes, while the rest of the globe, perhaps 100-200 other tiles, are randomly generated maps.

There is no longer a global pool of resources used for research, instead, each captured territory you have has it's own local stockpile of resources. Research, when unlocked, is automatically deducted from the local stockpile(s) of resources. It works, though it's kinda strange.

Instead of every map being endless, all* maps are completed after a set number of waves. 10, 15, 35, 60, whatever the number, after you reach this wave target, you 'win' the map and no further waves will spawn. This is a direct departure from the previous version, where all maps were endless until you decide to leave, which you were able to do every 5 or 10 waves or so.

When progressing to a new map, you must first 'launch' from an existing map. When you start a new map, you will have a pool of resources. Where you launch from controls where this pool of resources comes from. For the main, named maps, you can launch from any existing zone, no matter how far away, but for the randomly generated maps, you are only allowed to launch from an adjacent sector. This distinction is poorly explained and makes little sense. I give it a thumbs down for convolution. This also means that you can progress to the named maps just like on the previous versions, one after the other, and never do a single randomly generated map at all. Therefore, the randomly generated maps merely exist as filler, which is fine, but strange to have this obtuse set of 2 rules, one for named sectors, and one for random sectors.

*Additionally, the v16 updated added in a new concept: enemy attacks. Previously, there were a few 'enemy base' missions, such as Tar Fields, wherein the player didn't have to merely survive 20, 30, or 40 waves, but actively send attack waves of their own at the enemy base, to destroy their core. v16 expanded upon this concept a lot, adding in the possible event of a counterattack. Now, when there is an enemy-controlled sector directly adjacent to one of your own sectors, there is a chance for the enemy sector to send an attack wave at your sector. In practice, what this does is makes a previously secure sector insecure again, by adding on some waves to it. For example, a zone in which you originally captured after 40/40 waves, will now revert to an 'under attack' state, and be at 40/50 waves instead. Once you survive the additional 10 waves, the sector becomes secure once again. These attacks continue until you defeat the enemy base. This is a good concept, and I like it. It's only flaws are in presentation, as it is sometimes hard to tell which sectors of yours are under attack, as your only notification of such an event (besides checking the campaign map manually) are a popup notification on-screen which goes away after a short amount of time. If you missed it, you may never notice, and lose a sector without ever realizing it was in danger.

[h2]Unit Overhaul:[/h2]
To support the expansion of the mechanic of enemy bases, the units were completely overhauled. Now, instead of 3 or 4 producable unit types, there are 6 units types, each with five ranks. So, there is a tier 1 combat walker, a weak robot who shoots a few crappy shoots at medium range. This can be upgraded into the tier 2 combat walker, which is a fair bit stronger and comes equipped with a short range flamethrower instead. It can be further upgraded into a long-ranged artillery bot, a slow but powerful assault cannon-wielding walker, and even the tier 5 version, a giant brick with legs who could demolish entire enemy bases single-handedly. Naturally, though, it's quite expensive to produce these high tier units.

There are 3 types of ground unit, 2 flyers, and a new class of unit, sea units. It is worth noting that many of these units were previously in the game, but as enemy-only units. Now, there is parity between the player and the enemy, all units are the same for each side. In other words, all units that can attack you are also units you can produce, if you wish. This is a great feature, and easily the best feature.

Additionally, the player can take direct control over any unit they have produced, and even 'rally' several other units of similar types to follow you, allowing a lot more control over exactly how you assault an enemy base. It's still very rough though, and the AI is not particularly great. Outside of units you directly control, you still are limited to only 3 commands: Attack (suicide walk straight towards nearest enemy core), Rally (cluster up around the command post), or Idle (Stop moving). If these commands were expanded, it would help immensely.

[h2]Programmable Logic:[/h2]
Update 16 also adds in / expands upon the logic system in the game, adding in a new programmable language with which you can control your robots. Fully explaining what you can do with this is beyond the scope of this review, but it's a mixed bag. On the one hand, it's extremely powerful, which is good. You can setup your strongest turrets to only activate on the presence of a boss-type enemy, to save ammo. Or you could order your repair flyers to focus their repair only on a certain type of wall, or to wait to repair things until the attack wave is over. Or you could program the entire game of monopoly into it too, if that's your thing.

The reason I say it's a mixed bag is because of how powerful it is. Some things you can ONLY do with the logic block that should be much simpler. I myself did learn how to use the logic blocks and it helped so much, but I feel like the things I wanted to do should have been able to been done without the logic system. Stuff like: Turret targeting priority (seriously, other TD games have had this for decades), or unit pathing. To be clear, you CAN do these things with the logic system, but why does it require learning how to write and then writing 100 lines of code just to make my units follow me without getting stuck on a corner of a wall?

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Update 16 is great. If you liked the game before, it's better than it was before, and worth playing again. The campaign adds longevity, the new units add depth, and the logic adds optional complexity. It's the best $0 I ever spent on new content.

I thought automation/production games weren't my flavor, but for some reason i gave Mindustry a shot and I'm so glad I did. I'm still getting started at the time of this review, but if you're on the fence it's definitely worth a shot.

And the developer has a stellar reputation.

I didn't play that much of the game, but with the V6 Campaign release, I found the game challenging, head scratching and engaging.   It has a huge variety of maps to play with their own challenges.   I don't think I could progress though, without the excellent workshop items that other users create and make available on Steam.    Especially the "smart" items which allow players to build higher tier units without being expert at in-game logistics.

Mindustry is one of the more fun economy/defense games out there, and the developer continues to make creative, excellent improvements as the games ages. Bargain at this price, I'd highly recommend it to anyone even remotely interested.

This game is essentially Factorio tower defense, so it rules. The Pause is a critical feature, as you need it to map out your base expansions between/during the aggressive wave timer. Mindustry hits a real sweet spot with some of the best zone-out basebuilding and truly tense (at times) defense. It'd be a steal at twice the price, but for 5 bucks? Just get it!

Infuriating to find out mechanics that totally suck so long into the game. I get the hard impression that "it's tower defence" is just a different way of saying "we half assed our RTS mechanics".

Yes. I sunk nearly 60 hours into this game before I figured out:
 - Enemy turrets have unlimited ammo no matter if their supply is cut off: forget about trying to get smart
 - The game does not run "real time" between bases, it will make "best guesses" at how damaged your base should be if under attack, and how many resources it's consuming/producing
 - Guardians WILL spawn without notice. When this happens you do not get to see their health bar. Good luck!
 - Certain turrets are woefully over and under powered.
 - Bases will be attacked for dozens of waves before you get a notification that one of your bases is under attack.

On top of this:
 - The "AI" is dumb as rocks. I don't think it's fair to call the enemy behavior in this game "AI".  "Attack? Walk straight at the enemy core. Do not do anything else."
 - You cannot path-find for your units at all
 - You can only "control" 5 units at once, if the "leader" of that group dies, the rest of the units resume their super dumb "Walk straight to enemy base" no matter what.

Ultimately I'm sad I sunk so much time into a game where the mechanics seem to work well at first, but break down and become nonsensical when scaled up. Factorio does not suffer from these problems, neither does Satisfactory. Of course: neither of those games tried to tack on a half-ass tower-defence style game either. Play either one of them instead of this.

A cheap and fun version of Factorio x BTD6. A great factory builder (I spend hours on a single sector just refining setups and supply lines) and tower defense. 200+ "Sectors" with varying required waves to move on, 16ish main sectors, a bunch of units which you can use for utility, defense, and offense, tons of blocks to make your factories larger, more compact, or faster, and lots of fun. Mods are great as well- Most things on the Steam Workshop are schematics which you can use in-game to easily re-create setups so you dont have to place down 50+ blocks when you have maybe a minute to two minutes before the next wave. Mods also exist on the workshop, and those that are there (AND ARENT CHEAT MODS) like Braindustry and VF's Frontiers are great. This game is just a nice time-killer, I'd highly reccomend, as its cheap and well worth the price.

Mindustry is an Industrial Engineer's wet dream. I have never played Factorio, the game which inspired this one, but for a cheaper entry fee, this game is more accessible if you're interested in this style of game.

The most joy I've had in this game has never been from watching a successful defense sector annihilate a group of enemies; that fun belongs to my friend, a real defender. I prefer optimization. How much of a material can you produce using a small amount of space? I've spent hours of time building and rebuilding the  same structure in old levels to make it smaller, more compact, more efficient, etc. If you love making an efficient machine, you'll love this game.

The amount of depth given to you can be daunting. There are myriad resources to collect in different levels, and different combinations of resources force you to respond differently to the threats presented to you. Each turret accepts a variety of resources as munitions, providing a variety of ways to respond to threats. But slow mastery, experimentation, and developing schematics is one of the most rewarding experiences that Mindustry can offer.

I initially liked the game but there are a few issues that break the game.

The missions with enemy bases are incredibly frustrating. They are winnable but it takes a long time.
Problem 1: You units cannot be controlled like every other RTS every made. There is a building that can either rally your units or send all your units to beeline against the enemy, that's it. Want to select your units and move them somewhere? Not gonna happen. This is unacceptable, an RTS in 2020 needs to have basic commands that have been in games for 30+ years.
Problem 2: Pathfinding - it doesn't exist. If your unit cannot go straight to the enemy base then it will never, ever get there.
Problem 3: Enemy repair ships. If you blow up half the enemy base, within 30 seconds it will all be repaired, good as new. The range of these repair ships is massive. You end up slowly inching your way forward. So boring.

Bit of a weird one, almost a game of two halves - each world starts off as a tower defence game, you can build but the focus is on holding out, so mostly just building what you need to get your static defences strong. 

Then once you've won you can just carry on mining and optimising your factories in order to research better stuff, which in turn will help you on the next world.

The problem is the wave stage doesn't really give you much wiggle room to play around with designing your factory, then once you've finished the waves there are no enemies at all so it's ONLY optimising your factory, its a shame they couldn't keep the enemy waves going forever but give you more time between them to focus on research; the way it is now it feels like almost two games.

I'm actually really impressed with this game. I bought it originally last year on sale for me and a friend to play since we both really love Factorio. The game plays like a typical tower defense but with the added bonus of resource management. We beat the game after about 10 hours of play and then put it on the shelf as we really didn't want to play mods.

Then 6.0 dropped and we read the change log. The game added a ton of QOL fixes and other major modifications that simplified some of the gameplay elements and made it far easier to have a megabase. The region system that contributes to tech is a massive achievement and really makes the game much more enjoyable then afk farming a spot for 10 hours while you sleep with endless waves. 

Overall, they're asking for $6.00 and I can certainly say I would have been very happy paying more. Really looking forward to more updates on this game and seeing where they take it.

Holy crap what a cool game! The V6 Update expands the game exponentially with tons of new maps and adds an element where previously conquered maps can be attacked which makes the game more dynamic. As a resource management/tower defense/RTS game this is a lot of fun with a big tech tree and lots of ways to play each map. I find myself playing this when I have hours to play or as little as 10 minutes as it is easy to hop into it and make progress.

[h1] Why I don’t recommend Mindustry[/h1]

[b]First of all, you need to learn A LOT. The main issue with this is that you need to find everything out by yourself, and make some guesses how to actually use and obtain everything, based on a ‘tech tree’. If you need something, but have not yet unlocked any of those items, good luck. It’s not like this game will explain what to actually do.[/b]

[url=https://steamuserimages-a.akamaihd.net/ugc/1648845741575587556/312CBEED1ADA70786FD786BC73A8B19D81B31C6B/] Example [/url]

[b]Then there are ridiculous hard ‘guardians’ and certain mobs, that, despites the effort you take, can instantly wipe out hours of work. Literally. Even when all previous waves went very easy.[/b]

[i]This example was from a map I just joined, after seeing a warning that it was ‘under attack’ (a map where I defeated the enemy before - but not with that strenght), only to see 2 giants walk though all my previously placed defenses:[/i]

 [url=https://steamuserimages-a.akamaihd.net/ugc/1648845741575564367/650FAFCEA3A5DF2D4DDE6D4FF6A90F71C3351B41/] Example [/url]

[b]And finally, there are ‘enemy sectors’, where you need to attack the enemy core in order to win. It has a big territory surrounding the enemy core where you can’t build. This means you need to attack with bots. One of the issues I encounter with bots is they can get stuck everywhere. And even IF you manage to build a huge army before you attack, it still can happen that you fail simply because their defenses are too strong.[/b]

[i]In this example, the enemy sector is supposed to be ‘medium’ difficulty, and before I attacked I filled up the entire path with bots. Still they all got blasted away.[/i]

[url=https://steamuserimages-a.akamaihd.net/ugc/1648845741575488933/F8FA502BD9957C898235B8FC754643EE7F286FA9/] Example [/url]


[h1]Summary[/h1]

[b]So no, I don’t recommend Mindustry. This game has a big issue with unbalanced mob-strength and lacks to give relevant information that players can currently only obtain by ‘trial and error’ – losing hours of work in the process.[/b]

Bought the game when it was v5 and it was so much fun to play, things seemed well balanced. Beat the game and played through a ton of the steam workshop material as well. Then came v6....

The default ship is so nerfed now, good luck trying to defend your base if a few guys slip past your defenses, you shoot about 2 bullets per second now. The campaign resources are so few and far between, there is barely enough lead and copper to get the map and defenses going. Many of the levels send out enemies every 2 minutes and here you are trying to build up your weaponry when they come rolling in and you have to resort to your ridiculous pea-shooter, heaven forbid you get hit 3-5 times you'll blow up! Moreover enemies spawn from two locations (at least as far as I played) on every map no less.

The little tricks that worked in v5 are now "fixed" in v6. I had schematics to build massive amount of power or self runners easily. Since I was in end game and just playing it for fun it worked perfectly for me. Now the resources required to run combustion and steam gens etc are all screwed up.

The new weather, day/night time effects, on paper this probably seemed like a good idea but playing it in game is quite annoying.

The game's balance overall is the thing that is most messed up with the latest version 6 update.

My opinion version 5 was a masterpiece, version 6 so far has been a turd.

At first I played mindustry in a snap on ubuntu. I enjoyed the game quite a bit, but it had some stuff to polish, like the unit sistem, the lack of any kind of logic signals or the balancing in the campaign mode zone progression. Then update 6.0 came out, solved the aftermentioned problems and added a bunch of cool stuff.
That said, some people will struggle a lot to learn how to play and the logic system can be overwhelming if you don't have any prior programming experience. Luckily the steam community has you covered with their nice guides.
I bought the game in Steam to support the developer and I will recommend it in the future, this game delivers what it promises.

As someone who loved Factorio, I really wanted to like this game but it seems a bit unpolished currently. Maybe this is because a large update (6.0) was recently released.

The lack of the ability to save and reload makes the game quite unforgiving for new players. You are able to export your game data and import it later, but this is not the same. While importing does restore your buildings and the wave number you were at when the export took place, any enemies present before the import are still there afterwards. If you import when a boss (guardian) is rampaging through your base, it does little good.

The game doesn't prepare you for guardians - it tells you one is approching in X number of waves, but what does that mean? Sure, it's a tough fight coming up, but how and how much should you prepare? When one appears for the first time, you get a popup that says basic ammo isn't effective against them. Oh, that would have been useful to know 10 waves ago, when I could have prepared for it. 

The waves leading up to the guardian don't clue you in. There isn't a ramp up in difficulty - you could have a chokepoint defense in place that easily dispatches the waves but the guardian demolishes easily. It's frustrating going in to guardian fights blind - not knowing what kind of attacks are effective, how much defend, etc. The result is a fight that blindsides you and feels a bit cheap and unfair.

This seems like that kind of game that is a lot more enjoyable to experienced players - I can see it could be quite fulfilling if you know how to set up your defenses, how and how much to prepare for guardians, how to set up your factory, etc.

Right now I'm strongly tempted to move on and perhaps revisit it when a proper save/load system is implemented.

Interesting concept and some cool thoughts with base building, factory management, and tower defense. However, the game's difficulty is all over the place. Some levels will be so easy that they can be finished in a few minutes, others are incredibly difficult and take hours, while most will have 30 easy waves that you can sleep through followed by a final boss that is like fighting all previous 30 waves at once. It is just really hard to understand the balance and what to build up as the difficulty progression is so chaotic and seemingly random. Really wanted to like this, but as it stands it just feels like a weird smash up of genres without a clear goal or purpose in its ultimate design.

Imagine a tower defense game meets Factorio, where you spend two hours building up complicated supply lines and defenses.  Now imagine an enemy coming out of the blue, with a giant laser that out-ranges all of your towers, and slowly, step by step, advancing and mowing down everything you've built with no way to fire back at it.

That's Mindustry baby!

I would recommend this game to people who enjoying building complicated systems and then watching the AI destroy them.

Put a lot of time in to Mindustry (Though an awful lot of that time was just idling collecting resources.) and I saw a bunch of potential here, but I just cant recommend what is ultimately very tedious and in many ways poorly designed. 

To give an example of pretty much what happened to make me finally give up:
It has, without doubt, the worst conveyor belt system Ive ever seen implemented in a game. The belts and buildings are so sticky and break in frustrating ways. So a bunch of flyers came over my base, no problem, I have a crap load of air defence that wiped them out in short order... except one of them broke one side of a bridge before dying. The remaining side automatically glued on to the wrong conveyor and fed the wrong material in to my front line guns which stop taking on ammo without me realising.

This kind of thing happens _constantly_ you often dare not run conveyors next to each other for fear that any addition to them, any splitting, or bridging will result in resources pouring in to the wrong locations. Often it turns in to a hacked up mess as you try to keep things from mixing up all over.

Needless to say, my guns were effectively all jammed up, I had to start taking apart and replacing the entire system that was feeding them in the middle of the next wave, as the wrong material was stuck throughout. A boss came down before my ammo feed had filled everything back out, the boss went directly at my core, could fire far enough to go over my falls, did about 20x more damage than anything else could and killed my core in a couple of seconds...

One small structure gone, and about an hour of waves and a tonne of building progress was gone in 2 seconds. 
All of the levels are basically the same routine as well, so its making you grind out waves and build up similar bases over, and over again as is. Losing like that wasnt even enraging any more, just draining... and slow as I am, that was when I realised that I wasnt enjoying this in the least. The whole thing had become a chore. 

I thought the update may help, and it does improve a few things. Clearer resources, your core doesnt get jammed up like other buildings do, etc. but the core issues remain. 

I would strongly recommend trying something like shapez.io instead, it may not have the tower defence aspect, but its underlying mechanics are so much more solid, its interface so much easier to manage, etc.

Pros:

Cons:

The dev is very invested at improving the game, so the negatives aren't dead-ends in my opinion.
