[h1]From Ashes to Singularity[/h1]
Mindustry is a fantastic game that despite its tiny packaging, hits above its weight. Being a factory/tower defense hybrid, it utilizes both themes well to create varied gameplay across its maps and challenge the player. A research-based progression system, an entire planet, and various methods of production of complex materials offers much to do. A not-insignificant-feat with its one-person developer running the show.

You are the Builder Drone, arrived on Serpulo (somehow) and must construct your bases, secure sectors, acquire new materials, and recover lost technology. Every sector (game map) has a set amount of resources that you must extract, process, and then ship to your central core. Invading enemy machines will assault you every few minutes, up to a maximum amount of waves, that if finished secures the sector for you--unless they have an invading base nearby. To survive you must build massive turret arrays, supply, power, and fuel them, then launch a new core to another sector and continue your advance.

With a simplistic objective, Mindustry's depth comes from principally its factory side. All resources are infinite, you are limited by how much you can extract and how much throughput you can obtain. Thus, production ratios is the golden secret of the game, and utilizing simple overflow designs and smart routing becomes important for base design. What you ultimately make, and how much of it, affects your per-minute production and how much you can store in your core or fuel your turrets with.

As to the tower defense, the enemy logic is simple (functionally an attack-move command to your core). You can fully block off their advance or create mazes, both methods have their place. As one reaches more dangerous sectors later in the game, more advanced enemy units begin appearing, mandating heavier defenses. How to weave these defenses together is itself an artform, as map conditions and resources greatly change what you can use. You yourself can produce units (up to a limit) which can help mine, build, or defend your base alongside you (including boss units, if you can feed their expensive requirements).

There's virtually no story except small excerpts and whatever you can infer, which disappoints me as a lore lover. The music is okay, thematic but unremarkable, it doesn't hurt to listen to even for long times, so I regard this positively. The art design itself is functional and charming, and doesn't have much issue conveying important information to the player. Given that this game can run on a mobile device, that is strongly in its favor for those platforms.

[h2]Conclusion[/h2]
For its price point, flexibility across platforms (PC and mobile), refined game logic/experience, Mindustry is a great choice to pick up for factory/tower defense players. As of this writing it has on-going development, just recently putting out its massive V6.0 changes. The developer has great plans for the future and so I'm looking forward to what can be done there. Out the door, it has much to keep a person occupied. Notably having multiplayer co-op (up to 4 and more players) for PVE, it can also support PVP though I am unfamiliar with that side of the game.

Update after V6:
It starts out as a simple, yet compelling game with a few things to keep in mind and build, only to unlock more and more buildings and the theoretical ability to create complex production lines for high end stuff and while some maps get along by building the bare minimum, the moment the message "Guardian in 10 waves" the game is ready for a MASSIVE spike in challenge.
I lost several maps to those guardians because my sometimes several layers thick defense failed against them, while half a layer was enough for everything before that. 
Though the challenge might feel unfair, a lost map is not lost progress. Buildings get only destroyed partially, allowing for a quicker rebuild. And thanks to the new world-map-mechanic, you can not start with a gigantic ressource stack from a well developed world, once unlocked you can even send further ressources during gameplay.
I absolutely love this mechanic. Being able to use well developed areas to push my progress in other areas feels great. The game calculates non-active maps during gameplay, which gives further incent on not just building the bare minimum to succeed but to build up large production facilities to use on other maps.

Looks can be deceiving. I originally passed by this Recommendation in Steam but figured I'd give it a shot since it was so cheap. 36 hours later, I'm writing this review because of the impression it left on me. Mindustry (pronounced with a soft"i") is a tower defense game with base-building/resource gathering/crafting like Factorio. It's like Factorio steamlined for bite-sized rounds with a structure like your typical tower defense. Players begin with limited resources and must craft their equipment to mine ore/produce machinery to craft more weapons, ammo, utilities. It looks very simplistic and retro but has a very hidden depth. You'll be working with conveyor belts, electrical poles, pipes for water/oil, just like Factorio. At its heart, it is a tower defense game and I was surprised at the variety of builds and control it allows you. You'll start on a large map with you on one side and the enemy on the opposite and its up to you to control the flow of the attacks and how to repel them. All of the maps are randomized even in the campaign. So its up to your imagination on where you build walls, place weaponry in order to wittle down the enemy. You'll also be gathering resources, sending it to your base, to upgrade your tech tree and unlocking new abilities. This game has more "bang for your buck" than many others considering I spent $6 and have gotten 35 hours so far.

Invigorating and often challenging game of strategy and knowledge. Mindustry is on par or above other games of automation, such as Factorio, for a significantly cheaper price!
Mindustry has an incredible new troop system, allowing them to be used for many things like defence, attack, mining and building!
Mindustry also has wonderful mechanics and machines to make you stronger and make more resources to make you stronger, so you can take on more challenging levels, which have even better materials, and the number of levels is super huge!!

If you haven't played Factorio, I'd say it's a game about wave defense (and sometimes attack) combined with supply chain management; as you advance, it becomes more important to optimize things, which essentially boils down into bite-sized optimization problems. I've had the most fun playing co-op campaign with some friends.

If you have played Factorio, this game is undeniably smaller, but I feel like a lot of what's missing makes it more fun. Two-lane conveyors make for some interesting setups, but Mindustry's one-lane conveyors are less hassle. Building and blueprints are infinitely easier (balanced against the urgency of the wave timer), and success is more bite-sized (individual levels). The basic item transfer mechanics are just different enough to make the mini-puzzles fresh (no inserters). Plus v6 added a lot of buildable units, so that's cool.

I can't speak to versus-mode, since I've played very little of that, but all in all this is my favorite game at the moment for casual single-player / co-op fun.
Amazing time waster. 10/10. V6.0 really brings the game up to speed as a full fledged product and I can't wait for future updates.

Singleplayer is good if you like factorio and tower defense.
Campaign is Waiting Simulator 2.0. You just wait on every map until you have enough ressources to research everything available. This is already annoying, but you can also take ressources from one mission to the next, meaning you just wait to start the next map with lots of ressources.
I wanted to do it without, but at the 4th or 5th level you have no chance without taking ressources with you. You just have to straight build towers with no economy.
Whether the next wave is Air or Ground is hard to see, there should be some indicator for that.

Controls for belts are bad. You can use Ctrl to auto path belts, but it does something bad every other time. like just put belts on top of other belts or go farer than needed, go next to other miners which then mix copper in your coal belt.

Once these issues are fixed this game deserves an upvote, but for the moment it ruins the game fun for me.

Review updated following the update from December 2020: 

All in all, the update brought some welcome changes and improvements to the game such as the possibility for the core to get rid by itself of resources that are in overflow.
However, creating units has become more difficult since you need more resources and the amount of units you can create is limited, no matter how many unit factories you have. I thought this to be a negative aspect since big bases were hard to take over ... but now I know better. No spoiler here, I'll let everyone figure the solutions to that challenge by themselves. 
For the rest, the gameplay is still fun and mostly challenging as you progress through the bases and have to fight various units, each with particular features that challenge your defenses.

Update 6.0 made a lot of really good changes to the game.

GAMEPLAY LOOP: Mindustry is a fun game that revolves around setting up mining colonies all over a planet. For each sector you attempt to claim, you have to first fight off waves of enemies until they give up. You have to gather resources to power your turrets, and to research new tech for an ever-evolving arms race against the AI. Once the AI gives up, you get breathing room to finish up your mining colony, and set off for another sector. The AI can target sectors you have previously claimed, which means you'll face harder waves in that area. 
The new update added procedural generation for optional zones, and it'd take quite a while to take over the whole planet, if that's even possible.
The game's worth it if you like tower defences and Factorio.

Very fun multiplayer resource collection game that falls somewhere between Factorio, They Were Billions, and a classic RTS. The most recent update made this game even better and fixed a lot of the scaling concerns as well as added much needed depth to the enemies and overall game progression. It can be very relaxing with friends (early game), but there are also many more strategic levels that require precision and optimization of conveyors and mining positions. Great game and well worth it's price, even before all the new (free) content.

With this said, public lobbies can easily be ruined by griefers. A much more strict ban should be placed on those who join and just immediately start destroying everything. I'm not sure why newly joined players can destroy anything in the first few minutes. Even if they weren't griefing, there is no way they would know the total pathing of everything the first few seconds. A player rating alongside the host's admission for newly joined players would greatly assist with this issue. A way to auto fast forward waves, with some sort of special bonus, would also be greatly welcomed. 

Don't be poorly swayed by the mobile graphics. The game, while aesthetically very bland, offers a great bit of complex and engaging gameplay; if you so wish to dive deeply into it.

Note that this game is still very much in development.  I have started playing a campaign and had the entire tech tree completely break on me midway through.  Balance remains a work in progress - some units are very difficult to fight off.  The game also does not hold your hand at all (though this is changing as development continues).  Still, microprocessors and circuitry remains a mystery that will require external study.  

I say all of this while still very in love with the game.  The graphics scratch that minimalist itch (but some buildings are difficult to differentiate).  The units, mechanics, buildings, and blue print crafting all feel really really good. 

It's not for everyone, but if you enjoy factorio then you will almost certainly love this minimalist tower defense-lite game.

This game combines the simplicity of accomplishment and the complexity of the perfect factory.  What do I mean?  Sure.  You can get a factory going with a few resources and lots of tracks. Even on sale this is less then most speciality coffees.  I have dozens of triple A titles and this $5 beautiful is one of the most played games I own today. Having played both Mindustry and Factorio, Mindustry is the clear winner for me.

- In Factorio, I spend countless hours setting up even the most mundane factory network, including hundreds and hundreds of "inserters"; with Mindustry, I can get a pretty decent assembly line off the ground in 10 minutes.

- I like playing campaign mode, because you rebuild your factory for each campaign and can make it more optimized based on what you learned from previous campaigns.

- The pause-time mode in Mindustry is awesome; it lets you lay out a section of your factory while time is frozen, and then automatically build it when you start time again.

- I much prefer the scheduled pace of attacks, rather than the random attacks seen in Factorio.

- And, as an added bonus, I like the graphics of Mindustry much better.  They run great on my MacBook Pro.

All that said, I still like to go back to games like Cities: Skylines for a more relaxing experience.

It's a cross between Factorio and a tower defense game. The constant onslaught of enemies gives you a pressing reason to build better and better defenses. It doesn't feel as tedious as some factory-building games since you don't have time to over-optimize and over-plan.

It does have some small pitfalls like the bosses are surprising and gathering materials for the tech tree is not as much fun as just playing the game normally.

If you are looking for a good game for a small price this is for you. The animations and the art style I personally find very nice, and does not look like the trash graphics it once did. I played in both the older version that had some content but no a lot, and the newer version which is very expansive in its content. I have been playing the beta V6, and I would like to say I experienced little crashes, great work of performance Anuken. The one thing I would like to point out is this runs extemely well on potato pcs, even in beta it runs well. I would not recommend you playing on mobile; at times I have found myself getting destroyed because I could not place the blocks fast enough, but when I hop onto my pc i can build a lot of things faster than my mobile counterpart.

To say that this game is like a mini factorio is the highest compliment. The game does indeed take a lot of its inspiration from factorio but it remains enough of its own thing to be unique. It is complex but not overwhelming like factorio, and it is a tower defense primarily - you cannot play without engaging enemies. I think this is a must-buy recommendation for anyone who likes tower defense and logistics but doesn't LOVE either. 

Reason being - Factorio is the logistics/engineer's wet-dream but its complexity makes it somewhat inaccessible by comparison and a tower defense like Dungeon Warfare is likely more for those who are hardcore TD lovers...

This fits somewhere in the middle and I love it.

There is one easy fix however, but it requires the friend who has not bought Mindustry on steam to host, and then the you may join them in the local servers list. If you wish to play with friends on a server, eg: tower defence, it is perfectly fine to just join the server with your friends and play online that way. You do not have to be on LAN to play together on servers. Anyway, apart from all that, if i could rate this game max stars i would, sadly, I am literally unable to.

So..... We have here is Resource Managment, Tower Defense and RTS. To be honest, I really like these genres, all of them require attention, and also require resources to progress on one way or other.
What do we all usually see in normal RTS games? You build some resource-gatherer units, build some barracks, and just wait for resources to come into the house, and just start production, and then destroy the enemy.
TD games? Put something close to the road, and it attacks enemy passing through automatically. That's all.
Resource Managment says by itself.

But Mindustry has some unique way to connect both of these genres, especially in gamemodes.

Survive gamemode - More TD, less RTS, all you do is just trying to survive as long as possible. 

PVP - Equally both, at it feels like playing chess, but you had to build units to attack (or attack opponent by yourself) and build turrets to defend against opponent's units. Win by destroying opponent's core.

Attack - Less TD, more RTS. Yes, you still need some defenses, because enemy always will attack (especially if along with waves, enemy base can make units by itself). Win condition same as PVP.

About units: You [b]HAD TO[/b] build them literally, building only barracks are not enough (expect for Draug, but it's miner drone without any weapons), because you need some more resources, and somehow generate enough power to atleast kickstart them. Also every factory has a little limit, so you need alot of them, if you really want to attack an enemy, because units by themselfs are not... Really... Tough. Toughest unit prob will make you ask me a question "This one has 10k health, why do you say they are not tough?"
Remember, that in TD some towers deal with super-strong enemies? In Mindustry end-game towers are powerful enough to destroy any uniy. Just make sure you can deal with both air and ground at the same time.

Starts out shallow with basic blocks and strategies, with only a couple of challenges, but gets massively more complex as more layers are added such as power, and higher tier resources with steps to get. The PvP and coop areas of the game are lacking a little on other devices, particularly coop, but the Steam version has excellent no setup servers that are free to use at the click of a button. Great game for people looking for a tower defence game that defies the norms, or a sandbox player wanting more tech and wave based gameplay. Also a natural choice for anyone coming from factorio or satisfactory.

This game is a gem. The progression system is designed stepwise so as to not lose you. Not to mention the addictive resource management of getting everything where it needs to be, and essentially doing a small climb of the tech tree with every game. This game is great!  Some things I really like not mentioned in a lot of other reviews:
1 - Risk/Reward - Each wave gets progressively harder, so you need to choose when to keep building up your infrastructure and when to focus on defense AND when to call it quits and leave with all the resources you've gathered (which will be spent on the tech tree for future games).
2 - Co-operative multiplayer is really fun, and a good way to generate some resources for single player, since anything you ship in multiplayer is added to your stash for upgrades and future games.

This game is basically factorio tower defense. Most tower defense games are just placing down towers that shoot and making a maze. In this game you have to collect resources in order to the build towers and so they can shoot. The materials like factorio get everywhere with conveyer belts and like factorio as well as you progress, you gain access to new resources and new technology. For example everything you place can be destroyed by the enemy waves and later on there are new buildings that can repair things around it.
Absolutely engrossing, and at a very reasonable cost.  As of rn (October 2020) there's a huge update coming soon which will make the game even better.

A VERY fantastic game in the base building genre, among the likes of Factorio.  While I haven’t yet played the latter, for 6 dollars it’s insane how much playability and content you get with Mindustry.  After playing for hours I would still think about how to build and structure my bases long into my sleep keeping the engineering side of my brain tingling with delight.  
The game setting is comfortable and for the most part it moves at your own pace.  Progression is easily laid out and you get a good sense of reward when you reach a new technology you didn’t know you needed.  Once you build and maximize your perfect base you will notice a large swelling in your chest, don’t worry that’s pride because this game is difficult and stimulating and only for winners!  You should feel proud and show off your creations… what are you waiting for?!!!

I must say I've just about played the entire campaign and messed with servers a small amount at this point and I mainly have 2 things to say:

1. The game itself is really nice. Managing and building a small base out of nothing while flying all over the map to see where defenses are is quite fun. For the normal game-play when you are first getting into playing, really the only thing I could wish for is a better AI system for the enemy and bigger maps to create even bigger mega-structures on. Otherwise though it was very enjoyable and I had a lot of fun playing it. 

2. However, after you get past the initial progression (which is honestly quite short if you know what you are doing) then it can kind of drag on. At this point you can only really play on MP where people will either accept anarchy or already be in end game and just have the enemy waves boxed in which is not all that fun. There is PvP as well which is one of the more interesting areas I will concede. Overall I guess I can say I am just looking for more if anything and I hope that they can bring more eventually. This game is worth more than factorio IMO. Factorio may be heavily optimized for things like Mega Bases which this game also has, but this game just plays way better from start to end. From it's music, to its minimal art style, to the synergy and well balanced trade-offs of every approach or solution, forcing the player to think about every decision, without being too heavily punished for taking the easy route. Every aspect of this game reinforces the idea that more!=better... better=better. Nothing in the game exists in such a way that it feels annoying, irrelevant, or useless. 

This game encourages experimentation because not everything is always as it seems on the surface. Discovering the hidden uses and techniques for some items can be very exciting, as you cant wait to start actually leveraging them in each run though.

I've been supporting this game since it was free and must say that its seriously a gem, unmatched by its competitors.

I also really like the quick mobility and freedom the player has right from the start. Very little is any player just waiting on for stuff to happen. They are either planning and staging construction with time frozen, or they are or actively doing stuff.

Something else that makes it better than Factorio, is that it forces the player to restart as enemy waves are actually a force to be reckoned with. Intelligent approach to base design is still a factor but enemy waves force TIME to actually matter. Every second counts.

I seriously look forward to every update, and cant wait to see what the dev(s?) has in store for 6.0

This game is AMAZBALLS!  As many others have said, best game ever {for its genre}, and this thing is a multi-genre masterpiece so it meets best ever for all those genres.  I believe I'm somewhere between 60-80% through the tech tree and I have another 5 or 6 maps to unlock, but holy moley, this game is BRILLIANT!  I love how you stockpile the resources from the current map to then help you unlock the tech tree, but only after you've completed a map, AND you get to end the map when ever you want, as long as your on the right wave.  

Some other tower defense games only allow progression during the current battle and once the battle is over progression ends there.  Not this puppy. You feel like your progression is continual through out the span of the whole game.  Resources gained from winning a battle translate to global gains which can then be carried over to the next battle if you so choose.   Sure you have to start over, but you can come in with a huge stock pile of resources to quickly get built up and ready to annihilate any mobs that dare show their puny little faces.

All of this game is amazingly built within a tiny little 86Mb package.  Did I mention AMAZING!!!  The extras that come with this game are equally AMAZING too.  I've been nerding out on this game non-stop for the past two days save for a few hours of sleep and pause time to spend with the family, and I only picked it up 2 days ago.  I haven't even touched the mods yet.

Despite my presented limited game time, I have been playing Mindustry for MONTHS using my phone (It's free on the Google Play Store, with no paywalls, no ads, the only features missing are the minimap and the ability to highlight areas of machinery for copy+pasting (and in fairness, I didn't even try, so there's a fair possibility that is in there too) and after enjoying what this game has to offer through the campaign maps and progression, I just needed to say thank you to the developers. Now onto the actual review. 

Mine. Manufacture. Mechs. This is a brief summary of this game. It's simple in art style and simple in premise, but the flexibility this style permits makes is wide as a puddle and deep as an ocean. It's easy to pick up and play with the tutorial being fairly basic and minimal, only covering the basics while the rest of the game you are free to unlock new blocks (gun towers, conveyor systems, new drill types, energy supply and transport infrastructure and mini self-contained factories) and to use them in any ways you can think to use them. 

The game has a wave defence core approach, the objective to survive the waves until an evacuation opportunity arrives (every 2, 5, 10 or 20 waves depending on the map) or you destroy the enemy core. Resources you bring into you core can be used for construction but leftover resources pulled out when you evacuate are saved for tech-tree progression and can be re-deployed on replayed maps, giving you the freedom to give yourself a head-start when replying maps. Defence towers come in a wide range that are slowly unlocked, initially a simple but flexible anti-ground/anti-air gun that requires you feed it a supply of copper for ammunition. More guns = more copper for ammo. As you progress you unlock walls you can use to block enemy bullets and ground mechs (which will become increasingly plentiful and immense as the waves progress) as well as automated healing towers that use energy to repair walls and turrets, force field projectors, you can manufacture your own drones and mechs and many gun towers can take multiple types of ammunition, meaning that if you can build up the infrastructure, you can make a battery of simple turrets into incindiary turrets just by supplying them with the pyratite instead of lead (which can also be fed to artillery towers, meaning streamlined supply lines and more fire! Just don't let your demand outstrip your supply capabilities or you may find you're unable to produce enough ammo). 

The game includes level editors that let you both trial designs in a sandbox mode and to construct even the finest details of your own level designs for challenges or fun. There is also mod support and multiplayer, which honestly scares me a bit (I'm not that good, barely able to beat the campaign yet so playing other players, while insightful, will leave me a wounded man). 

The fun of coming up with (or finding out about other's) new designs to make better use of your space or your resources is always rewarding, but then you start to gamble the value of spending more time gathering resources in a dangerous region or do you leave while you still can? Before something truly devastating breaks through your defences... 

The cons of the game do exist, there isn't much in the way of story at all (yet) and while the game is receiving regular updates on both mobile and PC and bugs are few and far between, the campaign levels are built on the premise of being replayed as there aren't many of them. There is no voice acting (no characters to be fair, and other great games have told their stories without words before, just look at Hyper Light Drifter) and the music, while very fitting for the theme and honestly kinda epic, doesn't last long and often leaves you in the relative silence of your droning drills and crackle of cannon fire. These things do seem nitpicky - and the are because I had to really think of these things to find anything wrong with it. Honestly a great game even at full price. 

Well, if you've had any interest in Factorio or SatisFactory, this will be the beautifully simple and elegant cousin to those titles at a fraction of the cost with oh so much to offer its shocking in this day and age of game development. For a mobile game it's shocking and damn impressive. For a PC game it's more expected but by no means any less fantastic than I've already given credit for. 

Well, if you've read this far, you're probably interested in the game... Go try it on your phone or buy it now and see what all this noise is about for yourself!
It's great. Devs need to to release more content, I think we're all happy to pay for it.

It's basically what I thought -- Factorio meets tower defense. They've made some good tweaks to support the format -- you can move around the map quickly, construction is fast, resources are mostly plentiful, and you can convert your avatar into other forms that are better for combat. Without those sorts of changes, I don't think the game would be as strong.

A lot of the difficulty is in figuring out the logistics of getting the right materials to the right place at the right time. Because you can try different approaches, there's a lot of replay value on individual stages. On some stages the starting point is randomized, which also contributes to the replay value.

All in all it's pretty solid, and I'm looking forward to trying out multiplayer mode.

Mindustry draws a lot of comparisons to Factorio, for obvious reasons: superficially, they both appear to be about factory construction and resource collection/cultivation. Under the hood, though, I find them to be refreshingly different: to me, Factorio is ultimately an optimization game, and Mindustry practically encourages the opposite. In Factorio, unless you're playing on a death planet, your defenses will eventually far outpace the modest offensive capabilities of the biters. Mindustry, in contrast, is a tower defense: the longer the map wears on, the more challenging the enemies. So between the two games, your base develops in very different ways: whereas Factorio will have you throwing things together as you start knowing you'll have endless opportunities to improve, Mindustry to a great extent encourages careful thought about base layout through the midgame. As the map wears on, you'll spend more and more time shoring up the frontlines, with less and less opportunity to tweak your infrastructure. The changes you do need to make to your supply line become more and more haphazard, with conveyor belts crisscrossing each other willy-nilly in whatever arrangement is necessary to get things done quickly, consequences be damned. If Factorio is like programming, then Mindustry is pounding on the keyboard at 3 AM the night before the big demo.

As far as nitty-gritty technical stuff goes, it's worth mentioning that the game's multiplayer mode handles latency much better than does Factorio. If you want to play a factory-building game with a friend who's a long ways away, you're going to have a much better time with this.

Calling the game a tower defense game might be a bit misleading. It actually has more in common with Factorio. The main focus is resource gathering, production chains and logistics, and that part of the game is really fun. It's not as complex as Factorio, but it's more accessible and fast paced.

I didn't like the actual "tower defense" aspect of the game. There's no challenge at all, which also makes it feel like the base building has no purpose. The main issues are:
- Building up economy is too fast. By the time the first enemy wave arrives you already have massive income and strong defenses, often completely skipping lower tier buildings.
- This is made worse by the fact that entire map and all the resources are immediately accessible. With the exception of couple of campaign missions and some custom maps you don't have to fight to secure them.
- No need to research tech during games. You can build the best stuff as soon as you get the resources.
- Waves mostly just increase the number of enemies, which doesn't matter because they all die to AoE damage anyway. Only boss units are a threat.
- Waves only start to become a problem long after you've maxed all defenses. You might have to wait 500+ waves to get there, which is boring.
- Enemies always spawn in same location so it's easy to just build a blockade around the spawn point.
- Enemy pathing is extremely exploitable.
- A lot of the combat mechanics, like different turret types and ammo, are  wasted, because some of them are much better than others in the endgame.

I did't try multiplayer, but I've heard good things about it. I downloaded some custom maps, and they seem to suffer from the same lack of challenge as the campaign maps. There are some good attack mode maps though.

The game is in active development, so I hope that they improve the combat in some way. Instead of trying to force the game into the classic tower defense format I feel it should be more like an RTS game. Having an actual dynamic enemy AI would offer a more interesting and challenging experience.

This ia an excellent game and I highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys resource management games, or tower defence games, and wants to take it to the next level. This game has a campaign mode that will make you spend hours trying to research all the technologies (which I haven't finished yet), unlock all the maps (which I have done) and compete the configuration requirement for all those maps. You can spend atleast 50 or 60 hours doing that by yourself, but if you don't want to play the game by yourself, you can play multilayer on the campaign and in other rounds where everything is already automatically unlocked for you. There are a variety of game modes, resource tower defence being the main one - now don't get me wrong, this isn't your standard run of the mill tower defence game, it has a lot more too it. Different maps offer different resources which you can use to build your defences anywhere you want. It honestly is quite hard to explain but if you think tower defence games are boring, you won't find that this one is. You can also ay attack mode, where you attempt to destroy the enemies team base while defending your own, which on campaign is fine, but the devs need to fix the custom match mode where the enemy literally has nothing and does nothing, unless you build something of course. You can also have a battle with your friends in a pvp zone, which doesn't really need much explaining, and finally you can make your own custom maps and make any gamemode you want. And it's not that hard. You just drag and drop

Thank you for reading this review and if you haven't bout mindustry you definitely should it is worth every cent, and it is my most played game on steam, don't judge me, ik its not much 🤣

Like others have said, combines the fun of intricate resource trees (factorio) with a tower defense progression that balances fun and brain usage.  I enjoy the heck out of this game so far.

I often find myself maxing out a resource node and pumping those sweet resources back into my core.  Then I see a enemy wave is spawning so I rush to build some defenses but end up shooting most of the enemies myself.  Then I overbuild defense and lack upper tier resources.  Then I realize I only have 1 wave until I need to JUMP off the planet to keep all my goodies I've pumped into my core.  Really fun and good learning curve, but a bit difficult for the casual TD player.  If you are greedy with taking resources it becomes very difficult, if you are safe and don't take much the difficulty is less.

The campaign maps I've played (about 4 or 5) have a good variation of resources, enemy spawns, and spawn timers.  I find myself using different tower types, harvesting different resources and replaying the same maps with different strategies.  I feel like I still have a lot to learn but having fun as I go.

Recommended for TD lovers that want to optimize factory resource flow while managing waves of enemies.

The Short of it: Strangely fun and engaging. Makes you feel like an interstellar hive-mind mining corporation with a side of guns for hire; an awesome mix of Factorio and tower defense like I've never seen before. A+

Reminds me of: If you like tower defense games and want to take a step in a more in-depth direction, there's a good chance you'll like Mindustry.

Pros +
- takes pieces of fun genres and mixes them together in a creative and enjoyable way
- teaches you how to play WHILE you play, rather than drowning players in tutorials and wiki pages (the developers have a great sense of how to do progression right)

Cons -
- does involve a bit of grinding at times to save up resources, but I actually found the approach to the grind enjoyable in this game (though I know some people don't like to grind anything at all, nor do they like to replay areas they have "beaten" previously, so I am mentioning it as a potential con)
- some people may not be into the simplistic art/presentation style (though I thought it worked perfectly for the gameplay)
Very addictive. You can play for hours and not even notice it (kinda like in CIV).
Excellent game although a bit short on the SP side. Also the campaign part could be a bit more.

This game is amazing. Mining, conveyor belts, factories, robots and lots of guns.

Looks pretty simple on the surface but there's quite a lot of depth here. I dare you to jump into a multiplayer server and try to figure out what the hell is going on lol. Campaign teaches you the game quite well and is reasonably challenging. I'd put this game on the level with Factorio if you like tower defense games.

[i] My Experience [/i]

If you had told me prior to playing this game that I would like it as much as I do, I wouldn't have believed you. It looked tedious and complicated, with its low-fi pixelated graphics showing just [b]so much[/b] happening on screen.

But developer AnukenDev starts you slow, and allows you to generally take things at your own pace. The beginning enemy waves are generally manageable even late in the game with basic resources and setups, but the enemy waves provide enough tension to drive you into creating quick and efficient arrangements for gathering and combining materials and generating power.

The resources that you acquire in each campaign level will be shipped off with you when you finish, and you can then use them to acquire higher-level blocks outside of play in the tech tree in whatever order is comfortable to you. Feel free to hold off on purchasing something if it looks too complicated, or just dive in. One of my first purchases was the "mender" blocks that use power to heal other blocks in the vicinity, and these became a staple of my strategy throughout the campaign. Any purchases you make are then available to be constructed in the other campaign levels you play.

However, you'll soon become comfortable enough with the mechanics that you'll be itching for new blocks to buy and use in subsequent levels. You'll get better and better at creating efficient systems and upgrading them as you go.

In fact, my co-op partner and I (despite having finished the campaign) still find ourselves diving back in to collect more resources and unlock more advanced blocks. There is something immensely satisfying about just looking out upon the complex conveyor systems that you and your partner have created over perhaps 20-30 enemy waves. And there's even more advanced blocks we haven't unlocked and wave thresholds we haven't survived. I've done 100 (which took quite a while), but there is an achievement for 500 as well!

It's hard to make statements about Mindustry like "if you like X, you'll definitely like Mindustry!" because I haven't really played anything else like it (although now I am certainly interested in Factorio). Mindustry showed me an itch I didn't know I had, for a certain type of game. A new itch sounds like a bad thing, but this one is just so satisfying to scratch.
just get it

To the people who think this is factorio : Turn back, this is not factorio, this is nothing like factorio, and the people advertising it as factorio clearly played like... 2 hours on it...

So, if mindustry isn't factorio, what is mindustry?

It's a very arcade-like game, much more focused on combat and problem solving, than factory building

Yes, you do build a factory, but that's the thing, nothing's exactly practical, the fact nothing has a clear output makes building something optimised and compact complicated, plitters can slow things down, certain ways to transfer your ressources can stagger your ressources and you'll most likely have the case of a random ressource being on the wrong conveyor belt and blocking your entire production...

This is where the main part of the game is, it's more of a puzzle game if anything

Compare it to factorio, where the whole point of the game is to make those huuuuge, ultra optimised industries, with most threats really handled by simply having energy, here the whole point of getting ressources is so you can power up turrets in order to defend yourself.

The combat is a massive part of this game, less as in, you're gonna actually fight yourself, but as in, making defenses to manipulate the enemy AI and manage to deal with the (Very numerous and very real) threats the game sends at you.

Game's mostly got two types of enemies, grounded and flying, each having a bunch of various units, which you must defend against with (just as numerous) turrets, much like the enemies, each really fills-in a function, some deal with aerial enemies better than others, some can only attack grounded, some are more AoE based, some are literally artillery, and most of those turrets can drastically vary in use depending on the ammo you feed them, or if you manage to bring liquid to them or not

This game, simply put, is extremely good, but if you go in expecting factorio, you're gonna have a bad surprise.

Like Factorio but with more combat and a higher degree of tension.  The campaign is short, and the game still needs some work, but I had a great time beating the campaign with a friend. If you have a friend to play with, I wholeheartedly recommend the game.

Even when you think you've completed every objective or have explored every possible combination of turrets and ammo, something new reveals itself.  Strangely enough, I actually quit playing this game after spending only 10 minutes on the campaign. Do yourself a favor and don't drop the game because it requires some advanced learning. Stick with it and I promise you'll have a ton of fun!

I highly recommend this game to anyone interested in this genre.

A hybrid of tower defense, factory, and RTS genres. The pieces fit together pretty well, and there are some nice conveniences like copy and paste schematics.

The "survive" missions feel like a factory game where you build the perfect factory to supply your front line turrets well enough to stop the boss waves. You can build mazes like in standard TD but the enemies will shoot your wall blocks.

The "destroy enemy core" missions feel more like an RTS where you need to get built up quickly (rather than perfectly) and go on the offensive. You don't control your attack drones directly though.

Likely one of the best Tower Defense games I have played in recent time. If you like Factorio or other factory building games, then this will be right for you. The campaign has a simple structure; Land on the site, mine the resources, choose to divert it to your front lines to load your guns or to your core for construction, then EVAC to claim all the resources in your core for R&D or to boost a future expedition.

The games art is basic, but its simple and makes it easy to identify things on screen. I never mistake a resource at a glance and can keep track of all my lines to find jams. The only thing that could use better is mech colours as the main body is the same steel grey.  The sound track almost sounds Risk of Rain inspired. The multiplayer can be crazy as everyone splits off to build factory sections. The game is also cross platform, where PC and mobile players can work together (Android and iOS)

And at $6 while this game is cheap and well worth the price given the workshop support and other steam features, the game is actually free and open source. The steam version just makes things like multiplayer, modding and so on more automated. If you just want to try it feel free to go find the game on GitHub or Itch Io.

I have factorio and satisfactory and I feel like there is a comparison between the games in how you build increasingly complex industry from the resources available around the map. I feel with this game though it stands out from the other two because there is a campaign with a shared resource pool and tech tree. I find myself going back and playing levels I've already played to farm resources and refine my factory designs. The focus of defense and industry feels like it gives you greater purpose then just build and build more the way that Factorio and Satisfactory do.

Compared to Factorio: Factorio has a more complex resource management and generated maps instead of standardized ones. You can make more impressive factories in factorio, but I feel like the game is more focused and 'fun' in Mindustry.

Compared to Satisfactory: The graphics in Mindustry are very basic comparatively to Satisfactory. One is top down java game, the other is a first person factory builder with graphics that can tax current gen graphics cards. While there are some 'threats' in Satisfactory, there's no real need to heavily fortify your factories, its mostly just building bigger and bigger.

In the end, I feel like every one is going to subjectively like one game over the other, but I think of the three, I have played and enjoyed Mindustry the most. Just my $0.02.

The gameplay of Mindustry may not be as deep as that of Factorio, but it is still good. The gameplay is also sufficiently different, so that even as a Factorio veteran, I enjoy playing this game, even if many things are similar to Factorio. Also, the game is five times cheaper than Factorio, so it was certainly worth buying for me. (Factorio is well worth the asking price too, though).

It also has some nice features that Factorio does not have. One thing that I really like about this game is that you can increase the firing rate of your turrets by supplying coolant (for example water or something better) to them. This is not possible in Factorio.

Mindustry is a game I want to finish, but it's not a game I've enjoyed. The UI is exceptionally bad. Hotkeys that change whenever you unlock new tech. A volume slider that only works if you move it very slowly. Building mechanics that don't cooperate with the way things need to be built. Mindustry does you the double disservice of making building inherently un-fun and putting you on a timer. Even when it's nice (you can pause and look around and plan), it goes out of its way to be annoying. Pausing makes the camera very slow and awkward, like the developer wants to punish you.

Even if the UI issues were fixed, I don't think I'd consider Mindustry a good game. I'm personally of the opinion that highly non-interactive optimization puzzles aren't that fun to begin with, and that's really at the core of what Mindustry does. Player agency exists, but only in really stupid and gimmicky ways - the AI considers you a high priority target, and you can exploit this by standing inside walls, making the AI spread its damage out so your defenses function better. For the most part, there just isn't that much thinking OR acting to do, just pause, painfully queue up a bunch of building, and then unpause and painfully wait for it to finish.

I'll probably grind out the rest of the content out of some stupid sunk cost feeling, but I can honestly say I've only had fun a very small minority of the time I've spent playing this game, and the more I play it, the more that enjoyable percentage goes down. If you're thinking about buying this game, just go pick a Factorio mod that changes the enemies. It'll be a lot more fun.

I'm at 22 hours in, which I think isn't very far.  This thing is addictive as heck!   

If you like Factorio, this has many of the same ideas, but in simpler forms.  You're building a tiny economy to supply your turrets to defend your core while you loot resources.  It starts out quite simple, and ramps up quite a long way in complexity.  But the reward loop is phenomenal; after you figure out a new tier of goods and get a new weapon up and running, there are huge fireworks and life is amazing for a bit.  And then you're off building up for the next tier and even more massive weapons.  

I love Factorio to death; it's a much better building game.  But this has many of its good qualities in a simpler format, with a very strong element of time pressure.  It is, after all, a tower defense game.   And its weapons are a lot more fun than Factorio's....  there's something very satisfying about a new Mindustry turret that I never felt much with Factorio.  Factorio's laser turrets are super effective, but they're not *fun*.  Mindustry's are just fun to play with. 

They've really priced this thing to move; I would consider the price fair if it were much more expensive than it is.

The only complain I have so far is about HUD elements being hidden or poorly displayed, e.g tech tree that should be shown at the active screen instead of having players press ESC to research stuff on a completely separate menu... OR it should at least be hinted at the right bottom alongside the building menu.

If you like complex base building + tower defense + huge resource management, go for it when on sale. Although good I don't think its worth its full price atm. Mind that it may be very time consuming to learn how to survive and transport stuff through the map in an efficient way.
If you don't have that much time to spare learning and rebuilding over and over and over, skip this title.
This game is good if you like survival, tower defense, and if you want something not that difficult.
At first I thought it was boring, but eventually I got into it. Optimizing ore processing seems to be more fun than the TD stuff.
good
Very fun I guess

Surprisingly deep and addicting game that consumed all my free time for 2-3 weeks. Setting up your supply lines to create and fuel your defense towers is super fun and rewarding. Seeing your conveyors working at peak efficiency while your defenses chew through your enemies feels really good. In later levels, you also send waves at your enemy, which really changes the flavor of the game. 

In my opinion. using the hotkeys to select what you want to build is pretty essential, so I can't imagine playing it on mobile or a tablet.

I love this game.  I also love factorio and oxygen not included.  Both of the others are great sandbox experience... but this is a nice and proper 'game' which has end-game goals *cough* factorio.  It's that lovely combination of RTS meets, whatever category these factory games are in, meets tower defense... It's simpler than the others, but it is not simple; but it has goals.  I enjoy it :)
Really fun game, switched over from mobile and is definitly worth the extra money.
Good modding, excellent community and advanced game play in a small package
Best $8.50 for 100 hour gameplay easily.
Fantastic game.
Pleasurably frustrating
Absolutely addicting.
A great take on the RTS genre, Feels simple at first while playing the campaign but hop online and the game is an entirely new experience in PvP game modes.
Very fun, If you like Factorio and Tower defence games you will love this.

I love this game! it's like factorio tower defense. I played for hundreds of hours on itch.io and I just bought the steam version. Also, just so people know the game's available on itch.io for free. Only buy it on here if you want to support the developer
